<channel>
	<title>UWC Maastricht IMPACT</title>
	<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com</link>
	<description>UWC Maastricht</description>
	<pubDate>Fri, 23 Jun 2017 08:41:26 +0000</pubDate>
	<language>en-US</language>
	<wp:wxr_version>1.2</wp:wxr_version>
	<wp:base_site_url>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com</wp:base_site_url>
	<wp:base_blog_url>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com</wp:base_blog_url>

	<wp:author><wp:author_id>1</wp:author_id><wp:author_login><![CDATA[olaya]]></wp:author_login><wp:author_email><![CDATA[elton.jacob@uwcmaastricht.nl]]></wp:author_email><wp:author_display_name><![CDATA[olaya]]></wp:author_display_name><wp:author_first_name><![CDATA[]]></wp:author_first_name><wp:author_last_name><![CDATA[]]></wp:author_last_name></wp:author>

	<wp:category><wp:term_id>3</wp:term_id><wp:category_nicename><![CDATA[agc]]></wp:category_nicename><wp:category_parent><![CDATA[]]></wp:category_parent><wp:cat_name><![CDATA[Active Global Citizenship]]></wp:cat_name><wp:category_description><![CDATA[The Active Global Citizenship Programme started as a pilot in March 2015 and this year it has become part of the co-curricular programme scheduled for all students in the Middle Years Programme (MYP5), that is, students aged 15 to 16.
It has been conceived as a transition programme into the Diploma programme, encouraging our students to transcend their global citizenship to become truly engaged Active Participants and future Change-makers.
In these weekly sessions students work on Global Issues that relate to our UWC mission through open discussions and team work, strengthening their presentation/public speaking skills as well as team management, organization and planning while gaining awareness about international affairs.

In the first term, among other activities, students engage in designing actions which can raise awareness about the chosen theme (always about Rights) of the Dutch 3FM Serious Request Campaign in support of the Red Cross internationally. Students also develop basic fundraising skills.

In April, students launch their own social awareness campaigns, as their final project for this programme, through social media, at UWC Maastricht and later in the streets of Maastricht.

The topics covered in the sessions range from Global and Human Rights Education, the Sustainable Development Goals, Communication skills, Human Rights, International Migration, Globalisation &amp; Media, Climate Change and Sustainability, Participation &amp; Campaigning and also Feedback and Evaluation as a reporting tool to improve quality.


]]></wp:category_description></wp:category>
	<wp:category><wp:term_id>7</wp:term_id><wp:category_nicename><![CDATA[initiatives]]></wp:category_nicename><wp:category_parent><![CDATA[]]></wp:category_parent><wp:cat_name><![CDATA[Other Initiatives]]></wp:cat_name></wp:category>
	<wp:category><wp:term_id>2</wp:term_id><wp:category_nicename><![CDATA[project-week]]></wp:category_nicename><wp:category_parent><![CDATA[]]></wp:category_parent><wp:cat_name><![CDATA[Project Week]]></wp:cat_name><wp:category_description><![CDATA[A project week, an integral part of the UWC experience, contributes to students’ personal development and gives them a chance to test their skills and knowledge also outside the classroom. All DP1 students design, plan and carry out a local project week focused on providing service to the local communities of Maastricht. In order to successfully complete CAS, all DP1 students are expected to participate in a local project week in the final week of June. Moreover, all DP students are encouraged to organize a European optional project week during the study breaks. These optional project weeks can focus on service as well as creativity, action and exploration in general. Additionally, mainly during the summer holidays, students have an opportunity to carry out a home country service project week to provide, either individually or in a group, a service to their home country community.

]]></wp:category_description></wp:category>
	<wp:category><wp:term_id>1</wp:term_id><wp:category_nicename><![CDATA[yse]]></wp:category_nicename><wp:category_parent><![CDATA[]]></wp:category_parent><wp:cat_name><![CDATA[Youth Social Entrepreneurship]]></wp:cat_name><wp:category_description><![CDATA[At UWC Maastricht we are committed to fostering social entrepreneurship among our students and staff. In previous years we have offered short courses with the aim of training small groups of interested students in the tools and attitudes needed to start projects and make them sustainable. Moving towards equipping all our students and future alumni with the right skill-set has been one of the reasons to launch a Youth Social Entrepreneurship (YSE) Programme for all first year students of the IB Diploma Programme in September 2015.
Staff have been specifically trained to deliver YSE as facilitators, guiding a process of discovery of new concepts and tools and fostering initiatives. Several consultants and experts have been key in contributing to the programme.
UWC Maastricht is also networking with social entrepreneurs and experts in social economy in the Limburg region, other parts of The Netherlands and Belgium.

Making social entrepreneurship an intentional part of our experiential education will allow for more interaction with the local community and a better understanding among our students and staff of the particularities of Maastricht, as students will identify problems in this area and will design specific solutions, eventually  in the form of social
entrepreneurial projects.
On Friday 22 April, 10 projects will be pitched by the finalist teams at UWC Maastricht’s Community Panel.

In the same spirit, the UWCM  YSE Hub is a weekly space/time for our final year students (DP2s) to continue working on projects they were starting or developing last year, sharing with other students, staff and other experts. These students are currently working on a project to bring UWC Maastricht closer to the local population and for
our students to facilitate more processes of dialogue and events for the city.
]]></wp:category_description></wp:category>

	<item>
		<title>Home</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 06 Oct 2015 17:33:19 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com//?page_id=2</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[&nbsp;
<h3 class="widget-title">UWC MAASTRICHT</h3>
<script>// <![CDATA[
(function(d, s, id) {var js, fjs = d.getElementsByTagName(s)[0];if (d.getElementById(id)) return;js = d.createElement(s); js.id = id;js.src = "//connect.facebook.net/en_US/sdk.js#xfbml=1&version=v2.5&appId=846690882110183";fjs.parentNode.insertBefore(js, fjs);	}(document, 'script', 'facebook-jssdk'));
// ]]]]><![CDATA[></script>
<blockquote cite="https://www.facebook.com/uwcma"><a href="https://www.facebook.com/uwcma">https://www.facebook.com/uwcma</a></blockquote>
<h3 class="widget-title">OUR VISION</h3>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #333333;">At <strong><a href="https://www.uwcmaastricht.nl/" target="_blank">UWC Maastricht</a></strong> we believe our students and staff are the primary actors of a re-imagined education, which fosters multicultural and international understanding, celebrates differences, develops critical thinking and promotes peace and sustainability.</span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/large.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-295"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-295 size-medium" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/large-300x200.jpg" alt="United World College Maastricht" width="300" height="200" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #333333;">Our students are given opportunities, according to their age, throughout their time at <strong><a href="https://www.uwcmaastricht.nl/" target="_blank">UWC Maastricht</a></strong> to develop their self-initiative and reach out to the community. They are involved in service, organize awareness raising campaigns and student-led conferences. They are also engaged in <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Project Weeks</span> in Maastricht or abroad. The opportunity to present and debate about their own cultures and global issues is at the core of all of these projects and activities. Many programmes are being introduced into our school, both in Secondary and Primary, to ensure that we make a positive IMPACT. There is not a general agreement on what impact really means or how it can be measured. For us at <strong><a href="https://www.uwcmaastricht.nl/" target="_blank">UWC Maastricht</a></strong>, it’s about achieving the aims of a planned action, assessing the risks involved for all the parts and always-always evaluating the results to inform improvement next time around.</span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #333333;">This website, news section and blogs try to bring to the public light much of what we do at <strong><a href="https://www.uwcmaastricht.nl/" target="_blank">UWC Maastricht</a></strong> to intentionally ensure a positive impact in the context of Maastricht, its population but also the home communities of our students. This is so in addition to the academic programme, tutorial system and service programme that are already in place to support and encourage our students in pursuing their various goals.</span></p>

<h3 class="widget-title">OPPORTUNITIES</h3>
&nbsp;

Get money for your projects!
<ol>
	<li>GoMAD - <a href="http://www.gomakeadifference.global/">http://www.gomakeadifference.global/</a> - up to £1000 for putting UWC mission into action.</li>
	<li>SIF: Student Initiative Fund - unlimited funding for projects in line with UWC mission and values!</li>
	<li>Swap shop foundation - seed money for kick starting your projects!</li>
</ol>
Talk to Iva for more info!

&nbsp;

Human Rights Prize - <a href="http://maastrichtsemensenrechtenprijs.nl/en/">http://maastrichtsemensenrechtenprijs.nl/en/</a>

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

There is not a general agreement on what impact really means or how it can be measured. For us at <strong><a href="https://www.uwcmaastricht.nl/" target="_blank">UWC Maastricht</a></strong>, it’s about achieving the aims of a planned action, assessing the risks involved for all the parts and always-always evaluating the results to inform improvement next time around.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #333333;">This website, news section and blogs try to bring to the public light much of what we do at <strong><a href="https://www.uwcmaastricht.nl/" target="_blank">UWC Maastricht</a></strong> to intentionally ensure a positive impact in the context of Maastricht, its population but also the home communities of our students. This is so in addition to the academic programme, tutorial system and service programme that are already in place to support and encourage our students in pursuing their various goals.</span></p>";s:6:"filter";s:1:"1";s:11:"panels_info";a:6:{s:5:"class";s:30:"WP_Widget_Black_Studio_TinyMCE";s:3:"raw";b:0;s:4:"grid";i:1;s:4:"cell";i:1;s:2:"id";i:2;s:5:"style";a:1:{s:18:"background_display";s:4:"tile";}}}i:3;a:5:{s:4:"type";s:6:"visual";s:5:"title";s:13:"OPPORTUNITIES";s:4:"text";s:606:"<p> </p><p>Get money for your projects!</p><ol><li>GoMAD - <a href="http://www.gomakeadifference.global/">http://www.gomakeadifference.global/</a> - up to £1000 for putting UWC mission into action.</li><li>SIF: Student Initiative Fund - height="500px"]</p>
<h3 class="widget-title">NEWS</h3>
<p>At UWC Maastricht we believe our students and staff are the primary actors of a re-imagined education, which fosters multicultural and international understanding, celebrates differences, develops critical thinking and promotes peace and sustainability.</p>
<p>Our students are given opportunities, according to their age, throughout their time at UWC Maastricht to develop their self-initiative and reach out to the community. They are involved in service, organize awareness raising campaigns and student-led conferences. They are also engaged in Project Weeks in Maastricht or abroad. The opportunity to present and debate about their own cultures and global issues is at the core of all of these projects and activities.<br />
Many programmes are being introduced into our school, both in Secondary and Primary, to ensure that we make a positive IMPACT. There is not a general agreement on what impact really means or how it can be measured. For us at UWC Maastricht, it’s about achieving the aims of a planned action, assessing the risks involved for all the parts and always-always evaluating the results to inform improvement next time around.</p>
<p>This website, news section and blogs try to bring to the public light much of what we do at UWC Maastricht to intentionally ensure a positive impact in the context of Maastricht, its population but also the home communities of our students. This is so in addition to the academic programme, tutorial system and service programme that are already in place to support and encourage our students in pursuing their various assignments and projects.</p>
<h3 class="widget-title">OPPORTUNITIES</h3>
<p><span style="color: #ef6f00;">[spacer height="20px"]DP student? Interested in sustainability? Check this <a href="http://innovationgeneration.nl/">http://innovationgeneration.nl/</a>, focus on food sustainability and win 250€!</span></p>
<p><span style="color: #ef6f00;">[spacer height="20px"]DP student? Thinking of putting UWC values in practice over the summer? Check <a href="http://www.gomad.global/">http://www.gomad.global/</a> and get funding for your project! </span></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>

	<item>
		<title>Alumni</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/alumni/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 23 Nov 2015 00:23:22 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?page_id=32</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[&nbsp;

Once they graduate from UWC Maastricht, our alumni continue to be part of a growing community of changemakers who aim to improve situations and opportunities for others, increasing the positive impact of a UWC education by reaching out and interacting with others.

If you are a UWC Maastricht graduate you will surely enjoy joining our alumni platform here <a href="https://uwcmaastrichtconnect.com/">uwcmaastrichtconnect.com</a>

Here are some of the projects our alumni are currently involved in and some of their testimonies:

&nbsp;
<ul>
	<li>My name is Taha, UWCM'15 and I'm the founder of <a class="profileLink" href="https://www.facebook.com/tedxmisurata/" data-hovercard="/ajax/hovercard/page.php?id=1603167526564360&amp;extragetparams=%7B%22directed_target_id%22%3A176257202553766%7D">TEDxMisurata</a>.
TEDxMisurata goes beyond being a normal independently organized TED event, it is an event in which we are trying to make IDEAS the main focus of a group of activists from all around Libya. To use it as a force to unite them and create a community of bright minds in Libya, away from all of the other political issues and the instability.
<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/TEDxMisurata.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-228 aligncenter" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/TEDxMisurata-212x300.jpg" alt="TEDxMisurata" width="212" height="300" /></a></li>
</ul>
&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[closed]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[closed]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[alumni]]></wp:post_name>

		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[panels_data]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:3:{s:7:"widgets";a:3:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"type";s:6:"visual";s:5:"title";s:0:"";s:4:"text";s:30:"<p>[spacer height="500px"]</p>";s:6:"filter";s:1:"1";s:11:"panels_info";a:6:{s:5:"class";s:30:"WP_Widget_Black_Studio_TinyMCE";s:3:"raw";b:0;s:4:"grid";i:0;s:4:"cell";i:0;s:2:"id";i:0;s:5:"style";a:2:{s:27:"background_image_attachment";i:207;s:18:"background_display";s:5:"cover";}}}i:1;a:6:{s:5:"title";s:0:"";s:4:"text";s:548:"<p>Once they graduate from UWC Maastricht, our alumni continue to be part of a growing community of changemakers who aim to improve situations and opportunities for others, increasing the positive impact of a UWC education by reaching out and interacting with others.</p><p>If you are a UWC Maastricht graduate you will surely enjoy joining our alumni platform here <a href="https://uwcmaastrichtconnect.com/">uwcmaastrichtconnect.com</a></p><p>Here are some of the projects our alumni are currently involved in and some of their testimonies:</p>";s:20:"text_selected_editor";s:7:"tinymce";s:5:"autop";b:1;s:12:"_sow_form_id";s:13:"56cc6f33d76b9";s:11:"panels_info";a:6:{s:5:"class";s:31:"SiteOrigin_Widget_Editor_Widget";s:3:"raw";b:0;s:4:"grid";i:1;s:4:"cell";i:0;s:2:"id";i:1;s:5:"style";a:1:{s:18:"background_display";s:4:"tile";}}}i:2;a:5:{s:4:"type";s:6:"visual";s:5:"title";s:0:"";s:4:"text";s:924:"<p> </p><ul><li>My name is Taha, UWCM'15 and I'm the founder of <a class="profileLink" href="https://www.facebook.com/tedxmisurata/" data-hovercard="/ajax/hovercard/page.php?id=1603167526564360&amp;extragetparams=%7B%22directed_target_id%22%3A176257202553766%7D">TEDxMisurata</a>.<br /> TEDxMisurata goes beyond being a normal independently organized TED event, it is an event in which we are trying to make IDEAS the main focus of a group of activists from all around Libya. <h3 class="widget-title">Alumni</h3>
<p><span style="color: #000000; font-family: Calibri;">Once they graduate from UWC Maastricht, our alumni continue to be part of a growing community of changemakers who aim to improve situations and opportunities for others, increasing the positive impact of a UWC education by reaching out and interacting with others.</span></p>
<p><span style="color: #000000; font-family: Calibri;">Here are some of the projects our alumni are currently involved in and some of their testimonies:</span></p>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:4:{s:13:"566ab2388c963";O:8:"stdClass":5:{s:4:"node";s:13:"566ab2388c963";s:4:"type";s:3:"row";s:6:"parent";N;s:8:"position";i:0;s:8:"settings";O:8:"stdClass":47:{s:5:"width";s:5:"fixed";s:13:"content_width";s:5:"fixed";s:11:"full_height";s:7:"default";s:10:"text_color";s:0:"";s:10:"link_color";s:0:"";s:11:"hover_color";s:0:"";s:13:"heading_color";s:0:"";s:7:"bg_type";s:4:"none";s:8:"bg_color";s:0:"";s:10:"bg_opacity";s:3:"100";s:8:"bg_image";s:0:"";s:9:"bg_repeat";s:4:"none";s:11:"bg_position";s:13:"center <h3 class="widget-title">Alumni</h3>
<p><span style="color: #000000; font-family: Calibri;">Once they graduate from UWC Maastricht, our alumni continue to be part of a growing community of changemakers who aim to improve situations and opportunities for others, increasing the positive impact of a UWC education by reaching out and interacting with others.</span></p>
<p><span style="color: #000000; font-family: Calibri;">Here are some of the projects our alumni are currently involved in and some of their testimonies:</span></p>
";s:10:"margin_top";s:0:"";s:13:"margin_bottom";s:0:"";s:11:"margin_left";s:0:"";s:12:"margin_right";s:0:"";s:18:"responsive_display";s:0:"";s:9:"animation";s:0:"";s:15:"animation_delay";s:3:"0.0";s:2:"id";s:0:"";s:5:"class";s:0:"";s:4:"type";s:9:"rich-text";}}}]]></wp:meta_value>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Oct&#039;15 - Bulgaria I.</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2015/11/25/bulgaria-i/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 25 Nov 2015 15:27:19 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=60</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<b>October 2015</b>

<b>By:</b> <i><span style="font-weight: 400;">Dasha, Tony, Svetlana, Her, Mesut, Tiffany.</span></i>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">During our project week, we worked with UWC Bulgaria to raise awareness of the UWC program within Bulgaria.  We went to over 13 schools across Bulgaria giving presentations to hundreds of students about the opportunity that is UWC.</span>

<img class="aligncenter wp-image-61 size-full" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/Capture.png" alt="Capture" width="503" height="280" /><span style="font-weight: 400;">We chose to give presentation about UWC to schools in Bulgaria because even though UWC is a big movement around the world, there are still so many people who do not know about it, but have the perfect student profiles for our schools.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Our project week was magnificently important to the Bulgarian UWC National Committee because over the past years there have been very few Bulgarian students who were aware of the UWC movement. For instance, last year there were only 8 people out of the whole country applied and six got in, and this has been a big concern for the national committee of Bulgaria.  However, by us going there, we raised awareness to young students who are eager to study abroad and who have the potentials to become change makers the possibilities of making their dreams come true.   While we were giving presentation we saw so many students who were really interested in the UWC movement so we believe that there will be lots of students applying this year.  </span>

<img class="aligncenter wp-image-62 size-full" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/bul.png" alt="bul" width="619" height="460" />

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Our week progressed like this:</span>
<ul>
	<li>We started out in Maastricht, taking the lengthy train ride from Maastricht to Brussels Charleroi airport.</li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">We set up camp inside the wifi-lacking airport, enjoying expensive sandwiches while being curled up on the cold, hard ground, congregating with the other folks that didn’t have enough money to rent a hotel.</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Early in the morning, we set off through security, a sometimes lengthy process due to the exotic nature of our group.</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Naps were greedily taken on the 20-year-old Airbus as we flew an hour into the future.</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">We met up with our Bulgarian mother, found our hostel, dropped off our luggage, and headed out to a highly-anticipated lunch activity; grilled meat one of the greatest Bulgarian traditions.</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">We explored Sofia, exchanged our money, and then were swept away to dinner to meet with the national committee; again, the meal was not disappointing.</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> We then headed back to the hostel to finalize our presentation; we had our first school meeting the next day.  After a late night, we all crashed.</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">The next day, we rose early in the morning to find our first school.  There, in front of a group of teenagers, we stumbled over our message; luckily, they managed to find some sort of inspiration within it, and conversed with us extensively.  It was a great first encounter.</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">After the first presentation, we figured out what we needed to focus on and what we needed to cut out; that evening, the powerpoint was polished and so were our public speaking skills.</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Over the next couple days, we travelled by train, car, and foot to numerous schools all over Bulgaria, ending in the pleasant city of Stara Zagora.  An incredibly historic city, we took time to visit the museum before we headed back to Sofia by bus.</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">We arrived in Sofia late in the evening, returning to our original hostel; there, we collapsed in the familiar beds.</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">In the morning, we dragged Mesut out of bed and ran to the bus station to catch a ride to the airport; we went through the extensive process of security (damn passports) and then we were on our plane home.</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">We arrived back in Brussels, and took the long train to Maastricht, with the even longer walk to the UWC campus.  Home again, we crashed before working on our long-overdue homework.  What an incredible journey.</span></li>
</ul>
<img class="aligncenter wp-image-63 size-full" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/bulgaria.png" alt="bulgaria" width="621" height="465" />]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Oct&#039;15 - Berlin - Think of the kids</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2015/11/25/berlin/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 25 Nov 2015 15:38:28 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=68</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[October 2015

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Hi! We are Jennifer, Tamar, Johan and Rushil, and this is our blogspot about our Project Week in Berlin, in a refugee camp, taking care of kids. </span>

We  splitted our team in two: Rushil and Tamar, and Jennifer and Johan, and we had two shifts:  the first from 9:00 am to 4:00 pm, and the second from 2:00 pm to 9:00 pm (which were attended respectively).

<img class="aligncenter wp-image-69 size-full" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/berlin.png" alt="berlin" width="690" height="460" />

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Every single day we used to do different things with the kids, but playing with the rope was their favorite activity, apart from the fact that was the most energy-requiring activity and after playing with it, all the kids were tired and more calm. It also worked for teaching them the numbers, counting in german while each kid was jumping.. We also made some drawings with them, played football and made masks for them to use. Our main role in that refugee camp was taking care of the kids, prevent that the kids didn’t fight with each other, and keep them busy. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">On the other hand, we also spent some time with adults, who knew a bit of english and made communication easier. They used to play table tennis, play guitar, and also they used to play music to dance. They were making important efforts on trying to be part of the society, by learning either english or german, interacting, and even drawing the german flag</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">One of the main challenges that we found in that refugee camp was the language. There was a wide variety of nationalities, such as Syrians (mostly), Pakistani, Turkish, Farsi, Moldovans, among others. So, almost none of them spoke english, and as they were in Germany, they were taught German. But nevertheless, we managed to communicate with all of them, by using  body language or also by learning some words in either Arabic, Farsi, Urdu or German.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">We also learned about the whole process by which the refugees have to go through, in order to get migration issues done. Every day there were new refugees who arrived, and waited for their documentation to be checked. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">We also noticed that the refugee camp was open to all public, so if one day people would like to go and visit the place, you are completely free to go, register, and spend some time with the refugees, which helped them to be more part of german society.</span>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">We worked for 5 days, and even though we did not have much time to explore the city, we got to know the most important places. We really enjoyed the trip, and we also learned a lot about the refugees and this whole situation in which they are going through.</span>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>68</wp:post_id>

		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:ping_status>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Oct&#039;15 - Palermo - Tartaruga</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2015/11/25/palermo-tartaruga/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 25 Nov 2015 15:43:05 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=72</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>OCTOBER 2015</strong>

<em>by Eleonora Drago</em>

For Project Week 2015, I volunteered in an assisted living centre house hosting abused women and their children in my city, Palermo. The house is called “<em>Tartaruga</em>” and is run by the organization <em>3P.</em>

I had already been there last summer, so I decided to use the opportunity given by the school to go on a Project Week in order to work again in this centre. This time I enjoyed this experience even more, seeing as I already knew the other people working there. Some of the guests in the centre were the same, while some were new. Nevertheless, it was not difficult to get to know the new mothers and children thanks to the full programme of activities I helped run. We engaged the children in both outdoor and indoor activities and we tried to involve the mothers as much as possible, in order to give them the opportunity to spend quality time with their kids.

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/image-11.png"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-85 size-full" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/image-11.png" alt="image (1)" width="602" height="253" /></a>

Since the centre is in a big house with a garden, we did all the outdoor activities there. These consisted of sports, such as volleyball, Frisbee and badminton, as well as games involving running or throwing a ball. The aim was to teach the children the importance of an active and healthy life and, at the same time, it gave them the opportunity to get rid of the tension they might have accumulated, preventing it to be manifested through violent behaviours.

My favourite activity outside, however, was the creation of a vegetable garden. This was connected to the theme of the week, which was food education and nutrition. The children and their mothers first chose what kind of vegetables they wanted to have in the garden. Then, we went to buy the seeds and we planted them. Finally, we painted some wooden signs to remember where each type of vegetable was planted. This was the activity I liked the most because of the enthusiasm that I saw in everyone. One of the mothers was particularly passionate about gardening, so she took the role of leader teaching us how to plant the seeds in the best way and guiding us throughout the entire creation of the vegetable garden. This activity is also one, the effect of which will be long lasting, since it will teach the children important skills, such as patience, responsibility, care and respect for nature.

<img class="aligncenter wp-image-84 size-full" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/image-21.png" alt="image (2)" width="472" height="627" />

&nbsp;

Alongside the outdoor activities, we also run many indoor activities, aimed to teach the children new things and develop their thinking and creative skills. Since the theme of the week was food education, we taught the children about the food pyramid and about what to eat and how often to eat it in order to have a healthy diet. The concepts learnt were then applied through games and interactive activities. For instance, children and their mothers were divided into two teams. Each team had to cut images of the different food groups in the food pyramid (e.g. fruit and vegetables, cheese and meat) from magazines and newspapers. Once they had enough, each member of the two teams had to run in turns and place one of the food they had cut into the correct level of the food pyramid. The fastest team to stick all their foods in the correct place on the food pyramid, won. Other activities involved painting, making collages with different materials, dancing, singing, as well as playing board games and watch cartoons.

This experience has definitely benefited me in many ways and allowed me to achieve some of the PW learning goals, such as providing a service to an organization/community, organizing activities outside the campus,  applying and improving the knowledge and skills from lessons and CAS, getting to know more about myself, achieving a positive social change and learning new skills. I learnt many new skills in terms of how to work with children, especially those who experienced violence and abuse. Talking with the mothers, I learnt about many different realities different from mine. I heard stories of violence and domestic abuse and I understood how hard it is to recover after such horrible experiences. Nevertheless, I also met very strong women who had the courage to ask for help and stop that violence for both themselves and their children.

<img class="aligncenter wp-image-86 size-full" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/image1.png" alt="image" width="602" height="338" />

The way these people live together also reminded me of our school. Like us, they have to respect rules, accept other people’s diversity, share their spaces and live together in a very diverse environment. The diversity of the people in the house particularly stroke me. There were women who migrated from other countries as well as locals, women coming from poor social classes and middle-class women. Differently from what I thought, domestic violence is a phenomenon that is present in all social classes and cultural backgrounds. It is something that leaves you a mark for the rest of your life. The aim of “Casa Tartaruga”, therefore, is not to make the mothers and children forget about what happened to them, as this is impossible. Instead, the volunteers try to help them live with their experience and try to overcome it in order to build a new, happier life.

I am proud I gave them a little help in achieving this goal and I hope I will have the opportunity of volunteering in this centre again.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Oct&#039;15 - Trail of a refugee</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2015/11/26/trail-of-a-refugee/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 26 Nov 2015 08:11:16 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=74</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[October 2015

by Simon, Mia, Orwa and Paula

We are 4 students from UWC Maastricht who are engaged with current issues and have decided to put together a media project about the Refugee Crisis in Europe. The concept is to follow backwards the route of many refugees travelling from Syria. Starting from Munich followed by Vienna, Bratislava and finally Budapest. We call this project the Rail of a Refugee and hope to give a holistic picture of the current situation by interviewing organisation, locals and refugees. Keep an eye on our doings and the project through photos, videos and posts.

For more information check their private blog: <a href="https://trailofarefugee.wordpress.com/">https://trailofarefugee.wordpress.com/</a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Oct&#039;15 - Belfast: social-entrepreneurship</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2015/11/26/belfast-social-entrepreneurship/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 26 Nov 2015 08:34:13 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=88</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="color: #999999;">October 2015</span>

<span style="color: #999999;">By Roan, Melissa, Sasha, Camila, Bruno and Nadira</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400; color: #999999;">We had the opportunity to be part of an intense social entrepreneurship program in June of this year. As such, we are currently in the process on how to implement the skills we have acquired by creating a sustainable program for young entrepreneurs in school. We would like to learn more on how to deal with the problems faced by the local Maastricht community, especially with youth. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400; color: #999999;">One of the challenges we face as a school is how we utilize our skills and resources for the benefit, communication and integration of the local youth. Thus, listening and learning with people and organisations who have experience in this area would be invaluable. We visited 11 projects and interviewed respective members and got a feel of what they are tru=ying to achieve.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400; color: #999999;">The aim of the project was to obtain information on various social-entrepreneurships in Belfast, Northern Ireland and utilize its knowledge in connecting the UWCM and the local community. Social entrepreneurship is growing exponentially in the city of Belfast, due to it’s constant bureaucracy and political deadlock, the people are taking action into their own hands in addressing the issues which damaging their communities.</span>

<span style="color: #999999;"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-89 size-large" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/image1-1024x768.jpg" alt="image1" width="700" height="525" /></span>

<span style="color: #999999;"><b>These are the main goals we aim to pursue in the project week:</b></span>
<ul>
	<li><span style="color: #999999;"><b><b>Design and pursue a student-led project</b></b></span>
<ul>
	<li><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #999999;">We aim to create a short-film on our short visit.</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #999999;">The skills we acquire will be implemented in the UWCM social entrepreneurship hub</span></li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li><span style="color: #999999;"><b><b>Provide a service to an organization/community</b></b></span>
<ul>
	<li><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #999999;">The ability to replicate structures and projects that will contribute to the development of new initiatives that will address social problems in the local Maastricht community. </span></li>
	<li><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #999999;">Work in coordination with Belfast-based NGOs and local community groups in obtaining new skills</span></li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li><span style="color: #999999;"><b><b>Organize activities outside of campus</b></b></span>
<ul>
	<li><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #999999;">Implementing Social Entrepreneurships in the local community</span></li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li><span style="color: #999999;"><b><b>Explore a new country and culture</b></b></span>
<ul>
	<li><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #999999;">Explore how organisations and projects handle social problems among youth in Belfast</span></li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li><span style="color: #999999;"><b><b>Improve our communication and collaboration skills</b></b></span>
<ul>
	<li><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #999999;">By working with social projects in Belfast, we will develop how we communicate and collaborate our ideas to those who will benefit from future projects and entrepreneurship</span></li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li><span style="color: #999999;"><b><b>Achieve a positive (social) change</b></b></span>
<ul>
	<li><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #999999;">As is evident in our previous points, the core of the project is obtain improved knowledge on how to achieve social change in Maastricht, Belfast and other personal contexts.</span></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<span style="font-weight: 400; color: #999999;">The general program was quite sporadic, as we ad to negotiate different times which suited us and the projects logistically. Our program goes as follows:</span>
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #999999;">Day 1:</span>
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #999999;">We met with Peter Edgar of Northern Ireland Science Park</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #999999;">Explored Belfast with ‘the local’</span></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #999999;">Day 2:</span>
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #999999;">7am train to Derry!</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #999999;">Morning meeting with Jessica Caldwell at the Playhouse </span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #999999;">Lunchtime meeting with the Social entrepreneurship hub Derry</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #999999;">Experinceing the city walls and developing knowledge on the political context of Northern Ireland.</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #999999;">Afternoon meeting with the Fab lab and Nerve centre with Eamon Durey</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #999999;">Quickly back to Belfast for the Civic Conversation: 'Having Wellbeing at the Heart of NI Society' event.</span></li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #999999;">Day 3:</span>
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #999999;">Morning meeting with Liam McCusker - Young People Leading Change</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #999999;">Lunchtime meeting with the leadership team of the NOW group.</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #999999;">Afternoon meeting with Mango street smoothie entreprise </span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #999999;">Evening meeting with South Belfast Social Enterprise Hub </span></li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #999999;">Day 4:</span>
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #999999;">Morning meeting with The Thinking Cup</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #999999;">Lunchtime meeting with the Loca Centre (Lower Oldpark Community Centre)</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #999999;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Afternoon activity - visiting the ‘Titanic experience’ and the murals on the Falls and Shankill road.</span></span></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<span style="font-weight: 400; color: #999999;">The information gathered from this project will most beneficial in the creation of the Social entrepreneurship Hub in school. Also, it will help inspire and show others on campus implementation of ideas of SEs can be easily achieved.</span>

<span style="color: #999999;"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-90 size-large" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/image2-1024x768.jpg" alt="Processed with VSCOcam with a6 preset" width="700" height="525" /></span>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Oct&#039;15 - Slovakia</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2015/11/26/slovakia/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 26 Nov 2015 10:34:31 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=95</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="color: #808080;">October 2015</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400; color: #808080;">Our project week consisted of Matej, Frederic, Kathleen, Sara, Aya and Jeremiah. The idea came from Matej’s father, Peter Bilik, who is the head of the parents’ support group in Matej’s previous school: Spojena skola sv.Vincenta de Paul. He had previously highlighted the growing number of school dropouts to Matej and asked for ideas to change this trend. Matej then suggested that a few of us make the trip there in order to have a broader perspective of what the situation is and to then provide ideas on what could be done. Thus, we found ourselves on a train bound for Bratislava.</span>

<span style="color: #808080;"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-96 size-large" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/DSC_0465-1024x681.jpg" alt="DSC_0465" width="700" height="466" /></span>

<span style="font-weight: 400; color: #808080;">The rest of us joined this project week for different reasons, but the main idea that resonated among all of us was to have an impact on the education system in the school, to change it for the better. In addition, we also wanted to get to experience different cultures and see a bit of Slovakia and Austria. The cultural background also provided a foundation from which we could understand the attitude of students toward school especially in the light of the communist history of the area. Last but not least, we wanted to get to know each other better, especially since we hardly knew each other before this.</span>

<span style="color: #808080;"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-97 size-large" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/DSC_0467-1024x681.jpg" alt="DSC_0467" width="700" height="466" /></span>

<span style="font-weight: 400; color: #808080;">As part of our project week to set for ourselves 10 different learning goals and objectives.</span>
<ol>
	<li><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #808080;"> Design and pursue a student-led project.</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #808080;"> Provide a service to an organization/community.</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #808080;"> Organize activities outside the campus. </span></li>
	<li><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #808080;"> Explore a new country and culture.</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #808080;"> Apply and improve the knowledge and skills from lessons and CAS. </span></li>
	<li><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #808080;"> Improve your organization, communication and collaboration skills.</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #808080;"> Get to know more about yourself and your group.</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #808080;"> Share and spread the UWC mission and values.</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #808080;"> Achieve a positive (social) change.</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #808080;"> Learn new (practical) skills.</span></li>
</ol>
<span style="font-weight: 400; color: #808080;">These different goals were definitely achieved through our project week although to different levels in each individual as no two people are the same. Together we designed a student-led project that was meant to provide service to Spojena skola sv.Vincenta de Paul. Part of this service was spreading the UWC mission and values by emphasising the importance of education and the role the students can and should play in building the community. We learnt many things individually and learnt much about each other too. However the one goal that we cannot be fully sure if we achieved is whether we managed to create a positive change in the school. That is something only time will tell.</span>

<span style="color: #808080;"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-98 size-large" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/DSC_0460-1024x681.jpg" alt="DSC_0460" width="700" height="466" /></span>

<span style="font-weight: 400; color: #808080;">Our project week was rather straightforward; spend time in Spojena skola sv.Vincenta de Paul each day and observe the programmes and talk to the students. Matej had briefed us that students in the school do learn English but never use it and as such are unable to converse confidently in English. We also had a chance to speak to the school chaplain who wants to change something among the students and we suggested the idea of getting students involved in social service much like CAS in the IB diploma programme.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400; color: #808080;">Sadly, as much as we wanted to do, the person from the school who we were in contact with was not as cooperative as we hoped. After our first day there we were told not to come back into the school again. We had planned initially to spend from about 10am to 3pm each day in the school doing group discussions and providing English help as well as simply making conversation with the students in order to provide encouragement to keep on with school. As such we spent the rest of the project week spending time with Matej’s younger siblings who also attended the same school as well as some children from the neighbourhood.</span>

<span style="color: #808080;"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-101 size-large" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/DSC_0448-1024x681.jpg" alt="DSC_0448" width="700" height="466" /></span>

<span style="font-weight: 400; color: #808080;">Our project week to us particularly resonated with our own ideas of education and we felt that we wanted to give others an idea of what education could be like; something that has far greater impacts than merely learning from a textbook. We wanted to use education as a force to empower the students to make a change in their country for a sustainable future - similar to the UWC mission. We also focused on 2 of the UWC values: a sense of idealism and compassion and service. We wanted to show the students in the school that change is possible and that education is something important and we also wanted them to look beyond the walls of the school and to see the needs of their own community.     </span>

<span style="color: #808080;"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-100 size-large" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/DSC_0451-1024x681.jpg" alt="DSC_0451" width="700" height="466" /></span>

<span style="font-weight: 400; color: #808080;">At the end, though we could not spend as much time as we would have liked in the school, we still felt that we had made a positive impact on the lives of the few students we had contact with evidenced by the fact that they themselves told us that they wished every class could be like what we had carried out. In addition we also had a continuous opportunity to talk to the children and teens in the neighbourhood and even saw their level of English improve as they made the effort to learn and use the language. Mission accomplished!</span>

<span style="color: #808080;">Check their video: <a style="color: #808080;" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CzBa7ZJhJZA">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CzBa7ZJhJZA</a></span>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>95</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2015-11-26 10:34:31]]></wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2015-11-26 10:34:31]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[slovakia]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="project-week"><![CDATA[Project Week]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_edit_last]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[wptr_hide_title]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[0]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Oct&#039;15 - Bulgaria II. - CMDR COE</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2015/12/08/bulgaria-ii-cmdr-coe/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 08 Dec 2015 07:52:10 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=124</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="text-align: left;"><em>October 2015</em></p>
<p style="text-align: left;">Rumen and Saul volunteered for the Crisis Management and Disaster Response Centre of Excellence what is a branch of NATO, stationed in Sofia, Bulgaria. The Centre′s aim is to pool expertise in order to improve interoperability, development and enhancement of NATO standards in building capacities for crisis management and disaster response; to provide assistance for the effective use of joint experience and capabilities of NATO, Nations, Partners and international organizations in the field of crisis management and disaster response; to provide education and training of military personnel, government officials and civilians, and organizational structures in the field of crisis management and disaster response.</p>
<p style="text-align: left;"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-182 size-large" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/20151031_145958-1024x576.jpg" alt="20151031_145958" width="700" height="394" /></p>
<p style="text-align: left;">We chose this project because we could relate the UWC mission and values to the concepts of this NATO course since it teaches you how to prevent and if needed respond, to a natural or manmade disaster. We believe that these skills could be applied in many difficult situations that have become a daily reality of our world, such as the Syrian refugee crisis.</p>
<p style="text-align: left;"> We succeeded in creating a project that took place outside of school in a distant foreign country. We worked for an organization that keeps the community safe. As we committed to our project week we improved our organization skills as we had to make contact with people in another country who we had never met and had to meet deadlines to have everything finished on time and we had to find a place of temporary residence which was close to the NATO centre of Excellence to minimize transport costs. I had never been to Bulgaria before, so I was experiencing the culture for the first time. I enjoy seeing new parts of the world, so I was very excited that we would go to Bulgaria. The language barrier was not a problem as I was with Rumen, and I discovered many new things, such as typical Bulgarian food and the Alexander Nevsky Church. One of the key skills that we learned from NATO, was the risk matrix.  The Risk matrix is used in risk assessment to differentiate the size of the threat and ways to tackle it. This risk matrix is used by NATO to assess the levels of risk a country is facing. However, the concept can be applied to the risk assessment of almost anything, a valuable skill we now possess.</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">Overall, our project week was a great success. We explored parts of Bulgaria Rumen had not been to either, so it was full of new experiences for both of us. When working in the centre, we were not given any training in the field of crisis management in a country. We applied many skills that we had both learned in Geography HL, and used these skills as stepping stones to understand and interpret crisis management. We highly recommend people to go to Bulgaria or Eastern Europe in general, as it is so different from Western Europe and will be a great chance to discover a different side of the world.</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>124</wp:post_id>

	<item>
		<title>Critical Engagement Programme</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2015/12/13/critical-engagement-programme/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 13 Dec 2015 23:00:33 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=139</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Our Introduction Weeks for all DP1 students ended at the beginning of September with 3 days of intensive workshops and presentations around three key themes: Identity, Diversity and Social Responsibility. This took place as an introduction to our new pioneering Youth Social Entrepreneurship Programme at UWC Maastricht.

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/unnamed.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-141" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/unnamed-300x223.jpg" alt="Critical Engagement " width="300" height="223" /></a> <a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Group-discussions.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-172" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Group-discussions-300x225.jpg" alt="Group discussions" width="300" height="225" /> </a><a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Adams-group.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-178" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Adams-group-300x225.jpg" alt="Adams group" width="300" height="225" /></a> <a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Role-play.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-171" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Role-play-300x225.jpg" alt="Role play" width="300" height="225" /></a>

Critical Engagement (C.E.) is an outreach programme developed originally by UWC Atlantic College alumni as a way to "give back" to their former college. It aims to "put students at the centre of a forum for open, constructive discussion and collaboration on a range of crucial global and local issues." Emerging out of this dynamic forum, it is hoped that students will develop, "lasting transferable skills (which) serve as a foundation for active roles and sustained impact in varied personal, professional and academic settings."

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Final-reflection-in-groups.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-174" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Final-reflection-in-groups-300x225.jpg" alt="Final reflection in groups" width="300" height="225" /></a> <a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Bigger-game.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-177" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Bigger-game-300x225.jpg" alt="Bigger game" width="300" height="225" /></a> <a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Final-evaluation.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-175" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Final-evaluation-300x225.jpg" alt="Final evaluation" width="300" height="225" /></a> <a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Final-evaluation-2.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-176" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Final-evaluation-2-300x225.jpg" alt="Final evaluation 2" width="300" height="225" /></a>

This opportunity to exercise critical thinking in a non-conventional setting did surely
enable a very pro-active approach when we started looking at ideas, creativity, innovation
and social entrepreneurship from 9 September onwards.Over the years, new team members have joined and it is now run by a diverse pool of UWC alumni who have adapted and further developed the CE contents and methodology to different settings and age groups.

Students had also the opportunity to attend action workshops on: Mindfulness, Play in Education, Non-violent Communication, Campaigning or Start-ups: values, mission &amp; viability.

The programme was delivered by a group of experienced CE facilitators (all UWC Atlantic College and UWC Costa Rica alumni:Ari Cantwell, Mika Pasanen, Faima Ramírez Hirschauer, Adam Cantwell, Joe Llewellyn and Jhader Aguad) and staff from UWC Maastricht who are UWC alumni themselves (UWC Mahindra College: Olaya García, Ajay Hirani and Dasha LIs and UWC Adriatic: Iva Horejsi) or have worked at different UWCs for many years  (Annemarie Oomes).]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>The Team: YSE Programme Facilitators</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2015/12/13/the-team/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 13 Dec 2015 23:58:16 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=140</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The success of this pioneering programme at UWC Maastricht relies to a great extent in the inspiring team of 12 Secondary and Primary staff who decided to embark in this project already last year. In June 2015 we all attended an intense 3-day training with Lorena Silvestri (UWC Adriatic alumna), who is an experienced youth social entrepreneurship facilitator and coach and has collaborated with Ashoka Spain for many years developing and testing methodologies to engage youth in dreaming the impossible and turning their ideas into real projects.

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/20150615_155324.jpg"><img class="alignnone wp-image-143 size-medium" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/20150615_155324-e1450050938846-225x300.jpg" alt="20150615_155324" width="225" height="300" /></a> <a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/20150616_131309.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-144" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/20150616_131309-300x225.jpg" alt="20150616_131309" width="300" height="225" /></a> <a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/20150617_130150.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-145" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/20150617_130150-300x225.jpg" alt="20150617_130150" width="300" height="225" /></a> <a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/20150617_161000.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-148" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/20150617_161000-300x225.jpg" alt="20150617_161000" width="300" height="225" /></a>

We all have differing degrees of previous experience with social entrepreneurship and the reasons to join the team where different too but we had in common the excitement of wanting to try something new at UWC Maastricht which, we believe, will have a great positive impact in our students and the local community in the near future.

Encouraged by the Student Life &amp; Experiential Education Director, Tian Bersey and the Head of College, Peter Howe, we began our journey of discoveries and trials on 9th September 2015.

This is the first time a programme delivered to students, facilitates a process integrating both Secondary and Primary at UWC Maastricht, thus even in this regard, this Youth Social Entrepreneurship (YSE) programme is innovative and promising.

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/20150617_132311.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-146" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/20150617_132311-300x225.jpg" alt="20150617_132311" width="300" height="225" /></a> <a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Hakka-Joey.mov.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-241" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Hakka-Joey.mov-300x222.jpg" alt="Hakka Joey.mov" width="300" height="222" /></a>

Thanks to the pioneering YSE Facilitators Team at UWC Maastricht for making it possible: Ajay Hirani, Anita Broer, Annemarie Oomes, Carla Robinson, Colin Hogan, David Hart, Edward Omondi, Iva Horejsi, Joey in 't Panhuis, Katinka Mastboom, Olaya García and Ulrike Jongen.

<em>Olaya García - YSE Programme Coordinator</em>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Vibrant Butterflies</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2015/12/14/vibrant-butterflies/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 14 Dec 2015 13:41:22 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=151</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Our group's challenge was to make up a chant or mantra to represent us, including as much of the attributes and values we hold or would like to have as a team:

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/IMG_1569-1.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-152" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/IMG_1569-1-300x224.jpg" alt="IMG_1569 (1)" width="300" height="224" /></a> <a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/IMG_1570-1.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-153" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/IMG_1570-1-300x224.jpg" alt="IMG_1570 (1)" width="300" height="224" /></a>

Marius worked some poetic magic and "voila":

&nbsp;

<strong>VIBRANT BUTTERFLIES</strong>

We are the <strong>big</strong> <strong>vibrant</strong> <strong>butterflies</strong>.

Spreading our <strong>colourful</strong> wings from all over the world,

in hope of <strong>achieving</strong> <strong>perfection</strong>.

Our <strong>diverse</strong> patterns inspiring <strong>creativity</strong>,

<strong>action</strong>,

<strong>change</strong>.

With every <strong>possible</strong> <strong>problem</strong>,

we bring <strong>motivational</strong> <strong>solutions</strong>.

All <strong>special</strong> in our own ways,

we are <strong>fabulous</strong> as one.

<em>Marius Lizhi Smits - Singapore</em>

&nbsp;

This new school year we, as DP1 students were very lucky to have the privilege of having Social Entrepreneurship as a part of our timetable. At our young age, we are starting to think about the process behind success in original projects, and to actually understand the hard work and commitment this comes with. As a group, we have already developed a certain bond, even agreeing in being called the “Vibrant Butterflies”.

&nbsp;

<em>Victoria Gutierrez Pereira - Bolivia</em>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>151</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2015-12-14 13:41:22]]></wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2015-12-14 13:41:22]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[vibrant-butterflies]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="yse"><![CDATA[Youth Social Entrepreneurship]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_edit_last]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[0]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>What is Youth Social Entrepreneurship at UWC Maastricht?</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2015/12/14/what-is-youth-social-entrepreneurship-at-uwc-maastricht/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 14 Dec 2015 13:53:53 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=155</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Youth Social Entrepreneurship (or YSE), is a unique program, where while integrated into the subject package of all DP1 students at UWC Maastricht, is more than just a generic lesson attended once a week. Taking a different approach to learning, looking at how our lives are affected from both internal and external points of view, and encouraging the consideration of our position within, and potential impact on society, YSE aims to cultivate creative, open-minded citizens within the community, aware of their surroundings. This experience shapes the tools and facilitates the empowerment within students to start projects, with the common benefits of the community in mind, with the optimistic goal of eventually reaping social benefits.

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Attributes-passionate-positive-optimistic.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-156" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Attributes-passionate-positive-optimistic-225x300.jpg" alt="Attributes passionate positive optimistic" width="225" height="300" /></a><a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Hardworking-responsible.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-157" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Hardworking-responsible-225x300.jpg" alt="Hardworking responsible" width="225" height="300" /></a><a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Molecular-superstructure-Groups-9-7.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-159" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Molecular-superstructure-Groups-9-7-300x225.jpg" alt="Molecular superstructure Groups 9 &amp; 7" width="300" height="225" /></a>

[caption id="attachment_160" align="alignnone" width="300"]<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Groups-79-Final-Molecular-super-structure.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-160" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Groups-79-Final-Molecular-super-structure-300x225.jpg" alt="Our personal attributes make for a very strong &quot;super-molecule&quot; with incredible potential to find and design the greatest ventures!" width="300" height="225" /></a> Our personal attributes make for a very strong "super-molecule" with incredible potential to find and design the greatest ventures![/caption]

During the introductory period, many activities have been introduced to the group in hope of developing aspects within the umbrella of critical thinking - planting the seeds for ideas to grow, and facilitating the development of all-rounded solutions. Beginning with the basics, and area we are most familiar with - ourselves, we reflected upon our life journey and experiences, how these have shaped our outlook on life, and the emotions we associate with specific situations. This encouraged the development of an empathic perspective toward social initiatives, and how we, and others in the community with completely different backgrounds and exposures, respond to our environment.

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Drafting-Community-Agreement-1.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-164" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Drafting-Community-Agreement-1-225x300.jpg" alt="Drafting Community Agreement 1" width="225" height="300" /></a><a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Drafting-Community-Agreement-2.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-163" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Drafting-Community-Agreement-2-300x225.jpg" alt="Drafting Community Agreement 2" width="300" height="225" /></a><a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Demetrio-Community-Contract.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-165" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Demetrio-Community-Contract-300x169.jpg" alt="Demetrio Community Contract" width="300" height="169" /></a><a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Community-Contract-Entrepreneuzzz.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-162" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Community-Contract-Entrepreneuzzz-169x300.jpg" alt="Community Contract Entrepreneuzzz" width="169" height="300" /></a>

Then, moving on from internal reflection to external exploration, we began pushing ourselves to look at everyday objects, such as pencils or paperclips, and brainstorm unconventional, and in some cases rather quirky, use cases. Upon completion of these exercises, were then able to see beyond the single story and first impressions of new concepts and prospects, finding solutions that are “out of the box” and original, in hope of spawning more logical, effective, and sustainable solutions. Thought-provoking puzzles and group discussions followed, further reinforcing our application of creative thinking and at the same time, allowing us to view the same scenarios from the perspective of others. This more confident grasp of external perspectives then lead into the topic of understanding third-party user needs, beyond our personal intentions and expectations. Analysing and discussing case studies, such as the sustainability of the automated bicycle parking mechanisms in Japan - gave us the opportunity to reflect on the ideas of others from an objective, unbiased standpoint, and develop stronger critical thinking skills, helping us to judge our own suggestions and potential solutions in the future when it comes to our main projects. To make the ideation process more realistic, we also studied how existing advertising and marketing techniques we are subconsciously exposed to everyday affect our ideation process and judgement, and not only be aware of information being fed to us, but also to understand existing strategies that are currently adopted in the commercial world, and how we can adapt and improve upon these initiatives to create a more compelling product that will have the most positive impact on our local society.

Moving on from this point, more examples from the real world will be looked at, and opportunities for self-reflection, alongside productive brainstorming will be encouraged, in hope of stimulating a well rounded mindset for creative thinking, as we move towards initiating our own ideation and development processes, setting the foundation for impactful solutions.

<em>Marius Lizhi Smits - Singapore</em>

&nbsp;

Now that the program has started to get more serious, I feel that most of us are becoming more and more engaged with the project and the class. We like having games and activities that will keep us active in our way to learning, activities that will make us know more about each other as a group. This way, we will become a more efficient group, who truly enjoys working together because we all know each other's situation and personality better.

[caption id="attachment_161" align="alignnone" width="169"]<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Copy-of-IMG_20150930_100430.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-161" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Copy-of-IMG_20150930_100430-169x300.jpg" alt="Our Social Entrepreneur Idol: what attributes does it have?" width="169" height="300" /></a> Our Social Entrepreneur Idol: what attributes does s/he have?[/caption]

We are looking forward to having a fun and productive Social Entrepreneurship class, and we also hope to make the best out of it with the help of our amazing facilitators.

<em>Victoria Gutierrez Pereira - Bolivia</em>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Children&#039;s Peace Prize in The Hague</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2015/12/14/childrens-peace-prize-in-the-hague/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 14 Dec 2015 15:33:18 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=187</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[On 9th November, eight MYP5 students were invited by the Kids Rights Foundation and UWC Nederland to attend the <a href="http://childrenpeaceprize.org" target="_blank">Children's Peace Prize</a> awarding ceremony in The Hague.

These students were selected owing to their great presentations about the Sustainable Development Goals to different audiences within the Active Global Citizenship Programme.

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/IMG-20151110-WA0000.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-188" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/IMG-20151110-WA0000-225x300.jpg" alt="IMG-20151110-WA0000" width="225" height="300" /></a> <a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/IMG_20151109_134257182.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-189" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/IMG_20151109_134257182-300x169.jpg" alt="IMG_20151109_134257182" width="300" height="169" /></a> <a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/IMG_20151109_135336856.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-192" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/IMG_20151109_135336856-300x169.jpg" alt="IMG_20151109_135336856" width="300" height="169" /></a> <a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/IMG_20151109_153040902.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-200" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/IMG_20151109_135030157-300x169.jpg" alt="IMG_20151109_135030157" width="300" height="169" /></a>

It was a privilege to listen to Liberian Nobel Peace Laureate 2011, Leymah Gbowee, handing in the prize to 17 year old Abraham Keita: "Is this the world we want our children to learn from? [...] Can we all make a commitment today to live lives that <span class="il">kids</span> will be proud to emulate?                                         STEP OUT AND DO ONE GOOD THING EVERYDAY THAT EVERYONE ELSE IS SCARED TO DO!"

<img class="alignnone wp-image-191" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/IMG_20151109_153040902-300x169.jpg" alt="IMG_20151109_153040902" width="382" height="215" />

Our students were very inspired by the life example, leadership, passion and public speaking skills of the 2015 Children's Peace Prize Winner Abraham Keita (17 years old). He comes from the West Point slum in Liberia and is a human <span class="il">rights</span> campaigner against police brutality and violence against women, girls and youth in general.

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/IMG_20151109_164716234.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-193" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/IMG_20151109_164716234-300x169.jpg" alt="IMG_20151109_164716234" width="300" height="169" /></a>

A memorable evening!

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>
