	<item>
		<title>Serious Request 2015 - Supporting the Red Cross for the Right to Education of children and youth in conflict areas</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2015/12/14/serious-request-2015/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 14 Dec 2015 15:34:57 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=195</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[UWC Maastricht decided to embark in the Serious Request of the Red Cross this year to raise awareness about the challenges to the Right of Education of thousands of children and youth around the world who are also experiencing war or conflict in their countries.

This was an excellent opportunity as well for MYP5 students to design their own actions to fundraise for the Red Cross and other MYP students and staff also came up with their own ideas to raise awareness while having fun: <a href="https://kominactie.3fm.nl/actie/united-world-college-maastricht-komt-in-actie">UWC Maastricht with Serious Request 2015</a>

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Lockdown-preps.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-244" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Lockdown-preps-300x225.jpg" alt="Lockdown preps" width="300" height="225" /></a> <a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Serious-request-preps.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-246" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Serious-request-preps-300x225.jpg" alt="Serious request preps" width="300" height="225" /></a>

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Sponge-posters.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-245" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Sponge-posters-300x225.jpg" alt="Sponge posters" width="300" height="225" /></a>

Their learning outcomes have been that working as a team is not always easy because self-management requires planning and effort, that lower number of members in the team help to manage it better, that internal communication is something important which needs to be taken seriously to inform all aspects of the process and finally, that the will and commitment to a project is more than 50% of the success of that project.

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Human Rights</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2015/12/14/human-rights/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 14 Dec 2015 15:37:32 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=198</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Three of our sessions have been dedicated to understanding better the concept of Human Rights.

Last 2nd December, three members of the UWCM Amnesty International group joined us to present the 16 Days of Activism for the Elimination of Violence Against Women and Girls.

The three DP1 students (Mathilde Barland, Nusret Yildirim and Emi Lee Ai Yen) talked about AI's efforts wordwide and then proposed and interactive activity for the MYP5 students.

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/AI-members-presentation1.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-253" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/AI-members-presentation1-300x225.jpg" alt="AI members presentation" width="300" height="225" /></a> <a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/getting-ready-for-a-game2.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-257" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/getting-ready-for-a-game2-225x300.jpg" alt="getting ready for a game" width="225" height="300" /></a>

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Playing1.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-255" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Playing1-300x225.jpg" alt="Playing" width="300" height="225" /></a> <a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Reflections1.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-256" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Reflections1-300x225.jpg" alt="Reflections" width="300" height="225" /></a>

Students picked different roles of a variety of individuals in many different countries and situations and they had to answer to several statements in relation to how much their rights were being fulfilled or not. A very interesting exercise which made us think outside the box and reflect once again about how privileged we are for the comforts we have...]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>198</wp:post_id>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>A dialogue with Abraham Keita - Children´s Peace Prize laureate 2015</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2015/12/14/a-dialogue-with-abraham-keita-childrens-peace-prize-laureate-2015/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 14 Dec 2015 23:09:34 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=202</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Last Friday, 11<sup>th</sup> December, my friend Praise and I attended an event in Leiden, the Netherlands.   The event was organized by <a href="http://www.defenceforchildren.org/">Defense for Children</a> and we got to meet Abraham Keita who won the <a href="http://www.childrenspeaceprize.org/">Children’s Peace Prize</a> in November 2015.  Abraham Keita is an amazing youngster from Liberia who has done countless things to help his and others’ communities.  He is also an inspiring person who believes that children have the right to do what they believe is best for them.  When he was 9 years old he heard a story of a random girl who was raped, tortured, and killed.  The story made him realize that this time it happened to a girl whom he did not know at all but it could soon happen to his friends, cousins, and sisters if this issue was not stopped.  This whole incident inspired him to start a campaign against this problem and there were 500 children who joined him.  As a child he was always very passionate and he believes that everyone (especially children) can make a difference in the world.

[caption id="attachment_203" align="alignnone" width="300"]<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/defence-for-children.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-203" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/defence-for-children-300x200.jpg" alt="Defense for Children" width="300" height="200" /></a> Defense for Children[/caption]

<img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-204" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/12314024_919013428178826_8788796030910595427_n-300x200.jpg" alt="12314024_919013428178826_8788796030910595427_n" width="300" height="200" /> <a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/abraham-keita.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-205" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/abraham-keita-200x300.jpg" alt="abraham keita" width="200" height="300" /></a>

I had some really inspiring moments talking to some young university students who were social entrepreneurs with extreme passion to help others and to work towards their dreams.  Most of them are quite young but they all work really hard hoping to change and make the world a better place. They are people who see problems in their society as something that needs to be solved and they take initiative to show the world what they want to happen.  This really inspires me to live my life fully and to serve others with what I have. It also shows me that if these people can make a difference in life, so can I.

I realized that somehow some of us don’t think our YSE class is useful but I come to really appreciate what it has taught me and how important it is to everyone and the society we live in.  I am really grateful to have this opportunity to remind myself of what I have taken for granted.

<em>Ahai Vang (Laos)</em>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Challenges or Problem Identification</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2015/12/16/problem-identification/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 16 Dec 2015 10:02:47 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=216</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[“Young people are able to do many things that were never done before in  history”.  Over the past few months we have learnt a lot of new skills. For the most of us the Youth Social Entrepreneurship programme was something completely new, so we had to start from scratch. Before we actually started to work on the projects, we identified our weaknesses and strengths. This was done mainly to identify our strengths to help us improvise while we are working on our projects.

We also had a lot of fun games which helped to built trust and co-operation among the peers. The interactive sessions and the discussions were mainly for brainstorming purposes. Instead of approaching the problems directly, we looked at the situations that surrounded us. At first we identified a problem that we might have observed or experienced in the community and then we deconstructed the problem. We looked at the causes and the consequences of the problems and tried to get to the grassroot level. Therefore, our first step was to look at the problems rather than actually looking for the solutions. This was done to analyze the problems in a critical manner.

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Problems-in-Maastricht.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-222" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Problems-in-Maastricht-300x222.jpg" alt="Problems in Maastricht" width="300" height="222" /></a> <a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Anne-problem-food.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-219" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Anne-problem-food-300x222.jpg" alt="Anne problem food" width="300" height="222" /></a>

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Mental-health-issues.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-223" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Mental-health-issues-300x222.jpg" alt="Mental health issues" width="300" height="222" /></a> <a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Fake-harmony-problem.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-220" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Fake-harmony-problem-300x222.jpg" alt="Fake harmony problem" width="300" height="222" /></a>

Having a look at the impacts of the problem on the community was also an essential part of the course in order to get a clear picture of what the actual problem was. So, basically we dissolved the problems and chose the problems that were realistic and doable. During this term we also had guest speakers: <strong>Michal Steyn</strong> from ‘Serve the City’ and <strong>Vincent Frenken</strong> from ‘Trajekt’ who are working with the local community through a volunteering NGO and Maastricht’s Social Services. Their talks were not only inspiring but also helped us get equipped with knowledge about challenges in the city of Maastricht or the region, that made us look at social entrepreneurship from a completely different dimension.

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/FINAL-Michal-Steyn.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-225" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/FINAL-Michal-Steyn-300x222.jpg" alt="FINAL Michal Steyn" width="300" height="222" /></a> <a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Michal-Steyn.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-224" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Michal-Steyn-300x222.jpg" alt="Michal Steyn" width="300" height="222" /></a>

YSE is definitely one of the programmes that can solve many of the problems present in the community and also helps young students to develop into independent and creative people.

<em>Dechen Zangmo (Bhutan)</em>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:ping_status>

	<item>
		<title>Feb&#039;16 - Animals Faith Volunteering</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/02/23/animals-faith-volunteering/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 23 Feb 2016 14:57:05 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=314</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #333333;">Our group, consisting of <u>Asbjoern Hansen, Emma Agnelli, Martijn Hatfield and Leandra </u><u>Ilkka</u>, chose to help out at the local organisation <b><i>Animals Faith</i></b>. The organisation provides dog training, grooming, veterinary assistance, lodging and a shelter. The organisation runs mostly through the help of volunteers, so we knew that our help would be valuable, and this influenced us in choosing this project. We had not heard of many existing Project Weeks concerning animals, and we believe that helping animals is of great importance in any community so this was also a learning experience for us to see how animals are treated in Maastricht.</span></div>
<div style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #333333;"><b><u> [spacer height="20px"]These were our goals:</u></b></span></div>
<div><span style="color: #333333;">1. Design and pursue a student-led project.</span>
<span style="color: #333333;"> 2. Provide a service to an organization/community.</span>
<span style="color: #333333;"> 3. Organize activities outside the campus.</span>
<span style="color: #333333;"> 6. Improve your organization, communication and collaboration skills.</span>
<span style="color: #333333;"> 7. Get to know more about yourself and your group.</span>
<span style="color: #333333;"> 10. Learn new (practical) skills</span></div>
<div>

<span style="color: #333333;">[spacer height="20px"]</span>

<span style="color: #333333;">We believe that we did achieve all of these goals throughout the week.This was a general program of one of our Project Week days:</span>

<span style="color: #333333;">- Arrive at Animals Faith 9:00</span>
<span style="color: #333333;"> - Clean outside pens and refill water 9:00-9:30</span>
<span style="color: #333333;"> - Clean first two rows of pens inside (refill water, wash floor, dry floor, clean out poop) 9:30-10:30</span>
<span style="color: #333333;"> - Go for a walk with dogs 10:30-11:30</span>
<span style="color: #333333;"> - Clean last two rows of pens inside (refill water, wash floor, dry floor, clean out poop) 11:30-12:30</span>
<span style="color: #333333;"> - Wash bowls, Clean gutter, Take out poop bins 12:30- 13:00</span>
<span style="color: #333333;"> - Departure from Animals Faith 13:00</span>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #333333;">[spacer height="20px"]</span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #333333;">Our project week was important because the practical work we did has an effect on the whole life of an animal staying at that shelter. For example, if we did not clean their bowls sufficiently they could become sick and if we did not dry their pens well enough this could hurt their paws and make them very uncomfortable. Our Project Week links to the UWC values because we had to show intercultural understanding since the care of the animals differed to that of some of our cultures and we had to adjust to that. We also embodied personal responsibility and integrity as well as mutual responsibility and respect, since we were responsible for the well being of the animals and for completing our tasks well and efficiently. We also embodied compassion and service, since a big part of our project week was interacting with animals and the people who worked at the organisation, and compassion is a large part of animal care.</span></p>
<span style="color: #333333;">Here are some photos of our time at the shelter!</span>

<span style="color: #333333;">PHOTOS</span>

[gallery columns="5" ids="321,320,319,318,317"]

</div>
<div><span style="color: #333333;"><a style="color: #333333;" href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/dfgdfgd.png" rel="attachment wp-att-316">
</a></span></div>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Feb&#039;16 - Dublin, Ireland</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/03/09/feb16-dublin-ireland/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 09 Mar 2016 15:01:29 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=335</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3><strong><em><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><span style="color: #000000; text-decoration: underline;"> - Why did you choose the project?</span></span></em></strong></h3>
<blockquote>Freedom is a value, a term, a notion, a concept that we feel very comfortable about.</blockquote>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #333333;">Right from the beginning of the school year, we’ve been told by our peers and teachers about the possibility of doing a project week as part of the exceptional UWC experience which we, UWC students all want to live to the fullest. We have always thought that  it was especially important for us to do our first project week in Ireland, since we’ve both had a big interest in exploring the cultural and social development, growth and dynamics of this country caused by its rich history with a very specific aim that this population has longed for decades; freedom. Freedom is a value, a term, a notion, a concept that we feel very comfortable about. We often like to throw loosely into our  UWC discussions, seldom thinking critically of what freedom really means to us, be it freedom of speech, freedom of education or perhaps even just the simplest version of freedom commonly known as the power or right to think, speak, act or think as on wants. Despite all of it being essentially correct in its very narrow definition our intention was to challenge this tricky privilege we often find ourselves forgetting of as we tend to take it for granted, believing that’s it’s been given to like an inborn trait,  in its ultimate righteousness, just like the color of our hair and eyes along with all the other features that have been passed onto us from our parents. The Freedom achieved by the Dubliners as a consequence of the events during the Easter Rising in 1916 holds a certain dose of spirit, fiery, mood that humanizes those who have the courage to cherish, grow and protect the liberty they’ve fought for so long , and that in fact is still the principle reason for some ongoing tensions in other parts of that country. But it was the brave population of Dublin that reminded us of its infinite significance and responsibilities that freedom brings to our lives.</span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;">[spacer height="10px"]</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #000000;">With our understandable ignorance of the city, its dynamics, the people and the historic burden and atmosphere still very sensible in the streets of Dublin and unspecified expectations, we happened to approach this project with a rather fresh and unprejudiced mindset which eventually allowed us to discover the culture and history of Dublin for ourselves, using our own varying senses, for ourselves. It was the direct interaction with the people of this city which in the end represent at least to a some degree the culture, the art, the history and hence the spirit of the city that originated from a conflict we decided to investigate.  We wanted to experience something outside the parameters of UWC, something more real, more ordinary, humane and perhaps even more authentic, and although our main goal for this project week was to investigate a conflict from a more scholastic point-of-view based on analysis that we are thought to do in our academics, we learned much more about the people, the importance of human-interactions, kindness, empathy towards one another, understanding  and humanity itself than we would have ever expected. Finally we understood that the root of all positive, negative and neutral historical decisions lays in the human complexities which we all have. On a final note, beyond the acquisition of new knowledge, new skills that we gained this project week evoked unknown thoughts in us which made us learn a lot of intriguing things about ourselves and our team members. This made it a very reflective and useful experience on many different levels which I think was what we were ultimately looking for in a project week and Irish history and culture definitely helped us fulfill this goal.</span></p>
<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW-1.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-340"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-340 size-large" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW-1-1024x575.jpg" alt="PW 1" width="700" height="393" /></a>

<span style="text-decoration: underline;"><em><strong><span style="color: #000000; text-decoration: underline;">[spacer height="20px"]- What were your learning goals and objectives? Did you achieve them?</span></strong></em></span>
<ol>
	<li><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #000000;"> Design and pursue a student-led project.</span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Organize activities outside the campus.</span> </span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Explore a new country and culture.</span></span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Improve your organization, communication and collaboration skills.</span></span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Get to know more about yourself and your group.</span></span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Share and spread the UWC mission and values.</span></span></li>
	<li><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #000000;"> Learn new (practical) skills.</span></li>
</ol>
<span style="font-weight: 400; color: #000000;">We seem to have achieved all of the pre-fixed goals and we are proud of our experience.</span>

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW2.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-339"><img class="wp-image-339 size-large aligncenter" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW2-1024x575.jpg" alt="PW2" width="700" height="393" /></a>
<h3><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><em><strong><span style="color: #000000; text-decoration: underline;"> [spacer height="20px"]- General program and a detailed itinerary of a day of your PW?</span></strong></em></span></h3>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">Every morning we would wake up, have breakfast and get ready to take the bus to the city. We had our meetings with the organization and other supporters of our project in the morning, involving visiting museums, expositions and even Trinity College. We would have lunch around the city and in the evening we would have time to walk around the city and get to know it better. We had some problems with orientation at the beginning when walking from one place to the other around the city, however, in the end, we are proud to say we managed to have a general idea of the city center and where all the important reference locations were. In the evening/night we would either have dinner in the city or take the bus back to the apartment, where we would plan our next day in detail.</span></p>
<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW3.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-338"><img class="wp-image-338 size-large aligncenter" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW3-1024x683.jpg" alt="PW3" width="700" height="467" /></a>
<h3><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><em><strong><span style="color: #000000; text-decoration: underline;">[spacer height="20px"]- Why was your PW important?</span></strong></em></span></h3>
<blockquote>We learned a lot of skills related to being a more independent person that are inherently important.</blockquote>
<p style="text-align: justify;"></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #333333;">You can consider this question in two ways. The first is, why was this PW important to individuals of the group? The second is: Why was this PW important to the general cause of the project, which was to find out more about a historically fascinating period of change and struggle in Irish <i> and</i> European History? To answer the first question. The answer is very simple, and even though I can only vouch for myself, but I’m going to assume  all the participants had a great time. For most of us, it was the first time travelling without our parents, and we learned a lot of skills related to being a more independent person that are inherently important. Not only did we gain skills, but (as cheesy as it will sound) going to a new country, where we was constantly forced to talk to people, we learned how amazing and how interesting people are. Perhaps it is in the good nature of the Irish folk, but we believe certain characteristics of kindness can be found in most places depending on how you search for them. This is a big thing we lacked in looking for in people and that we missed, but we believe we have regained it thanks to Ireland. Secondly, it is impossibly important to realize the relevance of studying such cases- for innumerable reasons. It is also impossible to measure this value however, that only 5 students will take away from learning about a conflict, perhaps awareness? perhaps the unlikelihood that it will be occurred from ourselves? It is impossible to say. Not to mention how important it is to learn about different conflicts- learning about people and stories and histories is so critical because only when we are knowledgeable and culturally aware enough can we claim that we have abilities such as conflict resolution which are fatally imperative in our lives.</span></p>
<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW4.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-337"><img class="wp-image-337 size-large aligncenter" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW4-1024x683.jpg" alt="PW4" width="700" height="467" /></a>
<h3><em><strong><span style="text-decoration: underline; color: #000000;">[spacer height="20px"] - How did your PW link to the </span><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><span style="color: #000000; text-decoration: underline;">UWC</span></span><span style="text-decoration: underline; color: #000000;"> mission and values?</span></strong></em></h3>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">We believe that our project week had a great connection with UWC’s missions and values because the project which we were investigating was hugely involved in <span style="color: #000000;">understanding</span></span><span style="color: #000000;"> of the  culture of Ireland and values that a country possesses. Therefore, we think that this relation could contribute to our knowledge in terms of global understanding, awareness of global and historical problems and possible solutions that could be reached.</span></p>
<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW5.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-336"><img class="wp-image-336 size-large aligncenter" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW5-1024x683.jpg" alt="PW5" width="700" height="467" /></a>

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Feb&#039;16 - Athens, Greece</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/03/09/feb16-athens-greece/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 09 Mar 2016 15:14:45 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=343</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[by Melody Lam and Sophia-Iris Komparki
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #000000;">[spacer height="20px"]To be fairly honest, this wasn’t the most amazing project week ever. I’ve never done one before but there is quite a lot of room for improvement. Even so, there were still a lot of memorable and enjoyable moments.</span></p>

<blockquote>We chose Arsis because it is a non-governmental organization (NGO) that is not only supporting refugees but also specializing in the social support of youth that are in difficulty or even danger.</blockquote>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">We worked with <strong>Arsis</strong>, a Greek organization that provides refuge for asylum seekers while their legal status in Greece is being processed. Apart from providing accommodation, they also work with homeless people in Athens, providing them with food and blankets (i.e. basic necessities). The organization also receives non-monetary donations from the public and reorganizes them to give it to the people in need. These include food, clothes, toys, blankets and toiletries and a lot more.</span></p>
<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/IMG_7178-1.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-392"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-392 size-large" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/IMG_7178-1-1024x768.jpg" alt="IMG_7178 (1)" width="700" height="525" /></a>

&nbsp;
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">We chose Arsis because it is a non-governmental organization (NGO) that is not only supporting refugees but also specializing in the social support of youth that are in difficulty or even danger. Their vision is really inspiring as they strive to create a society with equal opportunities for everyone. Their work has been proven to have a huge impact in the society. They have helped so far thousands of families. This could be achieved thanks to the organization collaborating with a very big number of social entrepreneurs and volunteers.</span></p>

<blockquote>The room was about the size half the floor. It transformed with from a messy junkyard of donations to an organized inventory!</blockquote>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">We did some sort of service with the organization each day. When we emailed the organization, we were told that we would be handing out food and clothing to homeless people and refugees. When we arrived the organization, they turned out to be fairly unorganized. Instead of doing what we were promised, we ended up re-organizing their inventory of donations. To be honest, we were not very satisfied at the start, but I believe this was a very special learning experience. So, basically what we did every day was that we would arrive the organization at 10, re-organize their inventory and leave at 4. We did the same thing for 4 days. I was amazed by how we successfully re-organized the whole inventory/storage room in 4 days! The room was about the size half the floor. It transformed with from a messy junkyard of donations to an organized inventory! WE ARE PROUD OF OURSELVES.</span></p>
<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/IMG_7182.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-393"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-395 size-large" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/IMG_7182-1024x768.jpg" alt="" width="700" height="525" /></a>

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/IMG_7234-e1457967230283.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-396"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-396 size-large" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/IMG_7234-e1457967230283-768x1024.jpg" alt="IMG_7234" width="700" height="933" /></a>

&nbsp;
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #333333;">This day was our second day in the organisation “Al Asam”. We left our apartment that is in the area of Sultan Ahmet at approximately 9 o'clock to go to Karaköy. From that point we had to walk more than one hour. It was really difficult because the city is like a mountain and we do need to climb especially the way we had taken that day. We arrived to the organisation at around 10 and there was a Turkish lesson for the children (3 to 8 years old). We joined the lesson and helped the children with memorizing exercise. After the end of the lesson we had a lot of fun activities with them and this was the most important and enjoying moment of the journey. At 3 o'clock the second group of students came. They were mainly teenagers and with a highest age of 15. The day before we have gone with them near to the sea for their photography lesson. That day they had hip hop dance and singing lesson. The teachers were really professional and they danced very well. We also joined the dance lesson. And we had fun. The day before during the way to the sea they have taught us some Arabic and we taught them our first languages. At the end of the dance lesson was the singing lesson. Each of the teenagers had their own lyrics that they sing to express what they cannot say through music. We also participated to that lesson by doing random freestyle on a bit. At the end of the day we had an exchanges of addresses with them to keep being in touch.</span></p>

<blockquote>The gist of service isn’t just about how directly working with your target group and making their lives better, it’s about being compassionate and understanding.</blockquote>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #000000;">Although this project week had a lot of things we did not anticipate, we still met our project week goals. We successfully organized a project week and cooperated smoothly with the organization! (We thought we were going to miss our flight.) This was an off-campus project week which gained us a lot of insight about the Greek community. Most of the staff were Greeks or spoke Greek. We also stayed with Sophia-Iris’ family and met some of her friends. We talked about how different our home countries were compared to Greece and shared stories during the night. We definitely were able to learn a lot more about ourselves when we are all alone and hands on doing a project without much supervision of elders. Though we were not specifically spreading the UWC vision with target groups directly, we experienced it on another level ourselves. As we were a really international group, we also attracted a lot of attention and shared a lot of our experiences with Sophia’s family and friends. This is in another way spreading the UWC mission and values.</span></p>
&nbsp;

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/IMG_7325-e1457967316543.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-397"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-397 size-large" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/IMG_7325-e1457967316543-768x1024.jpg" alt="IMG_7325" width="700" height="933" /></a>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-weight: 400; color: #000000;">One of the mission and values of UWC is service and compassion. The gist of service isn’t just about how directly working with your target group and making their lives better, it’s about being compassionate and understanding. In this case, we have to understand that this organization needs help with their storage. The organization is not just the middle-man between we and our target group, they are also humans and they also need help.  Our work with the inventory speeds up their process of helping their target group. And I believe if we manage to understand why we are cleaning instead of giving food to the needy, we have illustrated the embraced and lived the true meaning of service.</span></p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Feb&#039;16 - Venice, Italy</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/03/09/feb16-venice-italy/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 09 Mar 2016 15:39:49 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=345</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img class="aligncenter" src="http://ic.pics.livejournal.com/nikkotomascasil/76768806/21673/21673_900.jpg" alt="" width="900" height="596" />

<span style="color: #000000;"><b>RENE RIETMEYER</b></span>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">Just as when he arrives, we welcome him upstanding. With a very humble smile, he waves and sits. “He’s the guy who hates formalities”, as Monica says 5 minutes before the meeting and interview as a tip for the whole panel. The group consists of up to 14 people in addition to the officers of the organization and us, the students. In the meantime, as we try to start up the conversation through warm greetings, unexpectedly, we’re the ones being asked by Rene. The conversation starts off with long introductions of each project week member, out of curiosity and amazement, Rene praises each of us. We’re stunned by his professionalism and dedication to putting his mindset through his works. Rene’s famous for his art form called “Boxes”. Although he’s very well known in the art industry, having traveled to many countries and organised many art exhibits in cooperation with many other artists. During the toughest weeks for work, he keeps himself grounded in his couch as he works with his laptop. “I remember times when I stayed inside my apartment for many days straight, not going out, due to work”. It believe that it’s a tough job, thanks to the easy communication nowadays, it makes it easier to communicate to people all around the world.</span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">We wondered what inspired him as an artist. He recalled his teenage life. He admitted of committing mistakes through his teenage times but he recalled making a “list” in his life for a change. This “list” made him think things through. Upon making this list, he considered knowing what’s bad and what’s good for him. To find out that he wrote “openness, transparency and honesty” on the right side of good things. These were things he remembered saying in front of a mirror as he promised to keep these values with him till he grows old.</span></p>
<span style="color: #000000;">Watch "boxes"  :  </span>

<span style="color: #000000;">Read more:<span style="color: #ff6600;">  <a style="color: #ff6600;" href="http://rimonimartgallery.com/artists/rene-rietmeyer/" target="_self" rel="nofollow">http://rimonimartgallery.com/artists/ren<wbr />e-rietmeyer/</a></span></span>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">Throughout the interview, he recalls his youth and how he started as an artist. He mentioned also about how he started his journey on building the European Cultural Center, formerly called as Global Arts Affairs Foundation.</span></p>
<span style="color: #000000;">Watch video of interview coverage: </span><span style="color: #000000;">edited by Zharina Nikko Tomas Casil, </span><span style="color: #000000;">Music credits and attribution to ModernThemeMusic</span>

&nbsp;

<span style="color: #000000;"><b>[spacer height="20px"]THE ORGANISATION</b></span>

<span style="color: #000000;"><b>How it all started</b></span>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">“I was invited here in Venice as an artist” Rene Rietmeyer remembers his journey. He decided to organise a Big Exhibition in Venice, along with other artists. He then meets more young students in Italy, interested in working with regards to arts and found a way to organise the body of his organization calling it Global Arts Affairs and now called as European Cultural Centre. He said “it’s just the name, but we’re aiming for the same thing”. The organisation brings about talents from designers, architects and artists of diverse cultures from all over the world. Every year, during the month of May, the Grand Biennale is conducted within four big Palazzos in the city of Venice. It’s a very huge event wherein famous and talented artists as well as ambassadors from different countries attend to.</span></p>

<blockquote>
<p style="text-align: center;">The organisation brings about talents from designers, architects and artists of diverse cultures from all over the world.</p>
</blockquote>
<span style="color: #000000;"><b>[spacer height="20px"] CHALLENGE</b></span>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">Bringing artists’ works in the exhibit as diverse as possible and to keep the budget money rolling at the same time. The exhibits in the Palazzo during the Biennale are for free entrance but the artists that would exhibit their works would pay for the allocation of their spots in the huge walls of the Palaces. Also, the four Palazzos are being rented by the organization and money is indeed a very important factor to keep the exhibitions running.</span></p>
<span style="color: #000000;">read more</span> :<span style="color: #ff6600;"> &lt;<a style="color: #ff6600;" href="http://www.globalartaffairs.org/" target="_self" rel="nofollow">http://www.globalartaffairs.org</a>&gt;</span>

<span style="color: #000000;"><b>[spacer height="20px"] UPCOMING BIENALLE IN VENICE ITALY</b></span>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">This year’s theme would be focused on architecture, wherein famous architects, artists and designers all over the world gather together and attend the Grand Venice Architecture Biennale 2016. It will take place in Palazzo Bembo and Palazzo Mora.</span></p>
<span style="color: #000000;">read more :</span>
<span style="color: #ff6600;">&lt;<a style="color: #ff6600;" href="http://www.globalartaffairs.org/index.php?page=48&amp;lang=jp" target="_self" rel="nofollow">http://www.globalartaffairs.org/index.ph<wbr />p?page=48&amp;lang=jp</a>&gt;</span>

<span style="color: #000000;"><b>[spacer height="20px"] UWC AND ECC on bond</b></span>
<blockquote>We’re hopeful that this would strengthen rapport between the organization and the United World College Maastricht for future educational opportunities.</blockquote>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">Initially, I wasn’t expecting that this whole project week opportunity would come along. I wasn’t expecting a “yes” from the global arts affairs organization for my proposal, but they humbly accepted all my proposals and plans. They’ve cooperated with us throughout the whole process. We’re very grateful to the European Cultural Centre, to Sir Rene Rietmeyer, to Gratzia, Marco, Monica and to all the officers and employees. We’re hopeful that this would strengthen rapport between the organization and the United World College Maastricht for future educational opportunities.</span>
<span style="color: #000000;"><img class="aligncenter" title="" src="http://ic.pics.livejournal.com/nikkotomascasil/76768806/21154/21154_900.jpg" alt="" /></span>
<span style="color: #000000;"><img class="alignnone" title="" src="http://ic.pics.livejournal.com/nikkotomascasil/76768806/21290/21290_900.jpg" alt="" /></span></p>
<span style="color: #000000;"><b>[spacer height="20px"] THE PHILIPPINE PAVILION</b></span>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">I was fortunate enough to see the accomplishments of fellow Filipino artists even abroad. I am proud of my country having established the nation’s arts, cultures and traditions in Venice. With the initiative of Senator Loren Legarda and the Republic of the Philippines. I have received positive stories from the Global Arts Affairs Organisation, having been working with them for the Biennale.</span></p>
<span style="color: #000000;"><img class="alignnone" title="" src="http://ic.pics.livejournal.com/nikkotomascasil/76768806/18835/18835_900.jpg" alt="" /></span>

<span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">Taken by United World College Maastricht Project Week Group Venice</span>

<span style="color: #000000;"><b>[spacer height="20px"]VENICE</b></span>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">Out of thousands of reasons why Venice is visited by a million of tourists everyday. We, as a Project Week Group, were able to witness at least hundreds of these reasons for three days. The mini outskirts of the city that could take you to the same spot after an hour of walk without noticing. Those lovely birds flying and eventually lands near you. Though sometimes, it might be a bit of a ruckus when you stay still at the same place for a minute or so, cause you never know, birds might pee on you.</span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">The blue green water seemingly perfect, making you realise that you’re in an city-island</span>.<span style="color: #000000;"> This extraordinary concept of where you’re standing makes you feel like floating. The streets and tall palaces resembling the european old times. The beautiful glass bridge in the grand canal that takes your breath away. The famous Piazza Rialto Bridge as well as the main square where most tourists go to. The real taste of Venetian Pizza and the smell of food on the streets keeping you scented all throughout the way. All these and many other faces of Venice keep it beautiful in many eyes of tourists and specially to people who’ve lived their whole lives in the city.</span></p>
<span style="color: #000000;"><b>watch video: </b></span><span style="color: #000000;">video by Zharina Nikko Casil</span>

<span style="color: #000000;"><b>[spacer height="20px"]INTERVIEW WITH A REAL VENETIAN</b></span>
<blockquote>“I love the city and this is why I work here and take care of it”</blockquote>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">Marco Barbaro</span> ,<span style="color: #000000;"><span style="color: #ff6600;"> &lt;<a style="color: #ff6600;" href="http://www.europeanculturalcentre.eu/index.php?page=10&amp;lang=en" target="_self" rel="nofollow">http://www.europeanculturalcentre.eu/ind<wbr />ex.php?page=10&amp;lang=en</a>&gt;</span>  who’s spent his life in the city as his home, where he grew up and currently works. “I love the city and this is why I work here and take care of it”, he says within a sincere and formal gesture.  When asked about his most favourite part of Venice, he said “many of them”.But he remembered his childhood then answered Fondamenta della Misericordia. “It’s not a very touristy place but it is where real Venetians live”.  With this reaction, we raised a question that’s quite personal. Having the idea that Venice is actually droning, he was quite moved. “In around 50 years, water is coming up, it’s reality” he says with in a realistic tone.  read more</span> :<span style="color: #000000;">  <span style="color: #ff6600;">&lt;<a style="color: #ff6600;" href="http://www.lifeinitaly.com/tourism/veneto/sinking-venice.asp" target="_self" rel="nofollow">http://www.lifeinitaly.com/tourism/venet<wbr />o/sinking-venice.asp</a>&gt;</span></span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">He commented also on the numbers of tourists coming to Venice City everyday. A million of tourists come to visit the city everyday, the number is way more than those who live in the city itself. It’s also quite alarming that “capitalism” runs within the city and the government, he said. We also asked him about his hopes for the betterment of the city in his point of view as a real Venetian.  “We need people who come here to respect the city because it’s a very historical yet fragile city, it’s hard to take care of it”, he says.</span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">He recalled the city during his childhood, “living within the city was never as expensive as it is now”. When we asked him, “what would you do if you’re given the chance to change things the way they are now?”. “I’d like to protect my fellow Venetians from economical strive and difficulty”, he replied.  He stressed the fact that the people living in the city don’t have much privilege as citizens and that they don’t usually have much power to decide on things.</span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">However, Marco Barbaro, as a real Venetian, remain hopeful for the betterment of the citizen’s state with regards to economy.  As a member of the European Cultural Center, he mentioned that he wants to contribute his talents through keeping art and architecture of Venice. He loved the fact that the city had no cars and that it’s such a tricky place.</span></p>
<span style="color: #000000;"><b>[spacer height="20px"]UWC MAASTRICHT ON MEETING THE EUROPEAN CULTURAL CENTRE ORGANIZATION AND THE FOUNDER, RENE RIETMEYER</b></span>

&nbsp;

<span style="color: #000000;">PROJECT WEEK IN VENICE ITALY</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">AIMS AND GOALS</span>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">We, the project week group of UWC Maastricht aim to establish a connection between the European Cultural Centre and the school through educational opportunities. In cooperation with the organization, we were able to conduct the three day project which aimed to introduce United World College Maastricht to the city through flashmob. Also, establishing the connection between the school has been accomplished through the successful interview with Rene Rietmeyer also with the members and officers of the ECC. We’ve briefly discussed about future plans on the possibility of a “summer-exchange student" opportunity for dedicated students for May break during the grand exhibition of the Biennale. Both sides are hopeful for this future project. We also made documentaries about Venice as a city considering interviews from tourists and a Venetian, Marco. All videos and articles we made are intended for the ECC and UWCM community.</span></p>
<span style="color: #000000;"><img class="aligncenter" title="" src="http://ic.pics.livejournal.com/nikkotomascasil/76768806/19359/19359_900.jpg" alt="" /></span>
<span style="color: #000000;">Photo taken by Ghita Benhayoune</span>

&nbsp;

<span style="color: #000000;"><b>[spacer height="20px"]OUR JOURNEY</b></span>

&nbsp;

<span style="color: #000000;">video edit by Zharina Nikko</span>
<span style="color: #000000;"><img title="" src="http://ic.pics.livejournal.com/nikkotomascasil/76768806/20742/20742_900.jpg" alt="" /></span>

<span style="color: #000000;"><b>by Gisela Hoxha (Albania)</b></span>

<span style="color: #000000;">Tuesday:</span>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">Its Tuesday early morning 3 am and we were walking nervously back and forth the airport. Initially there were 10 people meant to be in our PW group but we were only 9. We had no clue where the 10th person was. She was supposed to have arrived in the airport from Paris 2 hours before and we had no information about what happened to her and why she was late. There was no wifi and no one of us had credit on the phone. So we payed for internet connection and tried to connect with her, but failed. Then tried to connect with people who might know but no one was giving us any relevant information. Then when the gate was starting to open we decided to call the school and we were seriously considering to call the police. But she suddenly appeared and everyone was relieved, happy and ready to go. It seemed like a challenge awaited for us since the very beginning. After leaving the airport, we changed from subway to bus and then walking. Everyone was tired but excited to arrive in Venice. We arrived at the camping site at around 8. Even though we were tired and the centre of the city was quite far from the camping site we decided to go to the city. The carnival was over a bit before than the predicted because of the rainy weather but you could see the traces of carnival celebration. People wearing masks and costumes, music, vendors selling masks, costumes, decorations along the streets. Since the first moment we stepped in Venice city centre we were all fascinated with the beauty of the view.</span></p>
<span style="color: #000000;">Wednesday:</span>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">We woke up and took the bus to Venice. We were about to visit the European Culture Centre which is one of the most important venues for the Venice Biennale, a very important event in the art world. Walking along the narrow cobbled streets and the many , unique bridges we arrived at the palazzo Mora. They showed us around the palace, which was going under a huge transformation to prepare if for the biennale coming up in May. Then we moved to another palace nearby to have the interview with Mr. Rene.  Since the first introduction with him we understood that he was a man without complex and very flexible. He welcomed us in Venice and asked us to introduce ourselves. He had travelled so much and he had so many stories with people that he told us a story connected to each of our countries. And he talked about the importance of living in an international and diverse environment. We asked him about what inspired him to become an artist. And his answer was sharp and clear, he was looking for a medium to communicate with people in a larger scale. We talked about a variety of issues like gender equality, what to him meant making a difference in life. He is a truly avant garde and remarkable individual and he had some very interesting opinions from which I learned a lot.  Afterwards they gave us a tour around all the palaces and they showed us the office from which all the logistics and organizing was done. They explained us the process of preparing everything for the biennale. Everything from</span></p>
<span style="color: #000000;">Thursday:</span>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">The big day for which we had practiced a lot beforehand was about to come. We went there to set up everything the music and to do the final preparations. All the girls were nervous but excited. We were about to start the flash mob in Venice. The first dance was like a warm up and to attract people to come. Then more and more people were coming to watch us. They were taking videos and pictures and some of them even joined the dance. I felt really happy that many were asking about where we came from and about our school and they seemed impressed from what we told them about UWC. Since in Venice there are tourists from all around the world, there happened to be an Indian just-married couple, who got very excited when we were dancing a Bollywood song. The lady joined us and her husband was really happy to see her dancing with us and I felt honored that we became part of their honeymoon memories.</span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">After the flash mob we went to take an interview with one of the engineers, a native Venetian, working in the palazzo. We asked him about his connection with Venice and how he viewed the change happening to the city. I was amazed by the fact that everyday more and more Venetians were leaving the city to leave somewhere else because of the high prices and taxes. And the last activity of the day was visiting the St. Peter’s square, one of the main touristic spots of Venice. The view was breathtaking and the cultural heritage priceless. We interviewed many tourists about their impression of Venice and what they liked best.</span></p>
<span style="color: #000000;"><b>[spacer height="20px"]UWCM Flash mob </b></span>

<span style="color: #ff6600;"><a style="color: #ff6600;" href="https://www.facebook.com/groups/475240265997608">https://www.facebook.com/groups/475240265997608</a></span>
<span style="color: #000000;">due to copyright issues of song used in the flash mob, video was posted on facebook instead of YouTube. Therefore, please login to your account to access the video of the fla</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">Friday:</span>

<span style="color: #333333;">On Friday we went to say goodbye to everyone from the organization and went to see Rene once more for the last time. Again we had a very nice conversation with him. Even though we would have loved to stay longer it was about time we left. The journey back to Maastricht was long, tiring and painful, however it didn’t make our wonderful experience in Venice less valuable.   </span>

<span style="color: #000000;"><img title="" src="http://ic.pics.livejournal.com/nikkotomascasil/76768806/20720/20720_900.jpg" alt="" /></span>

<span style="color: #000000;"><b>[spacer height="20px"]REFLECTION by Tatevik Ghumashyan (Armenia)</b></span>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">I am Tatevik Ghumashyan ,from Armenia .I was  one of the lucky people ,who was a part of a project week in Venice .The aim of the project was exploration of the art in Venice and show it through the documentary film. We spent there four  days, and let me notice that those days were the most happiest days in my life .Adventurous  trip full of love and  harmony .I still can’t believe ,that we made it .I am very grateful to Zharina Nikko Casil, who united us around one idea .</span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">We had a cooperation with European cultural center ,in order to fully explore the art life in Venice . Due to different interviews with the local population we explored not only good but also bad sides of life in Venice .People complained about the government, and bad policy ruled by them.</span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">We had interviewed different tourists ,in order to understand their inspiration to traveling in Venice. Answers were multiple ,but they all felt, like they appeared in a real miracle .</span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">The last day in Venice was unforgettable .We prepared a flash mob, made by different dances, which we learnt from our friends in UWC Maastricht. I was proud to show the national dances of my friends, and for a moment I felt like a world citizen .I am very proud, that we could make such an amazing project, which will stay in our hearts forever .Special thanks to our lovely school ,to UWC for providing us this unique opportunity to explore the wonderful  world around us .</span></p>
<span style="color: #000000;"><img title="" src="http://ic.pics.livejournal.com/nikkotomascasil/76768806/19757/19757_900.jpg" alt="" /></span>

<span style="color: #000000;"><b>[spacer height="20px"]REFLECTION by Ghita Benhayoune (France and Morocco)</b></span>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">This Project Week was my most unexpected and eye-opening experience so far.  I was never very fund of arts and struggled a lot to enjoy it. Working with an art gallery was the first challenge: I had to overcome all the preconceived ideas I had of what I believed art to be and what being an artist meant. When we first met the team of the Global Arts Affair Foundation, I was amazed by their professionalism, passion and dedication. Their relationship was beyond anything I had ever seen before: they interacted like a family, all working together towards the bigger purpose that is their foundation. But the most significant moment of the project week was our meeting with the founder, René. His vision of art was eye opening for me: he saw his foundation as a way to support artists all over the world to convey their message, but also for him to spread his, which was the way he lived. He taught us about the value of honesty and love and how he incorporated it into the way his foundation works. He went to the point that he negotiated a business deal right in front of us! It was amazing to see how business worked in front of our eyes and how respectful he was of his values and considerate of other people with him. René inspired us and offered us a unique opportunity to investigate ourselves further, to thrive for growth during the summer. The city itself reflected René's way of living: full of life, the Carnival and its preparations showed us the best of Venezian artisanat and the value the locals gave it. This experience, truly changed me.</span></p>
<span style="color: #000000;"><img class="aligncenter" title="" src="http://ic.pics.livejournal.com/nikkotomascasil/76768806/22312/22312_900.jpg" alt="" /></span>

<span style="color: #000000;"><b>[spacer height="20px"]REFLECTION by Mishal Khan  (Pakistan)</b></span>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">I have never eaten as much cheese as I did in those 5 days.</span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">This project week was a great experience as we got to meet some great people like Rene. Sharing his life story with us and some acts and habits he values the most in life such as honesty. He gave us a insight to how his business works by making a business right in front of us. At that point I actually felt myself struggling with choosing sides. Should I support the client who is trying to get a place at the exhibition, showcasing their artwork, with having to pay as less as possible? Or should I favour Rene, “the boss” who is trying to get as much money out of the client’s pocket to fund his exhibition and cover all the costs? Both sides seeking their profit. It was another moment when I saw Game theory in action.</span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">However this was not it. We were offered internships, in case we wanted to join, over the summer when their final architectural exhibition about space, time and existence will take place. Having seen the working environment of the Palazzos, some of our team members are already planning to join.</span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">The flash mob was one of the things that I had never done before. It made me step out of my comfort zone. Talking to the locals sketched a different picture of venice from what we were seeing.</span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">As a whole, this project week was a good opportunity for team building. Trying to sort out and minimize the budget, buying the cheapest food in supermarkets, deciding who does what, everything added up to making these five days memorable.</span></p>
<span style="color: #000000;"><img title="" src="http://ic.pics.livejournal.com/nikkotomascasil/76768806/20216/20216_900.jpg" alt="" /></span>

<span style="color: #000000;"><b>[spacer height="20px"]Reflection by Matilda Mayamiko (Malawi)</b></span>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">The project week trip to Venice was such an amazing experience. I learnt that tolerance of cultural differences and values is one of the most important things when working as a group. Everyone in the group was willing to tolerate and work with the differences among us. We worked together as a group in everything, we divided the tasks among ourselves accordingly and it was much more easier to get through the whole week. I learnt that unity really matters and it one of the most important ways to move forward. Meeting Rhene and hearing his views about the world arts and cultures made me think about the issue of global unification even more. In his interview he said " The beauty lies in the differences but it does not mean that we should be blind to the differences". this made me think about our UWC community, how we are all different, from all over the world yet beautiful together working towards one common goal. in conclusion the project week experience was amazing! the team was wonderful and i had so much fun.</span></p>
<span style="color: #000000;"><img title="" src="http://ic.pics.livejournal.com/nikkotomascasil/76768806/19638/19638_900.jpg" alt="" /></span>

<span style="color: #000000;"><b>[spacer height="20px"]Reflection by Joelle Powe (Jamaica)</b></span>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">My project week to Italy was a coming of age experience that was full of adventure, laughter, cultural exchange and delicious international cuisine. Our project week team, was completely random, with people from a really diverse geographical background. I was the only person from the Western hemisphere, being from the Caribbean. Being in an intimate setting such as a hostel and having the struggle of figuring out how to pay for transport and food daily definitely brought us closer together as a group. We all grew in independence and improvisation skills. In the beginning, I was picky about how we spend our food money, but near the end, I learned how to compromise and was grateful for whatever was provided.</span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">In the sunny afternoons in the city of Venice, we had many conversations and interviews with local Italians and tourists, engrossing ourselves in the world around us. I enjoyed the smells of cigarettes, pizza, coffee and salt water. In the nights, the girls and I exchanged stories and reflected on our time visiting the palazzo.We also did dances from our respective countries in a flash mob outside of the palazzo. IN this way, we demonstrated the UWC phenomenon, the culture of many  diverse cultures in harmony.</span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">The Venice project week was a phenomenal experience for me! I have made new friends, discovered a new network of art collectors in Venice and made an impact in Venice the city by showing them the UWC values.</span></p>

<h1 dir="ltr"><span style="color: #000000;"><img title="" src="http://ic.pics.livejournal.com/nikkotomascasil/76768806/21909/21909_900.jpg" alt="" /></span></h1>
<h1 dir="ltr"><span style="color: #000000;">[spacer height="20px"]Between the reality and a dream</span></h1>
<p dir="ltr"><span style="color: #000000;"><b>by Seda Bagiryan (Armenia)</b></span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">Some memories never fade away,</span></p>
<p dir="ltr" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">Some of them seem to be illusion or a dream that tastes too sweet and feels too warm to be true, but Venice was real and I was part of the dream.</span></p>
<p dir="ltr" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">A few years ago hardly would I imagine having a chance to be in the City of the Masks, but a while ago I walked on Rialto bridge with 9 other beautiful ladies that shared my excitement and admiration for Venice.</span></p>
<p dir="ltr" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">It was a great time of getting the taste of Venice through the exploration of arts and cultures in the European Culture Center. The discovery of new types of art works left me thinking and reflecting upon my perception of arts and cultures. Some pieces of art also brought me out of my comfort zone. For example, some sexual nude art pictures made me feel confused questioning whether any lines have been crossed in the creation of these art pieces. Indeed the lines vary in different cultures and another question is whether they should exist at all; however, it was an interesting and in way eye-opening experience to get to see alternative art works and to question my perception of the beauty of art.</span></p>
<p dir="ltr" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">Venice itself is a big piece of art which has a strong character that envelopes its visitors.  It held me very strongly and it seemed that not much else mattered in life other than Venice and my thoughts.  If you saw Harry Potter you might remember Dementors that steal people’s good memories, if their opposite characters existed they would originate from Venice - the city brought out all the warm and sweet memories that I have ever had, made me appreciate small thing that I usually take for granted, things that allow my existence - the sun, the air, the sounds I hear, people and Yourself with a greater hope and satisfaction for the moment.</span></p>
<span style="color: #000000;"><img class="aligncenter" title="" src="http://ic.pics.livejournal.com/nikkotomascasil/76768806/22188/22188_900.jpg" alt="" /><span style="color: #ff6600;">Howdy, olaya</span></span>
<p dir="ltr"><span style="color: #000000;"><b><span style="font-family: Arial;">[spacer height="20px"]REFLECTION by Maria Abdelhadi (Palestine)</span></b></span></p>
<p dir="ltr" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">Our project week was in Venice. We interviewed an artist and we learned from him, we also visited his galleries. That made learned so many things, i saw different sides of everything, so the experience for the personal side was successful more than i expected. But also, we brought here ideas for the artist students, and we took UWC’s values there.</span></p>
<p dir="ltr" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">I think, the most important thing that we achieved was the relationship between our school and the galleries, therefore, many successful things can be achieved. Experiences, ideas, and art works can be shared with the galleries in Venice.</span></p>
<span style="color: #000000;"><img class="aligncenter" title="" src="http://ic.pics.livejournal.com/nikkotomascasil/76768806/22771/22771_900.jpg" alt="" /></span>
<span style="color: #000000;"><b>ZHARINA NIKKO'S REFLECTION</b></span>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">This is my first time organizing a huge project so far.</span>
<span style="color: #000000;"> Initially, my broad idea for planning a project week was something with regards to my interest, it's arts specifically--- music. But finding organizations offering opportunities for students isn't that probable.</span>
<span style="color: #000000;"> I rethought of everything and I decided to consider a project that would significantly help an organization.</span>
<span style="color: #000000;"> After emailing many organizations and proposing ideas, I was lucky enough to have several response from organizations. One of them was the response from Rene Rietmeyer, a very famous dutch artist who established European Cultural Centre, formerly known as Global Arts Affairs. I was very surpised with having the agreement from Rene. Within weeks after the notice, I got in contact with Grazia, the head of the Palazzos where we set our project. I am very grateful for the full cooperation of the ECC.</span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">"We see this as an educational opportunity between the United World College Maastricht and European Cultural Centre", Rene once sent via email. I was excited for the journey.</span>
<span style="color: #000000;"> I mean, it's a challenge. We're quite a large group. Yes, the road wasn't as easy as expected, but along the way, I found ease and relief within the company of nine other gorgeous and loving girls. I'm proud that we made it through better and worse situations during the 4-day project. We accomplished things we needed to and we extended UWC mission and values. The experience of eating bread and cheese most of meals for four days. Those times when we needed to wait for hours on airports and bust stations, sitting together, sleeping next to each other's arms, those warmth felt during late night chats. The times when we needed to cook our food, staying on one roof together, waking up sleepy ladies in the morning. Those mere natural 'arguing' moments and those sudden laughters, those fulfilling smiles and those dancing and singing moments. All these, I miss.</span>
<span style="color: #000000;"> I'm happy reading the reflections of my group mates for the PW. It feels satisfying being able to share a worthwhile experience with the girls.</span></p>
<span style="color: #000000;">Much love, Nikko</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">links provided for viewing videos:</span>
<span style="color: #ff6600;"><i>&lt;</i><i><u><a style="color: #ff6600;" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9nf_Ao82X_8&amp;feature=youtu.be" target="_self" rel="nofollow">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9nf_Ao8<wbr />2X_8&amp;feature=youtu.be</a></u>&gt;</i></span>

<span style="color: #ff6600;"><i><u>&lt;<a style="color: #ff6600;" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r79rKyQWrhI" target="_self" rel="nofollow">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r79rKy<wbr />QWrhI</a>&gt;</u></i></span>

<span style="color: #ff6600;"><i><u>&lt;<a style="color: #ff6600;" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vGTqQAp_Q4U" target="_self" rel="nofollow">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vGTqQA<wbr />p_Q4U</a>&gt;</u></i></span>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #ff6600;"><u><i><b>&lt;</b><a style="color: #ff6600;" href="https://www.facebook.com/groups/475240265997608/" target="_self" rel="nofollow">https://www.facebook.com/groups/4752402<wbr />65997608/</a>&gt;</i></u></span>

		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_oembed_time_a13265e42c10e5969f09e3222dd9307d]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1457942699]]></wp:meta_value>
