			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_panels_data_preview]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:3:{s:7:"widgets";a:1:{i:0;a:6:{s:5:"title";s:0:"";s:4:"text";s:37847:"<p><img class="aligncenter" src="http://ic.pics.livejournal.com/nikkotomascasil/76768806/21673/21673_900.jpg" alt="" width="900" height="596" /></p><p><span style="color: #000000;"><b>RENE RIETMEYER</b></span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">Just as when he arrives, we welcome him upstanding. With a very humble smile, he waves and sits. “He’s the guy who hates formalities”, as Monica says 5 minutes before the meeting and interview as a tip for the whole panel. The group consists of up to 14 people in addition to the officers of the organization and us, the students. In the meantime, as we try to start up the conversation through warm greetings, unexpectedly, we’re the ones being asked by Rene. The conversation starts off with long introductions of each project week member, out of curiosity and amazement, Rene praises each of us. We’re stunned by his professionalism and dedication to putting his mindset through his works. Rene’s famous for his art form called “Boxes”. Although he’s very well known in the art industry, having traveled to many countries and organised many art exhibits in cooperation with many other artists. During the toughest weeks for work, he keeps himself grounded in his couch as he works with his laptop. “I remember times when I stayed inside my apartment for many days straight, not going out, due to work”. It believe that it’s a tough job, thanks to the easy communication nowadays, it makes it easier to communicate to people all around the world.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">We wondered what inspired him as an artist. He recalled his teenage life. He admitted of committing mistakes through his teenage times but he recalled making a “list” in his life for a change. This “list” made him think things through. Upon making this list, he considered knowing what’s bad and what’s good for him. To find out that he wrote “openness, transparency and honesty” on the right side of good things. These were things he remembered saying in front of a mirror as he promised to keep these values with him till he grows old.</span></p><p><span style="color: #000000;">Watch "boxes"  :  </span></p><p>[embed]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iePLR5QBxUU[/embed]</p><p><span style="color: #000000;">Read more:  <a style="color: #000000;" href="http://rimonimartgallery.com/artists/rene-rietmeyer/" target="_self" rel="nofollow">http://rimonimartgallery.com/artists/ren<wbr></wbr>e-rietmeyer/</a></span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">Throughout the interview, he recalls his youth and how he started as an artist. He mentioned also about how he started his journey on building the European Cultural Center, formerly called as Global Arts Affairs Foundation.</span></p><p><span style="color: #000000;">Watch video of interview coverage:</span></p><p>[embed]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9nf_Ao82X_8&feature=youtu.be[/embed]</p><p><span style="color: #000000;">edited by Zharina Nikko Tomas Casil</span><br /> <span style="color: #000000;">Music credits and attribution to ModernThemeMusic</span></p><p> </p><p><span style="color: #000000;"><b>THE ORGANISATION</b></span></p><p><br /> <span style="color: #000000;"><b>How it all started</b></span></p><blockquote><p>The organisation brings about talents from designers, architects and artists of diverse cultures from all over the world.</p></blockquote><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">“I was invited here in Venice as an artist” Rene Rietmeyer remembers his journey. He decided to organise a Big Exhibition in Venice, along with other artists. He then meets more young students in Italy, interested in working with regards to arts and found a way to organise the body of his organization calling it Global Arts Affairs and now called as European Cultural Centre. He said “it’s just the name, but we’re aiming for the same thing”. The organisation brings about talents from designers, architects and artists of diverse cultures from all over the world. Every year, during the month of May, the Grand Biennale is conducted within four big Palazzos in the city of Venice. It’s a very huge event wherein famous and talented artists as well as ambassadors from different countries attend to.</span></p><p><span style="color: #000000;"><b>CHALLENGE</b></span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">Bringing artists’ works in the exhibit as diverse as possible and to keep the budget money rolling at the same time. The exhibits in the Palazzo during the Biennale are for free entrance but the artists that would exhibit their works would pay for the allocation of their spots in the huge walls of the Palaces. Also, the four Palazzos are being rented by the organization and money is indeed a very important factor to keep the exhibitions running.</span></p><p><span style="color: #000000;">read more</span> :<span style="color: #ff6600;"> &lt;<a style="color: #ff6600;" href="http://www.globalartaffairs.org/" target="_self" rel="nofollow">http://www.globalartaffairs.org</a>&gt;</span></p><p><span style="color: #000000;"><b>UPCOMING BIENALLE IN VENICE ITALY</b></span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">This year’s theme would be focused on architecture, wherein famous architects, artists and designers all over the world gather together and attend the Grand Venice Architecture Biennale 2016. It will take place in Palazzo Bembo and Palazzo Mora.</span></p><p><span style="color: #000000;">read more :</span><br /> <span style="color: #ff6600;">&lt;<a style="color: #ff6600;" href="http://www.globalartaffairs.org/index.php?page=48&amp;lang=jp" target="_self" rel="nofollow">http://www.globalartaffairs.org/index.ph<wbr></wbr>p?page=48&amp;lang=jp</a>&gt;</span></p><p><span style="color: #000000;"><b>UWC AND ECC on bond</b></span></p><blockquote><p>We’re hopeful that this would strengthen rapport between the organization and the United World College Maastricht for future educational opportunities.</p></blockquote><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">Initially, I wasn’t expecting that this whole project week opportunity would come along. I wasn’t expecting a “yes” from the global arts affairs organization for my proposal, but they humbly accepted all my proposals and plans. They’ve cooperated with us throughout the whole process. We’re very grateful to the European Cultural Centre, to Sir Rene Rietmeyer, to Gratzia, Marco, Monica and to all the officers and employees. We’re hopeful that this would strengthen rapport between the organization and the United World College Maastricht for future educational opportunities.</span><br /> <span style="color: #000000;"><img class="aligncenter" title="" src="http://ic.pics.livejournal.com/nikkotomascasil/76768806/21154/21154_900.jpg" alt="" /></span><br /> <span style="color: #000000;"><img class="alignnone" title="" src="http://ic.pics.livejournal.com/nikkotomascasil/76768806/21290/21290_900.jpg" alt="" /></span></p><p><span style="color: #000000;"><b>THE PHILIPPINE PAVILION</b></span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">I was fortunate enough to see the accomplishments of fellow Filipino artists even abroad. I am proud of my country having established the nation’s arts, cultures and traditions in Venice. With the initiative of Senator Loren Legarda and the Republic of the Philippines. I have received positive stories from the Global Arts Affairs Organisation, having been working with them for the Biennale.</span></p><p>[embed]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DzuUFXD03g0&feature=youtu.be[/embed]</p><p><span style="color: #000000;"><img class="alignnone" title="" src="http://ic.pics.livejournal.com/nikkotomascasil/76768806/18835/18835_900.jpg" alt="" /></span></p><p><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">Taken by United World College Maastricht Project Week Group Venice</span></p><p><span style="color: #000000;"><b>VENICE</b></span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">Out of thousands of reasons why Venice is visited by a million of tourists everyday. We, as a Project Week Group, were able to witness at least hundreds of these reasons for three days. The mini outskirts of the city that could take you to the same spot after an hour of walk without noticing. Those lovely birds flying and eventually lands near you. Though sometimes, it might be a bit of a ruckus when you stay still at the same place for a minute or so, cause you never know, birds might pee on you.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">The blue green water seemingly perfect, making you realise that you’re in an city-island</span>.<span style="color: #000000;"> This extraordinary concept of where you’re standing makes you feel like floating. The streets and tall palaces resembling the european old times. The beautiful glass bridge in the grand canal that takes your breath away. The famous Piazza Rialto Bridge as well as the main square where most tourists go to. The real taste of Venetian Pizza and the smell of food on the streets keeping you scented all throughout the way. All these and many other faces of Venice keep it beautiful in many eyes of tourists and specially to people who’ve lived their whole lives in the city.</span></p><p><span style="color: #000000;"><b>watch video:</b></span><br /> <span style="color: #000000;">   </span></p><p>[embed]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r79rKyQWrhI[/embed]</p><p><br /> <span style="color: #000000;">video by Zharina Nikko Casil</span></p><p><span style="color: #000000;"><b>INTERVIEW WITH A REAL VENETIAN</b></span></p><blockquote><p>“I love the city and this is why I work here and take care of it”</p></blockquote><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">Marco Barbaro</span> ,<span style="color: #000000;"><span style="color: #ff6600;"> &lt;<a style="color: #ff6600;" href="http://www.europeanculturalcentre.eu/index.php?page=10&amp;lang=en" target="_self" rel="nofollow">http://www.europeanculturalcentre.eu/ind<wbr></wbr>ex.php?page=10&amp;lang=en</a>&gt;</span>  who’s spent his life in the city as his home, where he grew up and currently works. “I love the city and this is why I work here and take care of it”, he says within a sincere and formal gesture.  When asked about his most favourite part of Venice, he said “many of them”.But he remembered his childhood then answered Fondamenta della Misericordia. “It’s not a very touristy place but it is where real Venetians live”.  With this reaction, we raised a question that’s quite personal. Having the idea that Venice is actually droning, he was quite moved. “In around 50 years, water is coming up, it’s reality” he says with in a realistic tone.  read more</span> :<span style="color: #000000;">  <span style="color: #ff6600;">&lt;<a style="color: #ff6600;" href="http://www.lifeinitaly.com/tourism/veneto/sinking-venice.asp" target="_self" rel="nofollow">http://www.lifeinitaly.com/tourism/venet<wbr></wbr>o/sinking-venice.asp</a>&gt;</span></span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">He commented also on the numbers of tourists coming to Venice City everyday. A million of tourists come to visit the city everyday, the number is way more than those who live in the city itself. It’s also quite alarming that “capitalism” runs within the city and the government, he said. We also asked him about his hopes for the betterment of the city in his point of view as a real Venetian.  “We need people who come here to respect the city because it’s a very historical yet fragile city, it’s hard to take care of it”, he says.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">He recalled the city during his childhood, “living within the city was never as expensive as it is now”. When we asked him, “what would you do if you’re given the chance to change things the way they are now?”. “I’d like to protect my fellow Venetians from economical strive and difficulty”, he replied.  He stressed the fact that the people living in the city don’t have much privilege as citizens and that they don’t usually have much power to decide on things.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">However, Marco Barbaro, as a real Venetian, remain hopeful for the betterment of the citizen’s state with regards to economy.  As a member of the European Cultural Center, he mentioned that he wants to contribute his talents through keeping art and architecture of Venice. He loved the fact that the city had no cars and that it’s such a tricky place.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"> </p><p><span style="color: #000000;"><b>UWC MAASTRICHT ON MEETING THE EUROPEAN CULTURAL CENTRE ORGANIZATION AND THE FOUNDER, RENE RIETMEYER</b></span></p><p> </p><p><span style="color: #000000;">PROJECT WEEK IN VENICE ITALY</span></p><p><span style="color: #000000;">AIMS AND GOALS</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">We, the project week group of UWC Maastricht aim to establish a connection between the European Cultural Centre and the school through educational opportunities. In cooperation with the organization, we were able to conduct the three day project which aimed to introduce United World College Maastricht to the city through flashmob. Also, establishing the connection between the school has been accomplished through the successful interview with Rene Rietmeyer also with the members and officers of the ECC. We’ve briefly discussed about future plans on the possibility of a “summer-exchange student" opportunity for dedicated students for May break during the grand exhibition of the Biennale. Both sides are hopeful for this future project. We also made documentaries about Venice as a city considering interviews from tourists and a Venetian, Marco. All videos and articles we made are intended for the ECC and UWCM community.</span></p><p><span style="color: #000000;"><img class="aligncenter" title="" src="http://ic.pics.livejournal.com/nikkotomascasil/76768806/19359/19359_900.jpg" alt="" /></span><br /> <span style="color: #000000;">Photo taken by Ghita Benhayoune</span></p><p> </p><p><span style="color: #000000;"><b>OUR JOURNEY</b></span></p><p> </p><p>[embed]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vGTqQAp_Q4U[/embed]</p><p><span style="color: #000000;">video edit by Zharina Nikko</span><br /> <span style="color: #000000;"><img title="" src="http://ic.pics.livejournal.com/nikkotomascasil/76768806/20742/20742_900.jpg" alt="" /></span></p><p><span style="color: #000000;"><b>by Gisela Hoxha (Albania)</b></span></p><p><span style="color: #000000;">Tuesday:</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">Its Tuesday early morning 3 am and we were walking nervously back and forth the airport. Initially there were 10 people meant to be in our PW group but we were only 9. We had no clue where the 10th person was. She was supposed to have arrived in the airport from Paris 2 hours before and we had no information about what happened to her and why she was late. There was no wifi and no one of us had credit on the phone. So we payed for internet connection and tried to connect with her, but failed. Then tried to connect with people who might know but no one was giving us any relevant information. Then when the gate was starting to open we decided to call the school and we were seriously considering to call the police. But she suddenly appeared and everyone was relieved, happy and ready to go. It seemed like a challenge awaited for us since the very beginning. After leaving the airport, we changed from subway to bus and then walking. Everyone was tired but excited to arrive in Venice. We arrived at the camping site at around 8. Even though we were tired and the centre of the city was quite far from the camping site we decided to go to the city. The carnival was over a bit before than the predicted because of the rainy weather but you could see the traces of carnival celebration. People wearing masks and costumes, music, vendors selling masks, costumes, decorations along the streets. Since the first moment we stepped in Venice city centre we were all fascinated with the beauty of the view.</span></p><p><span style="color: #000000;">Wednesday:</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">We woke up and took the bus to Venice. We were about to visit the European Culture Centre which is one of the most important venues for the Venice Biennale, a very important event in the art world. Walking along the narrow cobbled streets and the many , unique bridges we arrived at the palazzo Mora. They showed us around the palace, which was going under a huge transformation to prepare if for the biennale coming up in May. Then we moved to another palace nearby to have the interview with Mr. Rene.  Since the first introduction with him we understood that he was a man without complex and very flexible. He welcomed us in Venice and asked us to introduce ourselves. He had travelled so much and he had so many stories with people that he told us a story connected to each of our countries. And he talked about the importance of living in an international and diverse environment. We asked him about what inspired him to become an artist. And his answer was sharp and clear, he was looking for a medium to communicate with people in a larger scale. We talked about a variety of issues like gender equality, what to him meant making a difference in life. He is a truly avant garde and remarkable individual and he had some very interesting opinions from which I learned a lot.  Afterwards they gave us a tour around all the palaces and they showed us the office from which all the logistics and organizing was done. They explained us the process of preparing everything for the biennale. Everything from</span></p><p><span style="color: #000000;">Thursday:</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">The big day for which we had practiced a lot beforehand was about to come. We went there to set up everything the music and to do the final preparations. All the girls were nervous but excited. We were about to start the flash mob in Venice. The first dance was like a warm up and to attract people to come. Then more and more people were coming to watch us. They were taking videos and pictures and some of them even joined the dance. I felt really happy that many were asking about where we came from and about our school and they seemed impressed from what we told them about UWC. Since in Venice there are tourists from all around the world, there happened to be an Indian just-married couple, who got very excited when we were dancing a Bollywood song. The lady joined us and her husband was really happy to see her dancing with us and I felt honored that we became part of their honeymoon memories.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">After the flash mob we went to take an interview with one of the engineers, a native Venetian, working in the palazzo. We asked him about his connection with Venice and how he viewed the change happening to the city. I was amazed by the fact that everyday more and more Venetians were leaving the city to leave somewhere else because of the high prices and taxes. And the last activity of the day was visiting the St. Peter’s square, one of the main touristic spots of Venice. The view was breathtaking and the cultural heritage priceless. We interviewed many tourists about their impression of Venice and what they liked best.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"> </p><p><span style="color: #000000;"><b>UWCM Flash mob </b></span></p><p><br /> <span style="color: #ff6600;"><a style="color: #ff6600;" href="https://www.facebook.com/groups/475240265997608">https://www.facebook.com/groups/475240265997608</a></span><br /> <span style="color: #000000;">due to copyright issues of song used in the flash mob, video was posted on facebook instead of YouTube. Therefore, please login to your account to access the video of the fla</span></p><p><span style="color: #000000;">Friday:</span></p><p><span style="color: #333333;">On Friday we went to say goodbye to everyone from the organization and went to see Rene once more for the last time. Again we had a very nice conversation with him. Even though we would have loved to stay longer it was about time we left. The journey back to Maastricht was long, tiring and painful, however it didn’t make our wonderful experience in Venice less valuable.   </span></p><p><span style="color: #000000;"><img title="" src="http://ic.pics.livejournal.com/nikkotomascasil/76768806/20720/20720_900.jpg" alt="" /></span></p><p><span style="color: #000000;"><b>REFLECTION by Tatevik Ghumashyan (Armenia)</b></span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">I am Tatevik Ghumashyan ,from Armenia .I was  one of the lucky people ,who was a part of a project week in Venice .The aim of the project was exploration of the art in Venice and show it through the documentary film. We spent there four  days, and let me notice that those days were the most happiest days in my life .Adventurous  trip full of love and  harmony .I still can’t believe ,that we made it .I am very grateful to Zharina Nikko Casil, who united us around one idea .</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">We had a cooperation with European cultural center ,in order to fully explore the art life in Venice . Due to different interviews with the local population we explored not only good but also bad sides of life in Venice .People complained about the government, and bad policy ruled by them.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">We had interviewed different tourists ,in order to understand their inspiration to traveling in Venice. Answers were multiple ,but they all felt, like they appeared in a real miracle .</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">The last day in Venice was unforgettable .We prepared a flash mob, made by different dances, which we learnt from our friends in UWC Maastricht. I was proud to show the national dances of my friends, and for a moment I felt like a world citizen .I am very proud, that we could make such an amazing project, which will stay in our hearts forever .Special thanks to our lovely school ,to UWC for providing us this unique opportunity to explore the wonderful  world around us .</span></p><p><span style="color: #000000;"><img title="" src="http://ic.pics.livejournal.com/nikkotomascasil/76768806/19757/19757_900.jpg" alt="" /></span></p><p><span style="color: #000000;"><b>REFLECTION by Ghita Benhayoune (France and Morocco)</b></span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">This Project Week was my most unexpected and eye-opening experience so far.  I was never very fund of arts and struggled a lot to enjoy it. Working with an art gallery was the first challenge: I had to overcome all the preconceived ideas I had of what I believed art to be and what being an artist meant. When we first met the team of the Global Arts Affair Foundation, I was amazed by their professionalism, passion and dedication. Their relationship was beyond anything I had ever seen before: they interacted like a family, all working together towards the bigger purpose that is their foundation. But the most significant moment of the project week was our meeting with the founder, René. His vision of art was eye opening for me: he saw his foundation as a way to support artists all over the world to convey their message, but also for him to spread his, which was the way he lived. He taught us about the value of honesty and love and how he incorporated it into the way his foundation works. He went to the point that he negotiated a business deal right in front of us! It was amazing to see how business worked in front of our eyes and how respectful he was of his values and considerate of other people with him. René inspired us and offered us a unique opportunity to investigate ourselves further, to thrive for growth during the summer. The city itself reflected René's way of living: full of life, the Carnival and its preparations showed us the best of Venezian artisanat and the value the locals gave it. This experience, truly changed me.</span></p><p><span style="color: #000000;"><img class="aligncenter" title="" src="http://ic.pics.livejournal.com/nikkotomascasil/76768806/22312/22312_900.jpg" alt="" /></span></p><p><span style="color: #000000;"><b>REFLECTION by Mishal Khan  (Pakistan)</b></span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">I have never eaten as much cheese as I did in those 5 days.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">This project week was a great experience as we got to meet some great people like Rene. Sharing his life story with us and some acts and habits he values the most in life such as honesty. He gave us a insight to how his business works by making a business right in front of us. At that point I actually felt myself struggling with choosing sides. Should I support the client who is trying to get a place at the exhibition, showcasing their artwork, with having to pay as less as possible? Or should I favour Rene, “the boss” who is trying to get as much money out of the client’s pocket to fund his exhibition and cover all the costs? Both sides seeking their profit. It was another moment when I saw Game theory in action.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">However this was not it. We were offered internships, in case we wanted to join, over the summer when their final architectural exhibition about space, time and existence will take place. Having seen the working environment of the Palazzos, some of our team members are already planning to join.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">The flash mob was one of the things that I had never done before. It made me step out of my comfort zone. Talking to the locals sketched a different picture of venice from what we were seeing.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">As a whole, this project week was a good opportunity for team building. Trying to sort out and minimize the budget, buying the cheapest food in supermarkets, deciding who does what, everything added up to making these five days memorable.</span></p><p><span style="color: #000000;"><img title="" src="http://ic.pics.livejournal.com/nikkotomascasil/76768806/20216/20216_900.jpg" alt="" /></span></p><p><span style="color: #000000;"><b>Reflection by Matilda Mayamiko (Malawi)</b></span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">The project week trip to Venice was such an amazing experience. I learnt that tolerance of cultural differences and values is one of the most important things when working as a group. Everyone in the group was willing to tolerate and work with the differences among us. We worked together as a group in everything, we divided the tasks among ourselves accordingly and it was much more easier to get through the whole week. I learnt that unity really matters and it one of the most important ways to move forward. Meeting Rhene and hearing his views about the world arts and cultures made me think about the issue of global unification even more. In his interview he said " The beauty lies in the differences but it does not mean that we should be blind to the differences". this made me think about our UWC community, how we are all different, from all over the world yet beautiful together working towards one common goal. in conclusion the project week experience was amazing! the team was wonderful and i had so much fun.</span></p><p><span style="color: #000000;"><img title="" src="http://ic.pics.livejournal.com/nikkotomascasil/76768806/19638/19638_900.jpg" alt="" /></span></p><p><span style="color: #000000;"><b>Reflection by Joelle Powe (Jamaica)</b></span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">My project week to Italy was a coming of age experience that was full of adventure, laughter, cultural exchange and delicious international cuisine. Our project week team, was completely random, with people from a really diverse geographical background. I was the only person from the Western hemisphere, being from the Caribbean. Being in an intimate setting such as a hostel and having the struggle of figuring out how to pay for transport and food daily definitely brought us closer together as a group. We all grew in independence and improvisation skills. In the beginning, I was picky about how we spend our food money, but near the end, I learned how to compromise and was grateful for whatever was provided.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">In the sunny afternoons in the city of Venice, we had many conversations and interviews with local Italians and tourists, engrossing ourselves in the world around us. I enjoyed the smells of cigarettes, pizza, coffee and salt water. In the nights, the girls and I exchanged stories and reflected on our time visiting the palazzo.We also did dances from our respective countries in a flash mob outside of the palazzo. IN this way, we demonstrated the UWC phenomenon, the culture of many  diverse cultures in harmony.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">The Venice project week was a phenomenal experience for me! I have made new friends, discovered a new network of art collectors in Venice and made an impact in Venice the city by showing them the UWC values.</span></p><h1 dir="ltr"><span style="color: #000000;"><img title="" src="http://ic.pics.livejournal.com/nikkotomascasil/76768806/21909/21909_900.jpg" alt="" /></span></h1><h1 dir="ltr"><span style="color: #000000;">Between the reality and a dream</span></h1><p dir="ltr"><span style="color: #000000;"><b>by Seda Bagiryan (Armenia)</b></span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">Some memories never fade away,</span></p><p dir="ltr" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">Some of them seem to be illusion or a dream that tastes too sweet and feels too warm to be true, but Venice was real and I was part of the dream.</span></p><p dir="ltr" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">A few years ago hardly would I imagine having a chance to be in the City of the Masks, but a while ago I walked on Rialto bridge with 9 other beautiful ladies that shared my excitement and admiration for Venice.</span></p><p dir="ltr" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">It was a great time of getting the taste of Venice through the exploration of arts and cultures in the European Culture Center. The discovery of new types of art works left me thinking and reflecting upon my perception of arts and cultures. Some pieces of art also brought me out of my comfort zone. For example, some sexual nude art pictures made me feel confused questioning whether any lines have been crossed in the creation of these art pieces. Indeed the lines vary in different cultures and another question is whether they should exist at all; however, it was an interesting and in way eye-opening experience to get to see alternative art works and to question my perception of the beauty of art.</span></p><p dir="ltr" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">Venice itself is a big piece of art which has a strong character that envelopes its visitors.  It held me very strongly and it seemed that not much else mattered in life other than Venice and my thoughts.  If you saw Harry Potter you might remember Dementors that steal people’s good memories, if their opposite characters existed they would originate from Venice - the city brought out all the warm and sweet memories that I have ever had, made me appreciate small thing that I usually take for granted, things that allow my existence - the sun, the air, the sounds I hear, people and Yourself with a greater hope and satisfaction for the moment.</span></p><p><span style="color: #000000;"><img class="aligncenter" title="" src="http://ic.pics.livejournal.com/nikkotomascasil/76768806/22188/22188_900.jpg" alt="" /><span style="color: #ff6600;"><a style="color: #ff6600;" href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-admin/profile.php">Howdy, olaya</a></span></span></p><p dir="ltr"><span style="color: #000000;"><b><span style="font-family: Arial;">REFLECTION by Maria Abdelhadi (Palestine)</span></b></span></p><p dir="ltr" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">Our project week was in Venice. We interviewed an artist and we learned from him, we also visited his galleries. That made learned so many things, i saw different sides of everything, so the experience for the personal side was successful more than i expected. But also, we brought here ideas for the artist students, and we took UWC’s values there.</span></p><p dir="ltr" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">I think, the most important thing that we achieved was the relationship between our school and the galleries, therefore, many successful things can be achieved. Experiences, ideas, and art works can be shared with the galleries in Venice.</span></p><p><span style="color: #000000;"><img class="aligncenter" title="" src="http://ic.pics.livejournal.com/nikkotomascasil/76768806/22771/22771_900.jpg" alt="" /></span><br /> <span style="color: #000000;"><b>ZHARINA NIKKO'S REFLECTION</b></span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">This is my first time organizing a huge project so far.</span><br /> <span style="color: #000000;"> Initially, my broad idea for planning a project week was something with regards to my interest, it's arts specifically--- music. But finding organizations offering opportunities for students isn't that probable.</span><br /> <span style="color: #000000;"> I rethought of everything and I decided to consider a project that would significantly help an organization.</span><br /> <span style="color: #000000;"> After emailing many organizations and proposing ideas, I was lucky enough to have several response from organizations. One of them was the response from Rene Rietmeyer, a very famous dutch artist who established European Cultural Centre, formerly known as Global Arts Affairs. I was very surpised with having the agreement from Rene. Within weeks after the notice, I got in contact with Grazia, the head of the Palazzos where we set our project. I am very grateful for the full cooperation of the ECC.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">"We see this as an educational opportunity between the United World College Maastricht and European Cultural Centre", Rene once sent via email. I was excited for the journey.</span><br /> <span style="color: #000000;"> I mean, it's a challenge. We're quite a large group. Yes, the road wasn't as easy as expected, but along the way, I found ease and relief within the company of nine other gorgeous and loving girls. I'm proud that we made it through better and worse situations during the 4-day project. We accomplished things we needed to and we extended UWC mission and values. The experience of eating bread and cheese most of meals for four days. Those times when we needed to wait for hours on airports and bust stations, sitting together, sleeping next to each other's arms, those warmth felt during late night chats. The times when we needed to cook our food, staying on one roof together, waking up sleepy ladies in the morning. Those mere natural 'arguing' moments and those sudden laughters, those fulfilling smiles and those dancing and singing moments. All these, I miss.</span><br /> <span style="color: #000000;"> I'm happy reading the reflections of my group mates for the PW. It feels satisfying being able to share a worthwhile experience with the girls.</span></p><p><span style="color: #000000;">Much love, Nikko</span></p><p><span style="color: #000000;">links provided for viewing videos:</span><br /> <span style="color: #ff6600;"><i>&lt;</i><i><u><a style="color: #ff6600;" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9nf_Ao82X_8&amp;feature=youtu.be" target="_self" rel="nofollow">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9nf_Ao8<wbr></wbr>2X_8&amp;feature=youtu.be</a></u>&gt;</i></span></p><p><span style="color: #ff6600;"><i><u>&lt;<a style="color: #ff6600;" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r79rKyQWrhI" target="_self" rel="nofollow">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r79rKy<wbr></wbr>QWrhI</a>&gt;</u></i></span></p><p><span style="color: #ff6600;"><i><u>&lt;<a style="color: #ff6600;" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vGTqQAp_Q4U" target="_self" rel="nofollow">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vGTqQA<wbr></wbr>p_Q4U</a>&gt;</u></i></span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #ff6600;"><u><i><b>&lt;</b><a style="color: #ff6600;" href="https://www.facebook.com/groups/475240265997608/" target="_self" rel="nofollow">https://www.facebook.com/groups/4752402<wbr></wbr>65997608/</a>&gt;</i></u></span><br /> <span style="color: #000000;">(due to copyright issues of song used in the flash mob, video was posted on Facebook instead of YouTube. Therefore, please login to your account to access the video of the flash mob)</span></p>";s:20:"text_selected_editor";s:7:"tinymce";s:5:"autop";b:1;s:12:"_sow_form_id";s:13:"56e6d21db8a55";s:11:"panels_info";a:5:{s:5:"class";s:31:"SiteOrigin_Widget_Editor_Widget";s:4:"grid";i:0;s:4:"cell";i:0;s:2:"id";i:0;s:5:"style";a:2:{s:27:"background_image_attachment";b:0;s:18:"background_display";s:4:"tile";}}}}s:5:"grids";a:1:{i:0;a:2:{s:5:"cells";i:1;s:5:"style";a:0:{}}}s:10:"grid_cells";a:1:{i:0;a:2:{s:4:"grid";i:0;s:6:"weight";i:1;}}}]]></wp:meta_value>

	<item>
		<title>Feb&#039;16 - Refugee aid Serbia - Miksaliste</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/03/14/feb16-refugee-aid-serbia-miksaliste/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 14 Mar 2016 08:46:37 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=363</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">by Kylie Hamawndy</span>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">The morning of February 5th was  when we started our journey. I, Kylie along with six others; Hannah, Ibrahim, Isaac, Yvonne, Kiitan and Anthony, from United World College Maastricht, started off our journey all the way from Maastricht to Amsterdam to Budapest and then took a train to Belgrade, Serbia. We arrived in Belgrade very early in the morning, the silence of the city frightened us at 6.00am. We settled and then we started our real journey at Miksaliste.</span></p>
<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Capture.png" rel="attachment wp-att-364"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-364 size-medium" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Capture-300x79.png" alt="Capture" width="300" height="79" /></a>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Miksalište, an organization that is located at Mostarska 5 in Savamala, is one of Belgrade’s few open spaces where refugees from Syria, Afghanistan, Iraq, algeria, Western Sahara, Pakistan, Morocco who travel through Serbia to reach Europe can eat, get clothes, have a shower and get other necessities. The project was set up in September 2015 and the volunteers and coordinators worked hard to make it a sustainable place where they can provide as much as possible to the refugees.  We as a team chose it for this project week because we wanted to help the refugees who try to reach europe reach their next destination on the trail. Serbia is a place where there aren’t many established refugee camps and where most of the refugees sleep on the street as for most of them it is only a place along their trail, somewhere they pass through. We thought this was the best place to really help and apply some of our knowledge but also to gain more insight on the significance of the global matter of the refugees. By recommendation we came to the facebook page of Refugee Aid Serbia that brought us in contact with this organization. What appealed to us about this organisation is that they didn’t see the refugees as a number but as real people where they spoke to them as equals and hanged around with them.</span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Capture-1.png" rel="attachment wp-att-365"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-365 size-full" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Capture-1.png" alt="Capture" width="632" height="351" /></a></p>
&nbsp;
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">The reason we decided to do this project initially was because the refugee crisis is something we have discussed over and over again with our colleagues at school. Through discussing this issue we noticed that we were ready to be exposed to this crisis and also to no longer have to assume things but to see them and experience them first hand. Some of us had already been exposed to topics of such type before going there, others had not. From the first day in Miksalište we saw how much we have missed out on in our hours-long discussions, how we really do not know as much as we think we do. Although we always tried to fit them into one cultural background, ethnicity, religion, we found out that refugees are not only from Iraq and Syria, refugees come from all sorts of backgrounds and that is what makes it a global issue, and not the fact that almost all Western countries are involved with it. We learned from day one that discussions are essential but not when all you do is discuss, we learned that unless you go to the field and help out you never really know what it is all about. </span></p>
<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Capture-2.png" rel="attachment wp-att-366"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-366 size-full" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Capture-2.png" alt="Capture" width="715" height="299" /></a>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Everyday we volunteered at Miksalište from 9.30 in the morning until 16.00 in the afternoon. As the place is divided into sections every one or two of us were doing different things each day. The sections were clothes, shoes, hygiene, food (breakfast and lunch), tea as well as one person would be counting the number of  refugees coming into the center just to get an approximation to consider for the amount of food supplies each day, also to keep a record. Each one of us got to experience working at each one of these sections at least once throughout the week. Each day the center would be open to refugees at 10.00 in the morning with breakfast, all other sections would be closed when food was served. Then in an hour or an hour and half depending on the amount of people that day breakfast would finish and all other sections would open. The 2-3 hours between breakfast and lunch would be devoted to handing out the other supplies or simply by serving tea to the refugees as many times as they wanted and hanging out with them (the tea section was a separate big </span>tent which had a sitting area with tables and chairs where refugees would spend most of their day). At 13.00 in the afternoon lunch would start, refugees would rush in making a line and food would be served either by a company called Food For Life that would cook fresh food, or by some volunteering women that would cook soup, or simply giving out packagings of donations Miksalište gets. Lunch would continue until around 14.00 in the afternoon and then other sections would open again, the number of people would get less and less around 16.00 until the center closed. Each day we would hear quite a lot of stories through talking to the refugees and translating between them and different organizations that helped them plan their routes.</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Another organization that Miksalište got us in contact with was Info Park, we met a group from there as they would come to the center sometimes, what that group did was to go the train station a few times a week and meet the new refugees coming in mostly from Bulgaria and distribute food to them, help them get their tickets to the next train in case they were leaving directly to Croatian border or introduce them to Miksalište if they were staying. One night we decided to work with them as well at the train station to get a sense of what it was like, but mostly to wake up from the superficial bubble we unfortunately have surrounded ourselves with for a very long time. All team members agreed that that night was something to never forget, it was very real and hard, but what made it even harder was to know that most of these people that have been through a lot already will be sent back to Belgrade due to not being Syrian or Iraqi.</span></p>

<pre><img class="aligncenter wp-image-367 size-full" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Capture-3.png" alt="Capture" width="605" height="451" /></pre>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">By doing service in our break we became more aware of what our responsibility is as individuals, how we should deal with it, we learned that there is a lot to do and that each individual has the potential to do something about this, we learned that there are no limitations and if there are people like the coordinators of these organizations that contribute each working day of their week (and weekends even) to doing what they do, so can we. We became more aware of what it really means to be sustainable and how much of a major role it plays in keeping a clear balance in the world around us. We learned that teamwork means not only to work with others practically but to be able to emotionally support others when they have a hard time enduring the situation or when they have a breakdown. We learned that global issues are not far at all, they are right in front of us and that a lot of people are counting on us to help solve this or to at least try. The planning of the project week was not always easy and there were challenges working with people who had been through so much, but I think we learned a lot by the work we did and the challenges we faced. Overall, it surely was an unforgettable experience.</span></p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>363</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2016-03-14 08:46:37]]></wp:post_date>

	<item>
		<title>Feb&#039;16 - Oslo, Norway</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/03/14/feb16-oslo-norway/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 14 Mar 2016 09:12:06 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=369</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[by Ane, Lochlann, Isabella, Jule, Julius, Aru, Mikhail and Adithya
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong>[spacer height="20px"]Norway</strong> - a socialist utopia? Often cited among the best countries to live in, as a force for gender equality and social justice politically, the scarcely populated country makes a frequent appearance in the media. From Bernie Sanders to Disney’s Frozen, it is easy to view this tiny, mountainous nation with high regards - yet actually living or experiencing such a culture bids a different understanding.</span></p>

<blockquote>We found value in the kind of discussion, dilemmas and brainwork one seldom encounters in a homogeneous, monocultural group.</blockquote>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">Our project week was proposed as an opportunity for acquaintance, self-reflection - a chance to get a firmer grasp of a term we use frequently, yet often in a hollow manner. An investigation of how efficient the ‘’Nordic model’’ is, we claimed, an investigation into the manner which Nordic countries, such as Norway are run. In order to discover the effects of the “welfare state” and “mixed economy” this people embraces so zealously, we ventured to the capital of Oslo in order to gain impressions from both organizations and the common being. Indeed, it was educational - yet these days were filled of so much more substance than so.</span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">Few from the group can say it made them “understand” the “Nordic model” more. Yet we found value in the kind of discussion, dilemmas and brainwork one seldom encounters in a homogeneous, monocultural group. If it did not evoke an understanding of the Nordic model, surely it set a flame to our understanding of the world, of cultures and their inner workings.</span></p>
<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW8.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-372"><img class="wp-image-372 size-large aligncenter" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW8-1024x683.jpg" alt="PW8" width="700" height="467" /></a>

<span style="color: #000000;">[spacer height="20px"]Throughout our Project Week we encountered with several <strong>organisations</strong> and people in order to discover the multiple sides to the functioning of the Norwegian state and economy.</span>
<ul>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">The Norwegian parliament, Stortinget</span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">A lecture at the University of Oslo on “Women, Gender and Work”</span>
<ul>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">on how labour is distributed in Norway compared to other European countries</span></li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">Pro-sentret</span>
<ul>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">a center that provides help to sex workers in Norway, particularly with safety, emotions and keeping them healthy.</span></li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">Statoil</span>
<ul>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">one of the largest oil companies in the world, which also is working a bit with the development of renewable energy in Europe, namely off-shore wind energy. Particularly important is that it is state-owned, but it still functions as a competitive company.</span></li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">Barne-, ungdoms- og familiedirektoratet</span>
<ul>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">the Child Protection Agency of Norway, where we learned about when they actually take action, in particular with immigrant children, who might be used to a different upbringing. We also learned how they function within the Norwegian state, collaborating with other organisations to ensure a national protocol.</span></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<blockquote>
<p style="text-align: center;">We wanted to investigate the truthfulness of the stereotypes commonly perpetuated in the classroom.</p>
</blockquote>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">Norway is often internationally recognized as the ‘’optimal’’ society, due to high levels of quality of life, and low levels of corruption and poverty. However, the truth is often more convoluted. Particularly the increase in right-wing ideologies sparked by terrorists attacks on 22nd of July by Anders Behring Breivik, reinforced by the recent refugee crisis. We chose this project because we were very interested in how this economic and political system is achieved and implemented.</span></p>
<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW6.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-374"><img class="wp-image-374 size-large aligncenter" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW6-1024x576.jpg" alt="PW6" width="700" height="394" /></a>

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW7.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-373"><img class="wp-image-373 size-large aligncenter" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW7-1024x683.jpg" alt="PW7" width="700" height="467" /></a>

<span style="color: #000000;">[spacer height="20px"]Our main objective was to learn more of the economic situation in Norway. We wanted to investigate the truthfulness of the stereotypes commonly perpetuated in the classroom. We achieved them by visiting several organisations very much involved in the management of Norway as a state and could provide us insights in the situation currently.</span>
<h3><span style="color: #000000;">General program and a detailed itinerary of Thursday</span></h3>
<ul>
<ul>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">Saturday: Frognerparken (Vigeland sculpture park) - Slottet (Palace) - Nationaltheatret (National theatre)</span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">Sunday: Nasjonalgalleriet (national gallery) - Operaen (Opera)</span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">Monday: Stortinget (Parliament) - Hjemmefrontmuseet (Resistance museum)</span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">Tuesday: Hike at Holmenkollen</span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">Wednesday: Lecture on gender and work, University of Oslo 12.15-14</span>
<span style="color: #000000;">Munchmuseet (Munch museum)</span>
<span style="color: #000000;">Exhibition: Mapplethorpe+Munch</span>
<span style="color: #000000;">Grønland multiethnic immigrants’ zone</span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">Thursday: Itinerary</span>
<ul>
	<li style="padding-left: 30px;"><span style="color: #000000;">10-12: Pro senteret (prostitution research)</span></li>
	<li style="padding-left: 30px;"><span style="color: #000000;">Bus 31 to IT Fornebu</span></li>
	<li style="padding-left: 30px;"><span style="color: #000000;">13-16.20: Lunch 13-13.30, 13.30-16.00 in room A1031</span></li>
	<li style="padding-left: 30px;"><span style="color: #000000;">13.30-14.15: Anca Jalba, Investor relations: Intro: Value chain (exploration, field development, production, refining). The state as owner, Oil fund, transparency, activities worldwide etc.</span></li>
	<li style="padding-left: 30px;"><span style="color: #000000;">13.30-14.15: Anca Jalba, Investor relations: Intro: Value chain (exploration, field development, production, refining). The state as owner, Oil fund, transparency, activities worldwide etc.</span></li>
	<li style="padding-left: 30px;"><span style="color: #000000;">14.15-15: Fritz H. Eilertsen, Johan Castberg project: Project development in general+examples of major industry projects, Johan Castberg (offshore project development)</span></li>
	<li style="padding-left: 30px;"><span style="color: #000000;">15-15.45: Tom James, New energy solutions: Offshore wind etc.</span>
<span style="color: #000000;"> New energy venture fund, announced on 16 Feb: http://entry.statoil.no/NewsAndMedia/News/2016/Pages/16feb-energy-venture.aspx</span></li>
	<li style="padding-left: 30px;"><span style="color: #000000;">16.30: Ferry boat from Fornebu (Sjøflyhavna) to Aker brygge</span></li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">Friday: Barne-, ungdoms- og familiedirektoratet (Child protection services) - Nobel Peace Prize Museum</span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">Saturday and Sunday: Hiking around Oslo</span></li>
</ul>
</ul>
&nbsp;

&nbsp;
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">Our PW was particularly based on investigation, so it was very important in discovering something first hand. It links to the UWC mission of learning first hand of different cultures to eradicate hate and racism through the understanding of another person’s culture. For example, while traveling home on the metro, several people noticed Adithya’s hand bleeding, so they offered tissues and plasters. This gave those who didn’t know much about the people of Norway were positively surprised with this kindness. Some of the values we demonstrated were the values of international and intercultural understanding by departing on this culture week to a culture that most of us were unfamiliar with and compassion and service by handing some of our packed food to people on the street.</span></p>
<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW9.png" rel="attachment wp-att-371"><img class="wp-image-371 size-large aligncenter" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW9-1024x640.png" alt="PW9" width="700" height="438" /></a>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">[spacer height="20px"]All in all, our project week was a success of investigating the society of Norway and its history. We learned a lot about the developmental status of Norway, particularly also its scopes of international understanding, such as the Nobel Peace Prize committee. We all for sure widened our understanding of Norway and how we look upon other cultures in comparison.</span></p>
<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Pw10.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-370"><img class="wp-image-370 size-large aligncenter" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Pw10-1024x683.jpg" alt="Pw10" width="700" height="467" /></a>

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Feb&#039;16 - Istanbul, Turkey</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/03/14/feb16-istanbul-turkey/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 14 Mar 2016 09:23:56 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=376</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong>Information about organizations:</strong></span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong><u>Syrian Education Commission</u></strong>:This is a non-profit, non-political civil society organization that is specialized in the educational process in all its stages. It takes cares of the Syrian students by monitoring and seeking solutions for them through values such as teamwork, originality and modernity, credibility and transparency and professional standards. They have created many projects but the one that we visited was the “Project of Dropout Pupils”, which consists in establishing centers in Turkey for educating and rehabilitating students who have been deprived of education in order to prevent them from wandering in the streets and getting lost in the mazes of ignorance and terrorism. </span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;"><u><strong>[spacer height="20px"]ASAM (Istanbul’s unit)</strong>:</u> The Association for Solidarity with Asylum Seekers and Migrants (ASAM) was established in Ankara on December 22, 1995 as a non-profit and non-governmental organization. The primary goal of ASAM is to create solutions to the problems that refugees and asylum seekers encounter in Turkey, to help them to fulfill their primary needs and to support them to provide access for fundamental rights and services. ASAM provides services to refugees and asylum seekers without discrimination on the grounds of language, religion, sex, race, sexual orientation and political ideology.(Veronica, UWCM'17)</span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW12.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-383"><img class="wp-image-383 size-large aligncenter" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW12-1024x683.jpg" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" srcset="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW12-300x200.jpg 300w, http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW12-768x512.jpg 768w, http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW12-1024x683.jpg 1024w, http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW12-272x182.jpg 272w" alt="PW12" width="700" height="467" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW14.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-381"><img class="wp-image-381 size-large aligncenter" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW14-1024x576.jpg" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" srcset="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW14-300x169.jpg 300w, http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW14-768x432.jpg 768w, http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW14-1024x576.jpg 1024w, http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW14.jpg 1334w" alt="PW14" width="700" height="394" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong>[spacer height="20px"]Why this project week?</strong></span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">We chose this project week for couple of reasons. The first one is the activity, which is helping Syrian refugees. As we all know, many Syrians left their country, which is in a situation of a brutal civil war, in order to start their life again. We felt obligated to help them, and especially the kids, who are the next generation. Another reason is the location. Many people assume that Turkey is not a safe place because of what they hear in the media. We wanted to go there in order to see what Turkey is really is, and it turned out to be one of the most welcoming places we have ever been to! Despite the media, Turkey is safe, Istanbul is safe, and it was important to prove that.</span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">(Achiad, UWCM’16)</span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW11.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-384"><img class="wp-image-384 size-large aligncenter" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW11-1024x576.jpg" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" srcset="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW11-300x169.jpg 300w, http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW11-768x432.jpg 768w, http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW11-1024x576.jpg 1024w, http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW11.jpg 1334w" alt="PW11" width="700" height="394" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong>[spacer height="20px"]One of our days: </strong></span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">Thursday 11th of February - </span><span style="color: #000000;">Day four.</span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #333333;">This day was our second day in the organisation “Al Asam”. We left our apartment that is in the area of Sultan Ahmet at approximately 9 o'clock to go to Karaköy. From that point we had to walk more than one hour. It was really difficult because the city is like a mountain and we do need to climb especially the way we had taken that day. We arrived to the organisation at around 10 and there was a Turkish lesson for the children (3 to 8 years old). We joined the lesson and helped the children with memorizing exercise. After the end of the lesson we had a lot of fun activities with them and this was the most important and enjoying moment of the journey. At 3 o'clock the second group of students came. They were mainly teenagers and with a highest age of 15. The day before we have gone with them near to the sea for their photography lesson. That day they had hip hop dance and singing lesson. The teachers were really professional and they danced very well. We also joined the dance lesson. And we had fun. The day before during the way to the sea they have taught us some Arabic and we taught them our first languages. At the end of the dance lesson was the singing lesson. Each of the teenagers had their own lyrics that they sing to express what they cannot say through music. We also participated to that lesson by doing random freestyle on a bit. At the end of the day we had an exchanges of addresses with them to keep being in touch.</span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">(Naimatou, UWCM’17)</span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW15.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-380"><img class="wp-image-380 size-large aligncenter" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW15-1024x681.jpg" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" srcset="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW15-300x200.jpg 300w, http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW15-768x511.jpg 768w, http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW15-1024x681.jpg 1024w" alt="PW15" width="700" height="466" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong>[spacer height="20px"]Our objectives :</strong></span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">Our learning goals and objectives are to build project planning skills through the organization of the project week, build communication skills through the contact with Syrian organizations, become more aware of the situation of the Syrian children in foreign countries and have an impact on them through our own effort. During the project week in Istanbul we achieved our learning goals and objectives fully. Meanwhile, we planned the trip in Turkey entirely on our own: we booked the flight tickets, apartments and navigated ourselves to different locations, while everything went on smoothly. Also, we had a very good time with both organizations we worked with. We contacted them beforehand and arrived on time. They were very welcoming and there was no miscommunication within the process. Sitting together with Syrian kids from different age groups in the same room, we had a great opportunity to interact with them closely and understand them better. Although there were huge language barriers among us, as we couldn’t speak arabic nor turkish, they didn’t stop us from being friends with those innocent, cheerful kids. At the end of the day we became from very close to one another and too hard to say goodbye. However, despite the fact that we enjoyed a lot working with the organization, we did identify several problems and difficult that the Syrian refugees encountered. A lot of them are suffering from poverty, because of their family inability to make a living, the kids themselves have to work by selling tissues to pedestrians. Though the organizations provide basic education for them, they don’t have money for textbooks and the basic educational resources. For them education is a luxury. We felt very sad about that and through the speech we gave them, and all the games we played with them, we hoped that they would never give up their hope and dreams and thrive with the help of education.</span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">(Nina, UWCM’17)</span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW17.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-378"><img class="wp-image-378 size-large aligncenter" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW17-1024x681.jpg" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" srcset="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW17-300x200.jpg 300w, http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW17-768x511.jpg 768w, http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW17-1024x681.jpg 1024w" alt="PW17" width="700" height="466" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW18.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-377"><img class="wp-image-377 size-large aligncenter" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW18-1024x681.jpg" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" srcset="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW18-300x200.jpg 300w, http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW18-768x511.jpg 768w, http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW18-1024x681.jpg 1024w" alt="PW18" width="700" height="466" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong>[spacer height="20px"]The importance of this Project Week :<em>                  </em></strong></span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">We headed to Turkey to help with the syrian refugees. The trip there was a challenge, because a lot of us come from priviledged backgrounds. We learned that the world is far from ideal and that there is a long way to go. However we all believed that if we fight and if we taught the children to fight as well for everyone’s rights, the world will become a better place. Staying with the children was a personal challenge because of the language barrier, which was interesting because as much as we were different we were still able to comprehend each other and to build a special relationship. Also, dealing with children and seeing them facing a such situation where they flee from their home and have to find a way to survive in the street made us sad, angry and more compassionate towards the cause. But we were there, we showed them support and even if they were young and might not have ununderstood why we left so early, at least we made them smile and this wasn’t the kind of smiles you can see in Western Europe. These were pure smiles that you cannot immitate. As bad as their situation can be, you can still see the way they are interested by anything and the happiness they can share with you. I think this project week was definitely important for each of us in the sense that we directly saw what we used to hear on the TV, medias, internet and that it changed somehow our mind. We all come from different countries and for some of us, going in Turkey with such a different culture than where we are from was eye opening to the similarities and differences that western and eastern cultures can have. The fact that one paraguayan, one guatemalan, two french, one moroccan, one egyptian, one burkinabe, one israeli and one chinese show that it is possible to help and that it is not that complicated to help people different from us.</span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">(Mathilde, UWCM’17)</span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW16.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-379"><img class="wp-image-379 size-large aligncenter" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW16-1024x681.jpg" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" srcset="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW16-300x200.jpg 300w, http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW16-768x511.jpg 768w, http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW16-1024x681.jpg 1024w" alt="PW16" width="700" height="466" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">This project week lasted four days, but our actions won’t stop there. We come from all over the world and with this experience we can continue, at even bigger scales, to help</span>. <span style="color: #000000;">The refugee crisis is not a joke and media don’t share everything, so it’s our own responsibility to decide whether or not we should try to save people who die or children who are losing their childhood</span>.</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW13.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-382"><img class="wp-image-382 size-large" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW13-1024x683.jpg" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" srcset="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW13-300x200.jpg 300w, http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW13-768x512.jpg 768w, http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW13-1024x683.jpg 1024w, http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW13-272x182.jpg 272w" alt="PW13" width="700" height="467" /></a></p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
