			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_panels_data_preview]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:3:{s:7:"widgets";a:1:{i:0;a:6:{s:5:"title";s:0:"";s:4:"text";s:12467:"<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong>Information about organizations:</strong></span></p><ul style="text-align: justify;"><li><span style="color: #000000;"><strong><u>Syrian Education Commission</u></strong>:This is a non-profit, non-political civil society organization that is specialized in the educational process in all its stages. It takes cares of the Syrian students by monitoring and seeking solutions for them through values such as teamwork, originality and modernity, credibility and transparency and professional standards. They have created many projects but the one that we visited was the “Project of Dropout Pupils”, which consists in establishing centers in Turkey for educating and rehabilitating students who have been deprived of education in order to prevent them from wandering in the streets and getting lost in the mazes of ignorance and terrorism.</span></li><li><span style="color: #000000;"><u><strong>ASAM (Istanbul’s unit)</strong>:</u> The Association for Solidarity with Asylum Seekers and Migrants (ASAM) was established in Ankara on December 22, 1995 as a non-profit and non-governmental organization. The primary goal of ASAM is to create solutions to the problems that refugees and asylum seekers encounter in Turkey, to help them to fulfill their primary needs and to support them to provide access for fundamental rights and services. ASAM provides services to refugees and asylum seekers without discrimination on the grounds of language, religion, sex, race, sexual orientation and political ideology.(Veronica, UWCM'17)</span></li></ul><p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW12.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-383"><img class="wp-image-383 size-large aligncenter" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW12-1024x683.jpg" alt="PW12" width="700" height="467" /></a></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW14.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-381"><img class="wp-image-381 size-large aligncenter" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW14-1024x576.jpg" alt="PW14" width="700" height="394" /></a></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong>Why this project week?</strong></span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">We chose this project week for couple of reasons. The first one is the activity, which is helping Syrian refugees. As we all know, many Syrians left their country, which is in a situation of a brutal civil war, in order to start their life again. We felt obligated to help them, and especially the kids, who are the next generation. Another reason is the location. Many people assume that Turkey is not a safe place because of what they hear in the media. We wanted to go there in order to see what Turkey is really is, and it turned out to be one of the most welcoming places we have ever been to! Despite the media, Turkey is safe, Istanbul is safe, and it was important to prove that.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">(Achiad, UWCM’16)</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW11.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-384"><img class="wp-image-384 size-large aligncenter" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW11-1024x576.jpg" alt="PW11" width="700" height="394" /></a></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong>One of our day : </strong></span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">Thursday 11th of February</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">Day four.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">This day was our second day in the organisation “ Al Asam”.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">We left our apartment that is in the area of Sultan Ahmet at approximately 9 o'clock to go to Karaköy.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">From that point we had to walk more than one hour. It was really difficult because the city is like a mountain and we do need to climb especially the way we had taken that day.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">We arrived to the organisation at around 10 and there was a Turkish lesson for the children (3 to 8 years old). We joined the lesson and helped the children with memorising exercise.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">After the end of the lesson we had a lot of fun activities with them and this was the most important and enjoying moment of the journey.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">At 3 o'clock the second group of students came. They were mainly teenagers and with a highest age of 15. The day before we have gone with them near to the sea for their photography lesson.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">That day they had hip hop dance and singing lesson. The teachers were really professional and they danced very well. We also joined the dance lesson. And we had fun. The day before during the way to the sea they have taught us some Arabic and we taught them our first languages.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">At the end of the dance lesson was the singing lesson. Each of the teenagers had their own lyrics that they sing to express what they cannot say through music. We also participated to that lesson by doing random freestyle on a bit.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">At the end of the day we had an exchanges of addresses with them to keep being in touch.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">(Naimatou, UWCM’17)</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW15.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-380"><img class="wp-image-380 size-large aligncenter" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW15-1024x681.jpg" alt="PW15" width="700" height="466" /></a></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong>Our objectives :</strong></span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">Our learning goals and objectives are to build project planning skills through the organization of the project week, build communication skills through the contact with Syrian organizations, become more aware of the situation of the Syrian children in foreign countries and have an impact on them through our own effort. During the project week in Istanbul we achieved our learning goals and objectives fully. Meanwhile, we planned the trip in Turkey entirely on our own: we booked the flight tickets, apartments and navigated ourselves to different locations, while everything went on smoothly. Also, we had a very good time with both organizations we worked with. We contacted them beforehand and arrived on time. They were very welcoming and there was no miscommunication within the process. Sitting together with Syrian kids from different age groups in the same room, we had a great opportunity to interact with them closely and understand them better. Although there were huge language barriers among us, as we couldn’t speak arabic nor turkish, they didn’t stop us from being friends with those innocent, cheerful kids. At the end of the day we became from very close to one another and too hard to say goodbye. However, despite the fact that we enjoyed a lot working with the organization, we did identify several problems and difficult that the Syrian refugees encountered. A lot of them are suffering from poverty, because of their family inability to make a living, the kids themselves have to work by selling tissues to pedestrians. Though the organizations provide basic education for them, they don’t have money for textbooks and the basic educational resources. For them education is a luxury. We felt very sad about that and through the speech we gave them, and all the games we played with them, we hoped that they would never give up their hope and dreams and thrive with the help of education.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">(Nina, UWCM’17)</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW17.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-378"><img class="wp-image-378 size-large aligncenter" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW17-1024x681.jpg" alt="PW17" width="700" height="466" /></a></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW18.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-377"><img class="wp-image-377 size-large aligncenter" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW18-1024x681.jpg" alt="PW18" width="700" height="466" /></a></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong>The importance of this Project Week :<em>                  </em></strong></span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">We headed to Turkey to help with the syrian refugees. The trip there was a challenge, because a lot of us come from priviledged backgrounds. We learned that the world is far from ideal and that there is a long way to go. However we all believed that if we fight and if we taught the children to fight as well for everyone’s rights, the world will become a better place. Staying with the children was a personal challenge because of the language barrier, which was interesting because as much as we were different we were still able to comprehend each other and to build a special relationship. Also, dealing with children and seeing them facing a such situation where they flee from their home and have to find a way to survive in the street made us sad, angry and more compassionate towards the cause. But we were there, we showed them support and even if they were young and might not have ununderstood why we left so early, at least we made them smile and this wasn’t the kind of smiles you can see in Western Europe. These were pure smiles that you cannot immitate. As bad as their situation can be, you can still see the way they are interested by anything and the happiness they can share with you. I think this project week was definitely important for each of us in the sense that we directly saw what we used to hear on the TV, medias, internet and that it changed somehow our mind. We all come from different countries and for some of us, going in Turkey with such a different culture than where we are from was eye opening to the similarities and differences that western and eastern cultures can have. The fact that one paraguayan, one guatemalan, two french, one moroccan, one egyptian, one burkinabe, one israeli and one chinese show that it is possible to help and that it is not that complicated to help people different from us.</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">(Mathilde, UWCM’17)</span></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW16.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-379"><img class="wp-image-379 size-large aligncenter" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW16-1024x681.jpg" alt="PW16" width="700" height="466" /></a></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">This project week lasted four days, but our actions won’t stop there. We come from all over the world and with this experience we can continue, at even bigger scales, to help</span>.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #000000;">The refugee crisis is not a joke and media don’t share everything, so it’s our own responsibility to decide whether or not we should try to save people who die or children who are losing their childhood</span>.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW13.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-382"><img class="wp-image-382 size-large" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/PW13-1024x683.jpg" alt="PW13" width="700" height="467" /></a></p>";s:20:"text_selected_editor";s:7:"tinymce";s:5:"autop";b:1;s:12:"_sow_form_id";s:13:"56e6dab5eed80";s:11:"panels_info";a:5:{s:5:"class";s:31:"SiteOrigin_Widget_Editor_Widget";s:4:"grid";i:0;s:4:"cell";i:0;s:2:"id";i:0;s:5:"style";a:2:{s:27:"background_image_attachment";b:0;s:18:"background_display";s:4:"tile";}}}}s:5:"grids";a:1:{i:0;a:2:{s:5:"cells";i:1;s:5:"style";a:0:{}}}s:10:"grid_cells";a:1:{i:0;a:2:{s:4:"grid";i:0;s:6:"weight";i:1;}}}]]></wp:meta_value>

	<item>
		<title>Feb&#039;16 - Morocco</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/03/15/feb16-morocco/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 15 Mar 2016 07:56:27 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=410</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="text-align: justify;">by Ulises, Oumaima, Ceri, Charlotte, Valeria, Martin, Pietro, Sofia, Aya and Kathleen</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;">[spacer height="20px"]We just arrived at Weez airport in Dusseldorf it is only 4:20 and we have to wait until 9 in order to take our flight to Fez, Morocco. An atmosphere of excitement covers our team since we left campus. Another country, another continent, another culture is just three hours and a half from us.</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;">[spacer height="20px"]We just arrived in <strong>Fez</strong>, Morocco. The weather was surprisingly fresh, with a lot of dry wind. The effects of globalization could be seen since the moment we landed because the airport was just renovated and the installations where incredibly well designed. Furthermore, as we move along the city with the help of Aya’s parents, the effect of globalization could be seen more and more. Houses, large buildings were replacing the olive plantations in the surroundings of Fez.</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Capture-4.png" rel="attachment wp-att-411"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-411 size-full" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Capture-4.png" alt="Capture" width="605" height="452" /></a></p>

<h2 style="text-align: justify;">[spacer height="20px"]Our first Moroccan breakfast!</h2>
<p style="text-align: justify;">Sadly not all of us eat meat! However the ones we do, it was amazing! Eggs with a different kind of meat, “man” (no idea how it is spelled but it was heavenly delicious), some other sweet pieces of bread that were just full of taste. The environment around the restaurant was busier than our usual Maastricht but with a calm environment. A ride of at least three hours was ahead of us, we went through Rabat without stopping just to barely see it. <strong>Casablanca</strong> was our main goal by this day, however in our way we encountered with beautiful deserted landscapes that for many of us were totally new. Morocco is incredibly huge! So much free land.</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;">We discover the preference of Oumaima towards Indians! But we are going to keep the lucky one anonymously!</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;">[spacer height="20px"]As soon as we arrived at Aya’s house in Casablanca, the dinner was waiting for us! Well, we thought it was the dinner but it was the gate that is before the dinner. And the dinner was a combination of different salads, olives, chicken, beef which was perfectly combined. We all sleep really well that night! The first Breakfast! Pancakes, tangerines, bread, milk, amlo and more! Was just wonderful! Afterwards, we went to the French school, however, our entrance was not permitted because they were afraid of terrorist attacks. (If like a Mexican a Salvadoran, or even a girl from Hong Kong will attack) However, we observed how the impact of the globalization affected the areas surrounding the French school.</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;">[spacer height="20px"]We visited the Mosque Hassan II, one of the biggest in the whole world. We had the chance to visit inside of it. The amount of money that the king had to put on it has to be incredibly huge! Also, we had the chance to visit the biggest mall in the whole continent of Africa. An aquarium was waiting for us just in the middle of the mall.</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;">[spacer height="20px"]Hammam! The boys and the hammam got along pretty well! Hammam was a kind of spa where you get scrubbed in a warm room. The guys slept really well! After we all ate real couscous!</p>

<h2 style="text-align: justify;">[spacer height="20px"]On our way to Marrakech!</h2>
<p style="text-align: justify;">We just took the train to <b>Marrakesh</b>! The train was surprisingly well maintained. The impact of globalization had reached almost everywhere but not everyone. The development of the city of Marrakesh is incredibly high, however not everybody has the access to all of this new resources. In Marrakesh, we had the chance to discuss this and another type of problems with other teenagers. We had the chance to discuss the state of the monarchy is nowadays and how this and external factors affect the society as a whole. A lack of opportunities and a sense of censorship surrounds the youth we talked to, problems that are common everywhere else but that its roots are well into the ground, in such a way that is hard to find a solution.</p>
<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Capture-5.png" rel="attachment wp-att-412"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-412 size-full" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Capture-5.png" alt="Capture" width="420" height="558" /></a>
<p style="text-align: justify;">Marrakesh we had the chance to visit characteristic market which makes this city famous worldwide. A number of colors and different artifacts is characteristic of this place. Scarfs, food, seafood, spices anything you want can be found there. Morocco ends up being a country where all our expectations were and were not right at the same time. We experimented hospitality to the fullest from Aya’s parents, we felt morocco as a living organism made up of great people which are always moving, working, dancing, cooking, singing, playing all the time. Morocco ends up being for most of us the trigger for a paradigm shift towards our stereotypes. Morocco for project week, was a wise decision, not only for the particular environment but also for the people and the conversations we had with them. It is different to read about a country’s situation than experiencing it. We left Morocco with a feeling of hearts and flowers, with the aim to go back and actually immerse ourselves within their culture.</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Feb&#039;16 - Sweden</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/03/17/feb16-sweden/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 17 Mar 2016 07:54:14 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=485</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[For our project week we endeavored to the great lands of Scandinavia to face the cold winds and grey skies. Actually it wasn't that cold and we were graced with a few days of sun. We worked with an organization in Sweden called Mosaik a branch of a larger organisation called Students for Christ Europe (SFC Europe). This is in an organization leading to broaden discussions about faith, our beliefs and why we believe. One of our goals was to reach out to students in Malmo on their views of faith particularly Christianity and get their opinions on what role religion has in Sweden. In addition, though Sweden can be identified as a prosperous country the region we went to still faces some degree of poverty. This is especially faced by the Romani people. So with the church we volunteered at a homeless shelter where we helped to prepare meals and take care of other necessities such as making the beds and cleaning up. The people staying there usually pay a small fee of less than 2 euros which includes a night stay, 3 meals and other utilities. The church aims to help as many homeless people but does this with a fee as to give the people a sense of responsibility, dignity and a reward for their hard work.

During our project week we decided to try and achieve the following goals:
<ol>
	<li>Organize activities outside the campus.
The activities that we took part in were not completely organized by us alone, as most of the work we did was in collaboration with other organizations. However we took initiative and made clear as to what and how we would be doing. For example when we volunteered at the homeless shelter. The work itself was not organized by us but we made contact and were willing to take part.</li>
	<li>Explore a new country and culture.
After we had completed our service and during our breaks we were able to converse with the local people whom we were working with. This allowed us to get an understanding of the culture from a primary source. Also, on our final night, we were hosted by a resident family. During our time there we learned much about the culture and history of that area. Not only did we chat with locals but we also made time for exploring the city and experience the area. We spent many hours walking the city and familiarizing ourselves with our environment</li>
	<li>Design and pursue a student-led project.
The trip and project were organized by ourselves in collaboration with the organization that we were assisting. Also, we lead ourselves during the project. At times working with the organization and at time our own work.</li>
	<li>Improve your organization, communication and collaboration skills.
Our trip was great organization experience as it allowed us to work without relying on an adult. Also our communication and collaboration between the group and with third parties improved. We were able to work together as a group without any mishaps or conflict.</li>
	<li>Get to know more about yourself and your group.
Together as a group we had an amazing time and learned much about each other. This was done late at night chatting but also during our service times and during planning. Even interacting with the third party people taught us something about how we interacted with people away from home and the UWC.</li>
	<li>Share and spread the UWC mission and values.
While doing our service we were often asked as to why we came and why we were helping. Dutifully we told them about the UWC and its mission. People responded positively to this and we’re excited that such a mission exists. People were also impressed that such student led initiatives existed.</li>
	<li>Achieve a positive (social) change.
The work we did helping at the homeless shelter created a more positive environment not only through helping with the labor, but also through encouragement and motivation.</li>
</ol>
<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Capture-6.png" rel="attachment wp-att-488"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-488 size-full" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Capture-6.png" alt="Capture" width="684" height="381" /></a>

[spacer height="20px"]We decided to join the project for a number of reasons. Firstly all of us were very interested in volunteering at the homeless shelter and interested to serve in any way that we could as at first it was shock that this issue existed in a scandinavian country. In addition this was a unique project, that none of us had never done. We were all extremely anxious to talk about our own beliefs and opinions to strangers but wanted to challenge ourselves, especially by going to another country.

[spacer height="20px"]Even after all this said one might still ask: ‘Still what made your PW so important? How did your PW even link to the UWC mission and values? Was it any use to go, really?’

[spacer height="20px"]In congruence with all the numerous, so-true points mentioned above, during our project week we also learned more about our Christian faith. This was really important to us for as students in the UWC community we would like to contribute to the diversity in faith by knowing more about our actual spiritual beliefs, so that we are able to share those ideas. In the UWC mission it states that we must strive to reach ‘the celebration of difference’, and by going on this project week we added more difference to be celebrated in our mainly secular school.

[spacer height="20px"]On our project week we did not only further establish Jesus’ love for us, what we also did was serve at a homeless shelter. The security guard on the first day told us to speak of the shelter to the public in discretion in order to avoid complaints from locals about how homeless people get everything for free from the government. This not only incorrect opinion in the case of the homeless shelter we worked at since they do pay a fee of 15 krona for a bed, a grooming packet, dinner and breakfast, is unfortunately the mentality some have towards those with no money. We didn’t even know that it wasn’t for free either but through this experience we got more informed and therefore less biased, which is also what UWC aims to instill in us.

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Capture-7.png" rel="attachment wp-att-489"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-489 size-full" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Capture-7.png" alt="Capture" width="649" height="833" /></a>

[spacer height="20px"]As a team we looked out for each other even if it just meant encouraging words on our long walks, making sure everybody woke up on time or attempting to relieving another’s blister pain through well- meant footwear advice. The project week was all great way to emulate the ‘mutual responsibility and respect’ part of the UWC mission statement. Furthermore, when making food for the homeless we had to be very hygienic and respectful by wearing gloves and washing our hands. It is often very easy to bend the rules and not care because no one would know so you wouldn't get caught but we practiced our integrity well and out of respect for the shelter seekers, we handled their food appropriately.

[spacer height="20px"]From the project week our friendships grew stronger, we got a taster of what being a responsible young adult is like in the ‘real world’ away from the protection of our safe, idealistically minded UWC community.

[spacer height="20px"]All this seems pretty worthwhile to us.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Serve The City Maastricht - Michal Steyn</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/03/20/serve-the-city-maastricht-michal-steyn/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 20 Mar 2016 22:35:15 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=495</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[On 21st October Michal Steyn, chairman and one of the founders of <a href="http://stcmaastricht.nl/en/">ServetheCity Maastricht</a> (STC), visited us during our YSE session to help us understand our host city better and make us think about our attitudes and actions towards our new community.

This software engineer from South Africa had earlier in his professional life joined a group of friends with their startup technology company iKubu, which eventually invested a micro radar system and was later acquired by an American company.

Michal moved to the USA in 2014, where he started his current software consultancy business. In 2015 he relocated with his family to Maastricht, where he divides his time between engineering and STC.

These are some of Michal's inspiring lines:

<em>"What if we got to know the members of our community by name and not by numbers and needs?</em>

<em>Each community has something to give and something to receive. Don't pity them, have compassion!</em>

<em>There are needs even in this room, walk around with new eyes, be aware of the problems around you.</em>

<em>Starting a business must be one of the most humanitarian actions you can do: feeding a family is entrepreneurship.</em>

<em>Keep in mind always the triple bottom line: social equity, economic, and environmental factors =&gt; PEOPLE, PLANET &amp; PROFIT.</em>

<em>Be playful and dream again, don´t let education ruin your creativity."</em>

Michal also talked about their current projects with the Refugee Centre in Maastricht.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Trayekt - Vincent Frenken</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/03/20/trayekt-vincent-frenken/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 20 Mar 2016 22:51:09 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=497</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[On 4th November, Vincent Frenken visited us to present a map of Maastricht and neighbouring communities in terms of social challenges faced especially by youth.

Vincent has worked for many years for Trayekt, the equivalent of the Social Services in NL, and he works mostly at night with youth in the streets: "lover boys", female prostitution, etc.

This was a shocking presentation for many of us since we were not aware of the dimension of these problems.

There's also a street culture by which some youth make up big stories of what they have done that aren´t always true.

Besides these issues, one of the biggest problems among youngsters and young families or single-headed-households in Maastricht is the level of indebtedness, which at times makes these people resort to illegal and/or criminal activities to make quick money.

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Belgian Blast - Ashoka Belgium</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/03/20/belgian-blast-ashoka-belgium/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 20 Mar 2016 23:20:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=499</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[On 20 November ten of our DP1 students taking part in the YSE Programme attended in Brussels a one day event organised by <a href="http://belgium.ashoka.org/splash">Ashoka Belgium</a>, in collaboration with their <a href="http://belgium.ashoka.org/nl/changemaker-scholen">8 Ashoka Changemaker Schools</a> and <a href="http://www.mobileschool.org/nl">Mobile School/Streetwize</a>. The BELGIAN BLAST brought teachers, other frontline educators and students together to boost the movement for innovation and change in education.

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

A summary of the event here: <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8Eh0rljK5fk">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8Eh0rljK5fk</a>]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Bert Jongen: &quot;Working with Passion&quot;</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/03/21/bert-jongen-working-with-passion/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 21 Mar 2016 00:05:05 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=502</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[On Monday 23rd November, Bert Jongen - a senior member of the local government, long-life advocate for the rights of people with disabilities and an expert in Social Entrepreneurship in the Limburg region - joined DP2 students for a chat within the UWCM YSE Hub.

Bert is the author of ‘<em>Werken met Passie. </em><em>SociaalOndernemen in the Praktijk</em>and’, a book about those entrepreneurs working with passion in the Netherlands and the main social enterprises in this country.
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/IMG_0639.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-503"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-503" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/IMG_0639-300x225.jpg" alt="IMG_0639" width="300" height="225" /></a></p>
Students refreshed their ideas about the key features of a social enterprise and learnt about social enterprises in the Limburg region.

<em>"A social enterprise must fulfill the 3Ps: People, Planet and Profit. Profit is not their goal but a tool to enable their social project, to make it sustainable. The money is used to cover the costs of the project."</em>

"A social enterprise is a way to work within the capitalist system to find solutions to problems. [...] It's about the intention behind the 'helping'...people and disabilities or other".

There's now specific law in NL and a certification for social enterprises.

There are 25 firms in NL specialised in employment opportunities for people with disabilities as there are only 1 in 4 chances of finding a job as a person with disability in NL.

Crowdfunding donors are a good idea to start financing your project, at least to cover costs.

The examples of Ben&amp;Jerry ice-cream and StreetwiZe were discussed by the group.

Bert highlighted the following as the main social problems in Maastricht at the moment:
<ul>
	<li>Unemployment</li>
	<li>Solitude of elderly people (above 50 yeas old)</li>
	<li>Youth with severe debt (several thousand euros)</li>
</ul>
There are no social enterprises at the municipal level but the local goverment sponsors 140 social organisations. For example, Trajekt receives 12 million euros per year to run projects.

Bert mentioned the big niche for UWC Maastricht students starting social entrepreneurial projects and pointed at the potential of a project to awaken the province about funds to help young people start social enterprises.

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Mind Your Business Maastricht</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/03/21/mind-your-business-maastricht/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 21 Mar 2016 00:10:28 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=505</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The weekend of 28th and 29th November, 20 students from the YSE programme (DP1 students)  and the UWCM YSE Hub (DP2 students) attended the event MYB Maastricht. A start-up weekend full of workshops, inspirational sessions, legal advice, business models, social entrepreneurship, networking, coaching and pitching.

An action-oriented event that offered participants a unique occasion to channel their creativity and talents. Hosted by Smile to the Future Foundation. Sponsored by Gemeente Maastricht, Maastricht University, Stichting Elisabeth Strouven and CODE043.

Our students constituted most of the attendees of this event. They can be seen in these photos and videos below:

<a href="http://mindyourbusinessmaastricht.com/">http://mindyourbusinessmaastricht.com/</a>

<a href="http://smiletothefuture.org/mind-your-business-exceeds-expectations/">http://smiletothefuture.org/mind-your-business-exceeds-expectations/</a>

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Limburg &amp; Co. Project</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/03/21/limburg-co-project/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 21 Mar 2016 00:12:33 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=507</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<u>Integrated activities and projects with local industry 2015-2016</u>
This is a programme initiated by the Province of Limburg with the goal of making connections between the provincial government, educational institutions in the province and the local industry. Students from UWC Maastricht joined two regional vocational schools to work on two case studies developed by two local companies.

&nbsp;

UWC Maastricht students were matched with the following two companies:

1.Smurfit Kappa (Roermond)
Smurfit Kappa is one of the world leading providers of paper-based packaging (44.000 employees worldwide). Together with the Cita Verde College in Roermond and Leeuwenborgh in Sittard, our students worked on a project where they depicted the actual working of circular economy for Smurfit Kappa. Students were asked to think of a purpose for some of the waste materials from Smurfit Kappa. How can they be developed into a product? Our students followed the process of research, lab work and design and presented that as part of their broader case study of how circular economy works in practice. They developed a sort of marketing of Smurfit Kappa’s sustainability management and <u>won the competition</u>.

2. Arion (Geleen)
A company producing innovative solutions for the healthcare market. Examples of their products are aids to pull on and off compression stockings and products that allow washing patients without water. Especially the last product group, the washing without water products, is growing enormously in the last couple of years. They therefore developed a research question for students to focus on.
<em>“How can Arion make use of cultural, anthropological, philosophical, and historical findings on washing in general in the countries where it is currently active (NL, BE, DE, DK, ES) and is going to be active (UK, FR, SE)?”</em>
The goals of the activity were:

- To provide students with an insight into the daily running of a business.

- To allow students to independently work on a real life case study.
-  For students to explore how innovation can be a force of positive change.
- To create a network between our school, other schools, businesses and the local

government.
UWC Maastricht will continue its participation in the project next academic year.

<strong><em> </em></strong>

<strong><em> </em></strong>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Visits to Social Enterprises in NL</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/03/21/visits-to-social-enterprises-in-nl/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 21 Mar 2016 00:17:15 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=509</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[On 3rd February 2016 our YSE students (almost 150) visited five social enterprises in Eindhoven, Utrecht and Amsterdam. This was an Offsite Education opportunity within the Youth Social Entrepreneurship Programme.

Students and YSE facilitators visited <a href="http://www2.thecolourkitchen.com/en">The Colour Kitchen</a> in Eindhoven, <a href="http://www.healthyentrepreneurs.nl/">Healthy Entrepreneurs</a> in Utrecht and the <a href="http://www.proportionfoundation.org/">ProPortion</a> Foundation, <a href="http://www.nudge-global-leadership-challenge.com/nudge/">Nudge</a> and <a href="http://www.social-enterprise.nl/">Social Enterprise NL</a> in Amsterdam.
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Group-Healthy-Entrepreneurs.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-510"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-510" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Group-Healthy-Entrepreneurs-300x225.jpg" alt="Group Healthy Entrepreneurs" width="300" height="225" /></a> <a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/ColourKitchen.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-511"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-511" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/ColourKitchen-300x149.jpg" alt="ColourKitchen" width="300" height="149" /></a></p>
Re-known social entrepreneurs such as Jan van Betten (Nudge), Maarten Neve (co-founder of Healthy Entrepreneurs) or Merel Rumping (this young social entrepreneur had pitched for Bill Gates the week before presenting her project <a href="http://www.proportionfoundation.org/legbank/">LegBank</a>, with Pro-Portion Foundation) welcomed UWC Maastricht students and proposed to them different challenges such as designing health products for under 1€ or creating a social media campaign.

&nbsp;

Over all, it was a very inspiring day for our students who also learnt more technical aspects such as the business model behind these enterprises that create a positive social impact, the challenges they face or the strategic importance of creating the right team for their projects.

&nbsp;

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>May&#039;16 - In Search of Impressionist Eyes - Paris</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/06/03/in-search-of-impressionist-eyes-paris-april-27/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 03 Jun 2016 17:46:47 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=523</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The project week ‘In Search of Impressionist Eyes’ was aimed to researching French impressionists in the 19th and 20th century in Paris. The Project had a particular focus on Claude Monet, who is often considered to be the father of impressionism. The reason for this project was to investigate how this group of people managed to change the art culture so drastically, and what difficulties they encountered along the way.

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/paris.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-524"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-524 size-full" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/paris.jpg" alt="paris" width="1000" height="667" /></a>

To start my project and introduce myself to Claude Monet, I went straight to the Marmottan museum. This museum has a permanent exposition dedicated to Monet and contains some of his artworks from various points in his life. This first experience was key to gathering my first impressions of the impressionist movement and Monet’s life, later on I frequently went back to add to the things I noticed on this first visit.
After the first introduction, I moved on to the D’Orsay museum. This second visit included many other impressionist artists of Monet’s time period who lived in France. Also, I was able to see some paintings from impressionists from other countries like Van Gogh, and was able to compare his artworks with the ones I had previously seen. It would be a great extension to this project week to research Van Gogh and Dutch impressionists to see the full impact that the French impressionists had and the differences between the two movements.

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/paris7.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-530"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-530 size-full" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/paris7.jpg" alt="paris7" width="640" height="480" /></a>

On the second day I visited the Louvre museum, with the objective of seeing the impressionist exhibition of artists in the late 19<sup>th</sup> century, and early 20<sup>th</sup> century. Unfortunately that particular exhibition was closed, along with a few others due to working strike. Even though this obstacle came along, I visited the museum to see the kinds of artistic movements that were present in the past and to get an idea of where exactly impressionism was shifting from

After the visit at the Louvre museum, I visited the Orangerie. A museum dedicated and built around Monet’s giant water lilies oil on canvases. The sight of these enormous paintings was breath taking for me, and it was possible for me to understand the severeness of Monet’s sight condition that had manifested towards the end of his life. Monet had to rely on creating enormous paintings since he could no longer see clearly up close.

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/paris2.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-525"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-525 size-full" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/paris2.jpg" alt="paris2" width="640" height="480" /></a>

&nbsp;

After seeing an overview of Monet’s painting life and the one of his painter friends, I went to visit the Renoir Gardens in the area of Mon Matre. This area of Paris was and still is known to be a common place where artists lived and met up. During the time I visited, the artists in the area were exposing their artworks in the streets. Experiencing the atmosphere in which Impressionist artists grew and lived was very enriching and mind opening; I had to note that it is important to be surrounded by a community that supports you and in which you feel comfortable to do what you believe in.

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/paris3.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-526"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-526 size-full" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/paris3.jpg" alt="paris3" width="640" height="480" /></a>

The very last day, to get the final glimpses at Monet’s life, I visited his house in Giverny, where he spent the last years of his life, and created his famous water lily oil on canvases. During these last years Monet’s eyesight worsened with the years, but every time he was able to find ways to improve it he would paint as much as he could to use the full potential of his temporary cure. Visiting his house gave me an insight into what kind of person he was, one that would not simply stop doing what he loved because of old age or other restrictions, he was also known to sit through the coldest and the hottest of days to paint his heart out on canvas before the moment he was trying to capture would disappear. I think the last visit to his house and gardens were a perfect closing to the project week, that left me reflecting on the visit long after it was over.

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/paris5.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-528"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-528 size-full" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/paris5.jpg" alt="paris5" width="1000" height="688" /></a> <a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/paris6.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-529"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-529 size-full" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/paris6.jpg" alt="paris6" width="1000" height="667" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>May&#039;16 - Denmark WWII Museum</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/06/03/denmark-daniel/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 03 Jun 2016 21:46:28 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=533</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">For my project week I had worked at Aalborgs Fosvars og Garnisons musuem, which is a museum about world war 2 in Denmark, where mostly volunteers worked. I had worked there for 4 days throughout the May break from 10:00am to 15:00pm each day. At first it was a new experience because I had never worked in Denmark before and to be honest was a bit nervous due to my lack of having spoken Danish in a long time. However it all went well once I got used to things. On the first day it was a bit awkward as they did not exactly have everything thought through and did not know what they wanted me to do. So on the first day I was set to clean and wash the cabinets and display cases that were there. This was not as boring as it actually sounds because I was able to listen to music and explore the events that had occurred throughout Denmark during World War 2. So it was also an educational project week for me. The second and third day I was set to vacuum the area and also clean again, once again getting a detailed look at things I could do. However on the third day I was able to get a free tour of the exhibits and learnt quite a lot. I was able to gain a better understanding of what they actually do and have there and made me glad to see that I am helping out. I was also able to spread a lot of information about UWC since they all were surprised as to me living in Holland and why I was doing service there. The people who were there were very generous. They said that I could take as many breaks as I wanted to and for lunch I could take a soda. They were also very interesting and had worked there for most of their life. On the fourth day I was putting price tags on the goods that they were selling which varied but also had the chance to fix some of the flash lights their which were broken. This was actually a really fun experience because I’ve always had a passion for being able to fix something which is supposed to be broken. I had fixed most of the flashlights although some were beyond fixing. When discussing the project week as a whole I think that it was a very fun experience and would advise other people to do it since it is simple, educational and a fun experience. However I would advise people to do it in a group as it can tend to get quite a bit lonely when doing it by yourself. If you are fond of history I would advise it. I really enjoyed myself and met new people, learnt new cleaning skills and speaking skills as well and social behavior as a whole. This project week was a generally good experience for me and the people I helped. </span>

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/Denmark.png" rel="attachment wp-att-534"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-534 size-full" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/Denmark.png" alt="Denmark" width="555" height="372" /></a> <a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/denmark2.png" rel="attachment wp-att-535"><img class="wp-image-535 size-full aligncenter" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/denmark2.png" alt="denmark2" width="662" height="439" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>May&#039;16 - Berlin Wall</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/06/03/berlin-wall/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 03 Jun 2016 22:03:30 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=537</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">We are a group of 6 girls: Chiara from Italy; Emi from Malaysia; Hana from Japan; Hellen from Eritrea and Sudan; Jana from Germany and Len from Myanmar. Our project was to investigate the social impact of the Berlin Wall. Throughout our project week we went to museums, got to know the city and had meaningful interviews with people on this issue. Due to the different backgrounds we are from, each one of us had different perspectives. We would sit and share our feelings each day, and it gave us the opportunity to reach a more complete understanding of our research.</span>

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/berlin2.png" rel="attachment wp-att-539"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-539 size-full" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/berlin2.png" alt="berlin2" width="664" height="441" /></a>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Day 1 : On the first day, we went to the Deutsches Historisches museum, where we learnt about Germany before and after the World Wars. The next museum is the DDR museum. We observed the impact of the Wall, the ruling parties, personal stories, and ideologies from both East and West Germany at that time by using both primary and secondary resources available there.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Day 2:  At the Deutsches Technik, we saw a wide variety of technologies that brought Germany to its current shape such as weaving machines, boats, planes and cars.  In the computer section, we learned that computer skills were developing in the US during the separation of Berlin, so we could imagine the more developed life in the West side than the East.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">The Jewish museum showed us the history of their people, culture and religion starting from when Jewish religion started.  However, it wasn’t only about the beautiful culture.  We also saw the friction between Germans due to the differences in their religion.  The unique atmosphere of the museum's architecture stimulated our imagination.  </span>

<strong><span style="font-weight: 400;">Day 3: We visited the East Side Gallery and the German Resistance Memorial. The East Side Gallery is a kilometer of the Berlin Wall where art pieces have been drawn. There were creative drawings depicting the political and social issues. We saw how the Berlin Wall looked like and how the two sides were separated. Then, we went to the German Resistance Memorial. This was a memorial about the Berlin Wall and included stories of the people that lived at that time and their attempts of crossing the wall. Some succeeded and others were killed while trying to cross the wall. Around 138 people were killed trying to cross from the East to the West. They crossed because life was easier and there was more freedom in the west than in the East.</span></strong>

Day 4: We conducted interviews with some locals and tourists on their knowledge and views about the Wall. We decided to go to the Tiergarten Park and approach people to ask questions. Some of the questions were:
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">What are your views on the Berlin Wall?</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Were you taught anything about the Berlin Wall when you were still in school? If so, what information were you given?</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Do you see any difference between the East and West Berlin today?</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Do you still feel the effects of the Wall today?</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Some people still feel that the Wall should be present today, what do you think</span></li>
</ul>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">We have interviewed around 15 people in the park, and found some very interesting views and perspective. We asked whether they feel that the wall should still exist, we got very different answers where some people were against it, while some people felt that the wall could also be beneficial in terms of jobs, standard of living etc, as the people are taken care by the government.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Through this project, we were able to learn about the history of the Wall and the separation of Berlin. We learned greatly about the impact this had on society. With two very different government systems in East and West, people were treated very differently. People were separated from each other for 28 years. A whole generation of people developing very different political ideologies, beliefs and attitudes, as all east-west relations had been forcibly terminated. The consequences of this political and social division have left their marks on society to this day.  It was very interesting to see and hear first-hand the impact this had on the Berlin society through conducting interviews with people on different ages and visiting memorial sites and museums, which enabled us to experience the issue in a much more authentic way.</span>

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/berlin.png" rel="attachment wp-att-538"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-538 size-full" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/berlin.png" alt="berlin" width="662" height="374" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>537</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2016-06-03 22:03:30]]></wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2016-06-03 22:03:30]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[berlin-wall]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="project-week"><![CDATA[Project Week]]></category>

			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_edit_last]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>

	<item>
		<title>May&#039;16 - Project Week in Kosovo</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/06/03/may-2016-project-week-in-kosovo/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 03 Jun 2016 22:21:21 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=542</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<b>What did we do?</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">For our project week, we decided to explore the country that suffered massacres and war crimes not longer than one and a half decades ago. Not only did the numerous colonizations and invasions in history have an impact on the country’s later developments, but up to this day it is still not internationally recognised as an independent country where the inhabitants still have to bear the ongoing conflicts between itself and its bordering countries. Our team was: Diona (Kosovo), Alon (Israel), JV (Philippines), Victoria (Bolivia), and Lorenzo (French/Italian). We all decided to choose Kosovo as the destination, precisely because of this historical background, which fascinated us. It was a really long trip to get there, we left early on April 28th and arrived to Pristina (Kosovo’s capital) by dawn next morning.  We volunteered with an NGO called “The Ideas Partnership” is a quite new organization founded by young kosovars, and what they do is that they gather volunteers to tackle education, promoting the preservation of cultural heritage and facing environmental challenges in Kosovo and the region, without political or religious affiliation.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">On the first day, we went Janjeva, a small town hiding in hills somewhere in the centre of Kosovo. Janjeva is a place whose unusually diverse cultural history can still be heard in the different languages spoken in its winding dusty streets, and in the wood, plaster and stone of the buildings. There, along with other volunteers, we prepared creativity classes for 2 different groups of children, guiding them through their drawings. It was a bit difficult to communicate with them, as only Diona spoke the language, but nevertheless, their warm spirit allowed is in the end, to make this sharing a memorable experience. We did this 2 other times, as well as English lessons.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">The Ideas Partnership doesn’t work on Sundays nor Labor Day, as the children attend to this extra learning opportunities right after their normal school hours, so in these two days we went a bit farther, and took a day off to Diona’s hometown Gjakova, were we walked around, met friends and family, and visited a post-war memorial of the victims. Once we got back to action, we went to Fushë Kosova, which is another section of the NGO’s program. Fushë Kosova is perhaps five miles away from the centre of Pristina. Families there are trying to live in single rooms on 60 hours a month, each and one of them with different and sadder stories; children who don’t go to school because they lack shoes and proper clothes, children who have limited access to basic education, etc. The employment of the majority is going through bins for scrap metal to sell for a few cents, and children begging in the streets. There we took lead of the English classes and the reading program. We were separated in different groups which were divided by age and proficiency in English, but these activities were only present in of the days. During the last day we took part of the creativity day, where we shared facts and legends of our own cultures, and learned about theirs. This last one, was very successful and one could see the joy around everybody, specially when they had to guess our countries and got it right (only once). Fushë Kosova also supports the Changemakers, which is a group of community members who want to improve their community themselves by organizing clean-up campaigns, and even took initiative in the creation of a kindergarten. The Changemakers group was specifically interesting to see, as a until-now-successful social entrepreneurship project.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Once our service days came to an end, we took those last 2 days to travel a bit more. We went to Prizren, an astonishingly beautiful old city, with a huge influence from the Ottoman Empire. We visited the fortress, hiked a bit, ate delicious traditional dishes. All team members agreed that our stay in Prizren was very relaxing, and brought us more together as a group. On the last day, we went to Gjakova again, and did some for walking. That same night, we took a taxi to Skopje  (Macedonia), catched our plane to Charleroi and returned to campus. It was a really nice experience that all of us will remember for a long time.</span>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">PW Quote: “omg! This is so cheap!”</span>

[gallery size="large" ids="543,544,547,548,549,550,551,546,545"]]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>May&#039;16 - Win Bin Maastricht</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/06/03/may16-win-bin-maastricht/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 03 Jun 2016 22:32:16 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=553</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This past May break, the WinBin project week team set about on their project of bringing about positive environmental change, one bin at a time. Colin, Daan, Martijn, Tom, Cato, Elias and I (Ofek) were all motivated and excited to start this short week of building and creating recycling bins to be placed around the school. The idea behind WinBin was for us to plan and initiate our own project week of making bins after we realized there was a distinct lack of places within school where recyclable trash could be thrown away. We were all aware of the global importance of recycling, and were determined to do our bit on the fight against global warming. After recognizing this issue within the school community, we set about to try and change it by implementing Colin’s “green bin” idea from last year all around the school. Colin had designed and made a recycling bin during a Design Technology class last year, and we were planning on using its design during our Project week. Before the May break, we all consistently met and came together to discuss what exactly our action plan would be, as we wanted to ensure we made full use of the time we had. During these meetings, and after much discussion and collaborative work, we created the following vague action plan for us to follow.

<strong>Day 1:</strong> Spend most of the day going to GAMMA and selecting/finding wood. After this is completed will return to school and spend the rest of the day cutting everything down to the correct dimensions. Goal of day: Get all pieces ready for assembly tomorrow.
<strong>Day 2:</strong> We will start assembling the first bin today. This will probably take till about lunch. Afterwards we will apply the first (base) layer of paint to bin, so that we can divide roles tomorrow.

<strong>Day 3:</strong> Apply first layer of colour paint to the bin. While this dries we will start construction and assembly of both the second and third bin.
<strong>Day 4:</strong> Apply second layer of paint to first bin, and base layer to bins 2 and 3. Complete construction of the two remaining bins and alternate between applying paint layers. Additionally, file down all the bins and wood to be smooth before display. Clean-up all the mess.
In reality we were able to follow this plan somewhat, though at times we slightly deviated from it. This was the first time many of us were creating and designing something of this scale, and as such it took a while for us to fully develop and learn the necessary skills. Also, by bins 2 and 3 we were able to learn from mistakes made in the construction of bin 1, allowing for us to complete them quicker than expected.

Overall, we all learned valuable lessons from this project week experience, ranging from practical skills to lessons on the importance recycling. We were all able to enjoy this week, and are all extremely proud of the end result. We really think these bins will bring about positive change to the school, and are excited to see them in use.
- WinBin team 2016

[gallery size="medium" ids="568,567,566,565,564,562"]

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>June&#039;16 - Refugee welcome guide</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/06/27/june16-refugee-welcome-guide/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 27 Jun 2016 06:59:23 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=584</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[During the June Project Week our team has been working on the Refugee welcome guide. The Guide has been created in order to help the refugees in finding the cheapest places in town. The first day we met two women from the refugee camp, where they shared with us their first experiences and how difficult it has been for them to find their way in shops with affordable prices.

<img class="aligncenter wp-image-585 size-large" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/13499801_10209795966801884_753748227_o-768x1024.jpg" alt="13499801_10209795966801884_753748227_o" width="700" height="933" />

We understood that there was a genuine need for our project when one of the women told us that she had been starving for two days in a raw because she was not able to guide herself in the city. With the guidance of our supervisors we created some forms that consisted of the goods that the refugees need. We included the prices and the description of the goods and also detailed directions of how to reach the shop from the refugee center. After that, we visited the shops and filled in the forms. We managed to collect a significantly big amount of data that will be included in the guide.Finally we met a group of university students that introduced us to their initiative web platform where refuges can find guidance in many areas such as healthcare and shopping.

<img class="aligncenter wp-image-586 size-large" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/13509764_10209795966961888_1434780437_o-1024x768.jpg" alt="13509764_10209795966961888_1434780437_o" width="700" height="525" />

They invited us to upload the information that we have collected in the area of shopping so that more refugees have access into it. Although the project did not work as we expected due to some complications in communication and organization inside our group and with our contacts, we discovered in which areas we should improve and now we all feel more prepared and experienced for our next project. Our project is strongly interrelated with the UWC values and missions as each member of the group experienced a personal challenge, there was celebration of difference and intercultural understanding and we tried to be as environmentally sustainable as possible.

<img class="aligncenter wp-image-587 size-large" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/image1-1-1024x768.jpg" alt="image1 (1)" width="700" height="525" />

-By Sofia Iris Kormpaki, Veronica Bejm Franco, Mesut Caliskan, Jacob Elton, Len Tha Lang, Dechen Zangmo, Cami Lindo, Oumaima Rhalem]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>May&#039;16 Palestine</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/05/15/may16-palestine/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 15 May 2016 13:04:15 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=620</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/nuclear.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-621"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-621" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/nuclear.jpg" alt="nuclear" width="1052" height="790" /></a>

I wouldn’t say going to Palestine has particularly ever been on my bucket list, nor did I ever stop to think that it would be possible to travel such a ‘conflict area’. Growing up in an Arab (Moroccan) family, the Israeli-Palestinian conflict has always been quite present in my life, either on the news or in discussions during family events. This has, unsurprisingly, made me very biased in favor of Palestine.  The also biased Western media coverage of the conflict has led to many people viewing Palestine as a country in perpetual conflict and war, full of Hamas terrorists throwing rocks and stabbing civilians. So when Hannah once was telling me about her friend Obada who lived in Palestine and who she would love to visit in the future, I wasn’t very serious when I proposed to go during May break. Hannah (Netherlands), on the other hand, was already excited and after I asked my parents, who very surprisingly were much easier to convince than I could have ever expected, it was pretty much a set deal (although convincing the school was a bit more difficult). Isabella (Canada) and Asbjorn (Denmark) joined us, and after a few weeks packed with intense preparations (airport-interrogations simulations and a risk assessment of 20 pages long), I promised my parents a few dozen times to be very careful and we boarded on our flight to Israel.

Tel Aviv welcomed us with open arms, a dust storm and 36 degrees Celsius.  When we arrived at the airport, we were all quite nervous as we had heard stories about people being denied entry to Israel for ridiculous reasons such as seeming to be a political activist or having an Arab-sounding last name. The passport control went easier than we expected, although they were a bit hesitant with me, asking me questions about my family’s background and if I had any acquaintance in Palestine. That same night we were staying over at Hila’s place, one of Asbjorn’s childhood friends. They were very shocked to hear that we came to visit the West Bank rather than the usual Israeli tourist attractions.

We had an interesting discussion at 4.30 am in their kitchen while eating hummus with crackers (“Actually it’s Passover and they’re not selling bread in the stores.. But we’re not religious so we stocked in some bread last week”). When we were heading off to Jerusalem the following morning, Hila’s mother saw the title of our tour guide (titled ‘Israel and the Palestinian territories), and all of a sudden she got very upset, claiming that ‘the title gave the illusion that there was such a thing as Palestine’. She then went on to explain the case for the Israelis, stating that this was the only place they had in the world, and if they lost the war, they had nowhere to go whereas there ‘were so many Arab countries for them to go to’. Hila’s mom then said how ‘they’ (it was always ‘they’ or ‘those Arabs’, never ‘Palestinians’) didn’t want peace, how they educated their children to be terrorists and praised violence. As we didn’t quite know how to start arguing with such deep-rooted beliefs in front of an airport, we decided to just nod and leave it to what it was.<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/nuclear2.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-622"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-622" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/nuclear2.jpg" alt="nuclear2" width="760" height="571" /></a> <a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/nuclear3.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-623"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-623" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/nuclear3.jpg" alt="nuclear3" width="750" height="563" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>620</wp:post_id>

		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2016-05-15 13:04:15]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[may16-palestine]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>

	<item>
		<title>June&#039;16 - Student Handbook</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/06/27/june16-student-handbook/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 27 Jun 2016 11:46:39 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=589</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Our Project Week was to continue with the idea of the Student Handbook that was started last year by two past students. Last year this handbook was really helpful for new students to have all the most important information in one place, although there were some flaws in the book. So our idea was to create another Student Handbook in a new format that will be applicable for all students with different levels of English. Also another problem that we have discovered with the previous handbook was that it was given only to the residential students, leaving day students with no information. That’s why in our booklet we covered topics that are related to residential students but also some for day students, so they will also find this handbook useful next year.</span>

<img class="aligncenter wp-image-590 size-full" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/student-booklet.png" alt="student booklet" width="782" height="438" />

<span style="font-weight: 400;">During this four days we managed to create new Student Handbook. We divided work between the four of us, so each person was responsible for different part of the student handbook. Before we started writing we did a little research to see what other students thought about the last years handbook, what was good and what would that change. Based on that we did an outline of our student handbook and then we were just writing. We met regularly to check each other progress and finally put everything we got together to create a completely new Student Handbook.
Our Project Week for sure relates to the UWC value <b>Compassion and Service, because we created something for our school that hopefully will be useful next year for new students.

<span style="font-weight: 400;">by Jeremiah, Clara, Wiktoria &amp; Michalina</span>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>June&#039;16 - Takecarebnb --&gt; Kinderboerderij De Heeg</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/06/27/592/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 27 Jun 2016 11:51:59 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=592</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[It all started with takecarebnb, an organization based in Amsterdam that helped refugees to find local host families. We were all excited to work with them until we found out one day before that there had been a huge miscommunication with them since the early start of the collaboration with them. We were all worried about what was going on. Since it was very late we did not have many options to choose from so the only option possible was the animal farm. Some of us were not so enthusiastic because of the fear of being around animals, however we were determined to accomplish the project week so we undertook the challenge.

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/animal-farm.png" rel="attachment wp-att-593"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-593 size-full" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/animal-farm.png" alt="animal farm" width="601" height="359" /></a>

The first day was quite hard physical work cutting tree branches and transporting them and by the end of the day we were all very tired. Also we realized that we needed to communicate more effectively with the owners and workers in the farm when we wanted to share our feelings about a certain task given to us. On the second day the temperatures were quite high and for some of us that were fasting this proved to be very challenging. The task on the second day was cutting grass and cleaning the goat barn and the inside of the main facility. By the third day all of us got more used to the kind of work done in the farm so for all of us it felt easier. It is certain that for all the of us it was not the most enjoyable way we could have spent three days and not the ideal project week but there was need for that work to be done and we did learn a lot throughout the process. We learned about efficient communication, how to work better as a group, punctuality, perseverance.

by Gisela, Sophie, Holly, Helen, Nina, Nelson and Omnia]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>June&#039;16 - Introduction week Prep team</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/06/28/june16-introduction-week-prep-team/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 28 Jun 2016 06:10:44 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=598</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div>~~</div>
<div>In our project week we worked on the planning of the 2016 introduction week for the new DP1s. This includes planning activities and events, establishing clear communication with staff members and tutors and making student participation the best it can be. Yet our main aim was to make sure everyone has a chance to participate and feel welcome. Having members from both the day and residential community, we were able to get different inputs in the planning so that it suits as many people as possible. Even though last year there was also an introduction week team, not as a project week though, there were multiple aspects and events that could have been organised and communicated better, which is what we worked hard on changing. There was a genuine need for this project week as the time given for us to work in a team resulted in what we believe will be a successful and fun first two weeks of school, which will hopefully show the new DP1s the welcoming atmosphere UWCM has to offer as well as connect DP1 and DP2 as well as day and residential students. We really enjoyed working together and we are ready for our new firsties!</div>
<div></div>
<div>by Japhlet, Juul, Dominique, Valeria, Lotte, Melih, Aya, Ane, Akke and Tamar - Intro Week Team</div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>598</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2016-06-28 06:10:44]]></wp:post_date>
