	<item>
		<title>June&#039;16 - Writing support group</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/06/28/june16-writing-support-group/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 28 Jun 2016 06:16:16 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=600</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[For the past 4 days, our group had an intensive yet super fun time learning different writing techniques to help people next year.

To be honest, at first I doubted my abilities in writing. Coming to UWC and taking up IB was challenging for me in terms of having so many essay-based subjects. Yet after workshops with Larissa and Johannes, I realize I am very privileged to be able to speak English fluently and convey my intended message with ease. This project week is basically preparing us to set up a writing support team.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-627" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/File_001.jpeg" alt="File_001" width="3264" height="2448" />

Why did this all start? Well, in our community, we have quite diverse English levels. We have a very wide range of English speakers, ranging from native speakers to people who have never spoken a word of English until 1 month before they come. Since at UWCM, we do the IB in English. From what we see from our friends and peers to our very personal experience, we feel that there is not enough support for writing in general, especially when IB is such an ‘essay based’ curriculum. Hopefully, after this intensive kind of short course, we can establish a writing support team to help students with any kind of problem with writing in any subjects.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-628" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/File_006.jpeg" alt="File_006" width="3264" height="2448" />

Throughout the course of the project week, I myself took a lot away from what Larissa and Johannes presented. Larissa focussed on the technical parts for writing an essay especially for English A students, while Johannes highlighted the needs of students who take English acquisition. In order for the support group to work, we really have to cater for needs of different individuals, exploring the differences between a native speaker and a non-native and how to approach them were particularly useful. It is also very important to be empathetic. We’ve all been through different struggles on our road of learning, we want them to feel safe and positive when coming to us, it id only by them feeling safe to share their work then we can all learn and improve.

<img class="aligncenter size-large wp-image-629" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/File_008-1024x768.jpeg" alt="File_008" width="700" height="525" />

All in all, it was a very fruitful and intensive project week. I hope we could all make the writing support a reality next year!

It will be all WRITE!

Written by Melody Lam.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>June&#039;16 - Bike repair group</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/06/28/june16-bike-repair-group/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 28 Jun 2016 06:23:49 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=602</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[During our project we spend our time repairing the residential/school bicycles. This would benefit the school community due to the fact that students arriving next school year for DP1 will have transport to for example the city of Maastricht. This will also benefit the soon to be DP2’s because over the course of the year they might have run in to some problems with their bicycle which we repaired so that they can also have a fresh start at the beginning of the next school year, Transport wise. What we’ve accomplished during this project week is that we tried our at most to repair the damaged/nonworking bicycles. This means: Replacing the inner tube, gluing the inner tube, oiling the chain + breaks, filling up the tires, reattaching breaks, wheels, locks, fenders etc. As we are not bicycle experts we lacked some knowledge thus the fact being we were also giving a limited amount of tools and funding to fully repair the residential bicycle. For example on some bicycles the wheel was bend which means that the bicycle did not function. We would have to purchase an entire new wheel in order to fix this problem. A very common issue we ran into was that more then 1/3 of the bicycles had missing keys meaning that the level of repairing on those specific bicycles was very limited. We could only tire pressure and if all the parts were firm.

<img class="aligncenter wp-image-603 size-full" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/bike1.png" alt="bike1" width="712" height="283" />

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/bike2.png" rel="attachment wp-att-604"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-604 size-full" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/bike2.png" alt="bike2" width="708" height="311" /></a>

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/bike3.png" rel="attachment wp-att-605"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-605 size-full" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/bike3.png" alt="bike3" width="714" height="311" /></a>

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/bike4.png" rel="attachment wp-att-606"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-606 size-full" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/bike4.png" alt="bike4" width="711" height="312" /></a>

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/bike5.png" rel="attachment wp-att-607"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-607 size-full" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/bike5.png" alt="bike5" width="710" height="312" /></a>

Overall it was a good experience and our project has shown a clear link between the mission and the values of UWC. By creating safer and better transport for the students we also created more learning opportunities. Also by improving the school owned bicycles we can promote the use of this way of environmentally friendly transport. Everyone got along and got treated with patience and respect. Therefore we learned to cooperate with each other. It was of course also a personal challenge for everyone on the team because not everyone was as well known with bicycles as the other. In conclusion taking the lack of tools and other items such as keys and spare parts into consideration it was quite successful.

&nbsp;

By Tristan]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>June&#039;16 - The nuclear reactor Tihange in Belgium</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/06/28/june16-the-nuclear-reactor-tihange-in-belgium/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 28 Jun 2016 11:21:12 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=611</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Maastricht is only 50km away from the nuclear reactor Tihange located in Belgium. Pressurized water reactors such as Tihange are built to have a lifespan of 30 to 40 years, which means that Tihange should have been shut down in 2012. This however did not happen, its lifespan was even extended to 2025. When there is a serious problem or some kind of damage, the reactor shuts down automatically. Over the past two year it has happened hundreds of times and every single time the Belgian government has re-started it  manually. If there is a core meltdown accident, we could face similar consequences as we have experienced with Chernobyl and Fukushima. Carolin and I found that no one in school is informed about this local issue and decided that we want to raise awareness. Our aim is to inform people in order to avoid panic if something should happen, since that would create a disastrous chaos.  We have created power point presentation and will be printing leaflets that we want to share with the school community next school year. This will give people a detailed overview of  what exactly the issue is, what they should prepare for and how to act in a worst case scenario. We will offer people to come talk to us if they should have any further concerns or are unsure. </span>

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/tih1.png" rel="attachment wp-att-612"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-612" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/tih1.png" alt="tih1" width="769" height="575" /></a> <a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/tih2.png" rel="attachment wp-att-613"><img class="wp-image-613 size-full aligncenter" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/tih2.png" alt="tih2" width="742" height="491" /></a> <a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/tih4.png" rel="attachment wp-att-615"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-615 size-full" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/tih4.png" alt="tih4" width="451" height="602" /></a>

&nbsp;

Our PW links to the UWC mission and values in several ways. The UWC mission states “UWC makes education a force to unite people, nations and cultures for peace and <b>a sustainable future</b>”. Sustainability plays a major role in this project, since we have to invest in sustainable energy resources rather than for example nuclear energy, that carries too many risks when not operated correctly. Looking at the nine values, a few stand out: “Mutual responsibility and respect”, “Respect for the environment” and ”Action and personal example”. These apply to our PW as it is our mutual responsibility to consider and act upon these issues as it can only be resolved when people work together and find solutions. Respect for the environment it very obvious as the environment would majorly suffer under a core meltdown. Action is needed in the resolution of this issue and Carolin and I have taken part in the demonstration (personal example) and are planning on signing the petition  (min. Age 18). Thus, all three values apply.

&nbsp;

<img class="aligncenter wp-image-614 size-full" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/tih3.png" alt="tih3" width="743" height="563" />]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>June&#039;16 - Happiness Project</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/06/28/june16-happiness-project/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 28 Jun 2016 13:12:03 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=625</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Our project aims to act as a start up to the Happiness Club to be organised in school next year. The project will serve as a trial period for us to try out different events and activities and also a chance to implement our ideas. We would also used this project week opportunity to interview people about their thoughts on happiness and the significance of this. We felt that there was a genuine need as we believe that happiness is something simple and beautiful, yet our busy schedules in this boarding and school environment often makes us feel unhappy and forget the importance of being happy and to think positively. And so, the project week and the club aims to promote happiness to the school community (MYP, primary, DP and staff members) through various activities, sessions etc. This project week also gives us time to plan our year schedule for next year’s club.

We spent our first day filming the happiness documentary and also planning the MYP session. The second day, we have successfully conducted three MYP sessions (more than planned, MYP 1,2, and 3) during June 23. The focus topic of the day was gratitude, and how by appreciating others we can make others and also ourselves happy. The workshop was our greatest accomplishments as we felt that we were able to get across our message well, and it was interesting to see the different reaction of the activity from the different age groups. The MYP1s, we felt had the most fun, where some of the MYP2s and 3s got emotional during the focus activity, which was very touching and interesting to observe. We also decided to do more of these sessions but with different focus topics to more MYPs, primary, DPs and staff members next year, as we got feedback from the MYPs that they wished they had sessions like this during tutor period. The last 2 days were used to finish the documentary and also planning for next year’s club structure.

In this project week, we linked the UWC value of Personal Challenge, as we felt that happiness is simple, but difficult to always be positive, hence it is important to challenge ourselves to see the bright side of what we face in life, and to look deeper and around us to realize the happiness around us and to embrace it. We believe that in order to change the world, we have to change ourselves first! Also, Mutual understanding, as we had to adapt to different age groups for the MYP sessions. And a sense of idealism, for the idea of happiness!

&nbsp;

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>June&#039;16 - Map of Maastricht for new students</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/06/28/june16-map-of-maastricht-for-new-students/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 28 Jun 2016 22:00:35 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=635</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">In our project week we created a map of Maastricht for the DP1s coming in the fall. The map comes in the form of a pamphlet which also contains useful information to the students which are unfamiliar to the city. Our group was made up of three students, two of which are day students and one is a former day student. This allowed us to use a lot of our past knowledge of the city to come up with ideas for the map.</span>

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/jv3.png" rel="attachment wp-att-636"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-636" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/jv3.png" alt="jv3" width="550" height="308" /></a>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">In the picture above,  the final version of the map can be seen. This is the main accomplishment of our project week because we had to make a concrete product. It required a lot of planning, and evaluation of what the students required in the map. In order to know what the students needed, we talked to residential students about what they felt in need of. We also had to gather a lot of information on the internet about restaurants, stores, day activities etc. which we included on the other page. However, we had to leave out a lot of information because we felt that it was not vital and we did not have a lot of space. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">While thinking about a possible project week our group was brainstorming what students in our school needed. Last year there was a handbook given out to the students which included a map. Looking at the map, we saw that it could be taken much further and was very lackluster. Therefore we proposed to make a map of Maastricht accompanied by information which could be folded into a pamphlet, so that students can easily carry them. They will be provided to the students by including them in the student hand books created by another project week.</span>

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/jv2.png" rel="attachment wp-att-638"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-638" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/jv2.png" alt="jv2" width="591" height="335" /></a>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Making our project week required us to have a deeper understanding of students needs with regards to their background and culture. Not only did we have to take into account the student's needs, but also the environment’s. We made sure to not print more paper than we needed. Since there was little to no supervision of the project week we had to keep ourselves in check throughout the four days. We made sure to take the same breaks as normal days as much as possible so that we did not waste too much time. Overall it was a nice project week with a lot of memorable experiences and fun :)</span>

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/jv.png" rel="attachment wp-att-637"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-637" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/jv.png" alt="jv" width="579" height="321" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>June&#039;16 - Art Exploration</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/06/28/june16-art-exploration/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 28 Jun 2016 22:04:29 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=640</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">During this past week, we have been working on a mural project for the school campus. Our plan was to make a piece of art that was made by the students for the school community. This way we would be celebrating the different cultures of our students whilst creating a colourful and interesting artwork to brighten up the campus.</span>

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/artp2.png" rel="attachment wp-att-642"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-642" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/artp2.png" alt="artp2" width="491" height="363" /></a>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">We wanted this to be a whole school project (ideally with primary and MYP getting involved with the painting) so we asked and used ideas from the staff and students. On the first day we met with students from MYP 2 and, using their different cultural backgrounds, created a list of monuments from around the globe. We then went on to designing, drawing and beginning to paint the final mural. Although we haven’t completely finished the mural, we have made good progress and plan to finish the rest when we return from the summer break.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">The purpose of the mural was to visually represent the idea of global peace and intercultural  understanding by joining monuments from many cultures - showing how we are a united community. Once finished, we are planning to attach the board along the wall going into the bike sheds. This way students, parents and visitors will be able to experience it when entering the campus.

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/artp.png" rel="attachment wp-att-641"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-641" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/artp.png" alt="artp" width="740" height="367" /></a>

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>640</wp:post_id>

		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:ping_status>

		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>

		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>June&#039;16 - The Journey</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/06/28/june16-the-journey/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 28 Jun 2016 22:12:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=644</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The Journey Project Maastricht is an initiative designed by UWCM students for the YSE Programme and has since developed into a full June Project Week. It started when the founding students realized that there was a lack of communication and socialization between local Dutch people and the refugees that were in the area, primarily the ones living at the nearby Aziel Zoekers Centrum. Since this led to many misconceptions and negative sentiments, they realized that there was a need to improve this and the result was The Journey, a magazine or book intended to share the stories of refugees at the AZC accompanied by creative pieces done by the refugees themselves. This promotes deeper understanding between people from different cultures now living together and encourages them to treat one another with respect and compassion. As we hope to continue issuing the Journey into the future, we hope that it will improve peaceful intercultural understanding between the two groups both in the present and sustainably into the future.

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/thejourney.png" rel="attachment wp-att-646"><img class="size-full wp-image-646 aligncenter" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/thejourney.png" alt="thejourney" width="322" height="423" /></a> <a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/thejourney2.png" rel="attachment wp-att-647"><img class="size-full wp-image-647 alignright" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/thejourney2.png" alt="thejourney2" width="420" height="308" /></a> <a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/thejourney3.png" rel="attachment wp-att-648"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-648" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/thejourney3.png" alt="thejourney3" width="327" height="436" /></a>

Throughout our project week we worked with the refugees to start our process of creating a magazine. Our group created flyers to get our project known to the refugees. Many refugees were interested in meeting with us and collaborating on making this magazine. We held interviews with various refugees from different countries and each had a different unique story to tell. This is very benefitting for our magazine as we want our readers to get to know the situations of these refugees and to understand their situation better. After conducting these interviews we wrote them up in a style of a story so that our readers would be more engaged with the stories. To promote the magazine we made a website and a facebook page. We also worked with a local organisation who distribute items to refugees to make their lives more comfortable. This was very successful and the organisation was grateful for our help. Our project week overall was very successful and we enjoyed working with the refugees.

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/thejourney4.png" rel="attachment wp-att-645"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-645" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/thejourney4.png" alt="thejourney4" width="428" height="286" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>June&#039;16 - Peer support training</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/06/28/june16-peer-support-training/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 28 Jun 2016 22:18:31 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=650</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Our project consisted of a peer-support training programme. Peer supporters are a group of students that other students can approach and talk to without a fear of being judged or gossiped about. We believe that everyone in the UWC community needs someone to talk to without worrying about these things.This is because of the huge amount of stress in the DP programme and also for many people the great change faced when joining this school. This largely impacts the psychological well-being of the students and the peer supporters can help relieve that stress or deal with it.</span>

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/20160623_112242.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-651"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-651" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/20160623_112242.jpg" alt="20160623_112242" width="3264" height="1836" /></a>

Throughout the project week we bonded as a group, we achieved this through different off campus activities (such as yoga and hiking) as well as cooking and eating as a group. The training sessions took place in the mornings of Wednesday. Thursday and Friday, and the afternoon of Monday. In those we acquired theoretical knowledge and we got to practice it with each other while preparing to become peer supporters the whole of the community next year. While reflecting on the project week activities we recognised how we came across many values. At first, empathy and understanding are a key element of peer support as they allow us to see facts from the other person’s point of view, helping us to listen in an objective manner and to create a non-judgemental environment.

Personal responsibility and integrity - each of the peer-supporters has the responsibility of keeping the information the other person tells them confidential unless they or the people around them are at risk of harm. Integrity is necessary because it is important that we as peer-supporters don’t lose our individuality because one of our main features is being peers because we are members of the same community collaborating to make it a happier place. Mutual responsibility and respect is therefore also important because of the peer aspect, neither of them are superior to the other.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-653" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/20160627_093436.jpg" alt="20160627_093436" width="1280" height="720" />

<span style="font-weight: 400;">We will dedicate time to provide this service to our community and through compassion we will be able to achieve empathy and understanding.</span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">We challenged ourselves to learning new skills and at times going out of our comfort zone by opening ourselves up to our fellow peer supporters while practicing.</span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Action and personal example - we think that our action will not only be directly positive for the community but an example for our peers to feel more comfortable in opening themselves.</span>

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/20160627_093436.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-653">
</a> <a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/20160627_0933130.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-652"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-652" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/20160627_0933130.jpg" alt="20160627_093313(0)" width="3264" height="1836" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>650</wp:post_id>

	<item>
		<title>June&#039;16 - English Childcare</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/06/28/june16-english-childcare/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 28 Jun 2016 22:22:28 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=655</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Why was there a genuine need for the PW?</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">English Childcare opened very recently and as a newborn daycare, they needed a lot of equipment and infrastructure in order to have an optimal environment for the kids. We thought that it was a good and constructive idea to help them build the equipment they needed, especially when the growth of kids of different range of years is in play. Furthermore, the Childcare has financial limits as well and they need to reconstruct and redesign the interior and exterior of the host house, prioritizing matters of higher importance and taking care of them through financial means. </span>We were able to learn many new skills through completing many tasks, such as building baby cribs, building an entire garden for vegetables out of nothing, sandpits, did a football court and redefined the aesthetics of a garden maze. Furthermore, we learnt how to deal with kids of many ages and especially many personalities. We have also bound with the staff of English Childcare, because they were very open to us and chose tasks adapted to our needs and limits.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-656" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/child.png" alt="child" width="702" height="524" />

Our project week links with the UWC mission mainly in these points: international and intercultural understanding, as the range of nationalities of the kids is very ample and come from different cultural backgrounds (most of them come from UWC primary section). Personal responsibility and integrity, as taking care and work for a daycare is a huge responsibility as the safety of kids is the focus. Compassion and service is of central importance because our work there is unpaid and without any second aims; just helping some people in need.

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/child.png" rel="attachment wp-att-656">
</a> <a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/child1.png" rel="attachment wp-att-657"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-657" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/child1.png" alt="child1" width="708" height="531" /></a>

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>June&#039;16 - Serve the City</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/06/28/june16-serve-the-city/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 28 Jun 2016 22:30:55 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=659</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The project week at AZC Maastricht started rather rough for 6 of our students, coming from 5 countries- Syria, Palestine, Morocco, Bulgaria and France. However, in the first days we established the genuine need for such a project in a place such as AZC Maastricht- The refugee center in Maastricht.

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/servethecity.png" rel="attachment wp-att-660"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-660" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/servethecity.png" alt="servethecity" width="754" height="435" /></a>

In the beginning couple of days, we attempted to inquire into the true needs and perhaps preferences of the people we started to meet at the refugee center. Through very personal contacts and conversations, we established that the main need for the people there was something in the form of activities that would make their day less gray and make them happier each day in order to decrease the prolonged time that they have to spend often away from their families through having fun in the form of activities and listening to their diverse and very interesting stories.
We succeeded in diversifying their quotidian and making sure that they would spend their time in a slightly different way than the one they have had before through sports tournaments, group discussions, group activities such as cooking or just walking. Such activities reached our set objective and helped to us to develop our personality and mindset.
The values that we had in mind for our project, and the mission we wanted to fulfil were similar to the ones of UWC.

With values such as compassion and service, mutual responsibility and respect and many other UWC Values, we started our project week full of enthusiasm to help others,
Each value played a big role in our work and helped influencing the way we deal with people in AZC, and the fact that we were able to share those values was very uplifting for us and was an achievement by itself.
The outcome was quite satisfying as well as we managed to meet most of the objectives that we had set previously.

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/servethecity2.png" rel="attachment wp-att-662"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-662" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/servethecity2.png" alt="servethecity2" width="679" height="429" /></a> <a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/servethecity1.png" rel="attachment wp-att-661"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-661" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/servethecity1.png" alt="servethecity1" width="637" height="407" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>659</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2016-06-28 22:30:55]]></wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2016-06-28 22:30:55]]></wp:post_date_gmt>

	<item>
		<title>June&#039;16 - The Water Project</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/06/28/june16-the-water-project/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 28 Jun 2016 22:36:28 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=664</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">5 team members of water project: Bruno, Kylie, Pietro, Naim and Tamar decided to compose a project week connected to the problem of water consumption not only in the school itself but in the local community: Maastricht. After several meetings we agreed on 2 major activities we wanted to undertake in this small period of time. First two days we spend researching and executing several trials to make homemade toothpaste, together with a small advertisement.</span>

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/kiitan.png" rel="attachment wp-att-665"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-665" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/kiitan.png" alt="kiitan" width="615" height="452" /></a>

<span style="font-weight: 400;"> Regular toothpastes from shop contain a large amount of plastic and chemicals in it, moreover the production of such a good creates a lot of plastic waste since it’s tube can not be reused. Therefore our homemade toothpaste would be healthier for teeth and more sustainable, since we plan to reuse the glass jars. The last two days we went to the city and interviewed people asking them if they were aware about their water consumption habits. As we could see by the people’s reactions during the interviews, a lot of people are still not aware of their water footprint i.e. how much water they use in their daily lives. This causes them to over consume water while around billion people lack access to clean water. It was a surprise even for us to come across a fact that by 2025, two-thirds of the world’s population is expected to be facing water shortages.</span>

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/waterproject.png" rel="attachment wp-att-666"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-666" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/waterproject.png" alt="waterproject" width="573" height="376" /></a>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">We are ready to set up a toothpaste enterprise during next year that can reduce water consumption, and we have footage for a documentary that we are going to show to school when we’re done cutting important parts and editing. We also think the documentary will have room outside the school. With this, we are contributing towards a more sustainable future which is part of the UWC values.
</span>

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/waterproject1.png" rel="attachment wp-att-667"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-667" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/waterproject1.png" alt="waterproject1" width="872" height="391" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>664</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2016-06-28 22:36:28]]></wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2016-06-28 22:36:28]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[june16-the-water-project]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>

	<item>
		<title>June&#039;16 - Mensa Furniture</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/06/28/june16-mensa-furniture/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 28 Jun 2016 22:42:26 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=669</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">UWCM has many places for people to spend time together, from the common rooms to people’s own individual rooms. For events the school can be considered a nice meeting spot, offering places for both conferences and meetings. However, a nice area that offers everyone a place to just really chill and relax was not present on campus the way it should. </span>

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-671" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/furniture2.png" alt="furniture2" width="692" height="190" />

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Our PW decided to face that issue and work on the mensa. We saw an opportunity to create something for everyone on campus to enjoy for a long time to come. We decided to use wooden pallets to create some extra furniture for mensa as well as redecorate it. On day three we had accomplished a lot. We had made two couches, and one table which we also painted. We got three rugs to add to the decoration and two closets, one of which we painted. Another couch that can be turned into a bed was donated to us and we constructed it and added it to the mensa. We added the lanterns from the graduation to make it even better looking. </span>

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-672" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/furniture3.png" alt="furniture3" width="502" height="369" />
<p style="text-align: left;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">The place looks a much more nice, and our hard work made the mensa chill area look much better. Our work paid off as it is already more inhabited. Of course we linked our project week to the UWC values as well. All of us had <strong>personal challenge</strong> as we set out to create a better mensa. We learned about construction and challenged ourselves in order to make our project as good as possible. <strong>Respect for the environment</strong> is yet another value we upheld. We recycled wooden pallets and reused old material in order to make the mensa look as nice as we could. Instead of buying new furniture, we went to the second hand store and reused old furniture as well.
<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/furniture.png" rel="attachment wp-att-670"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-670" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/furniture.png" alt="furniture" width="521" height="399" /></a> <a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/furniture2.png" rel="attachment wp-att-671">
</a></span></p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>June&#039;16 - CNME</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2016/07/01/june16-cnme/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 01 Jul 2016 12:48:19 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=689</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This year a group of 5 students did a project at an organization called CNME. It is called Centrum voor Natuur en Milieu Educatie which is a place to learn about nature, environmental education and apply it to real life in Maastricht. The CNME is a group that makes Maastricht beautiful again and makes more safer spaces for endangered species such as the slow worm and podarcis muralis (a reptile that lives on stones).

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/lizard.png" rel="attachment wp-att-690"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-690" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/lizard.png" alt="lizard" width="612" height="413" /></a>

During the project week we worked in the North-West area of Maastricht. We worked in closed and open areas. On top of the roof and on the ground. Some days it was boiling heat and others were not too bad.
On the first day we went to Fort Willem and cutted grass on top of a roof. This took the whole day because there was a lot of grass. It was a nice day to scrap all the grass and to throw it of the roof in the truck. We were all hard at work, cleaning it that grass was nice and smooth.
The second was the hardest of them all, not of work but of the weather. It was soo hot that we had take a lot more breaks than we expected but we got a lot of work done too.
The best moment was to walk in the tunnels because it was very nice and chilly in there.
The third day was cutting away the “Japanese knotweed” away because there are no animals that live underneath it and it is extremely invasive. So we had to make sure that it wouldn’t grow on different spots which made us dig to the root of those plants.
The last day was a nice way of finishing our project week, we had to clean stone and grass so when it does get hot outside, the podarcis muralis can warm faster because of the stones absorbing heat faster.
After this project all of us felt that we had made difference to the Maastricht community and we hope next there will be a group going to the CNME to get the same experience as we did
Thank you CNME,

Christian, Leander, Joel, Joey &amp; Ronald]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Feb&#039;17 - Prague I., the Kangaroo Orphanage</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2017/03/16/feb17-prague-project-week-with-the-kangaroo-orphanage/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 16 Mar 2017 09:31:55 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=696</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Our project week group consist of Arabi, Martha, Marion, Alejo, Tereza, Sydney, Zaafir, Jeremiah, Yi Wynn, and Abdul. We conducted this project week based on the idea from Tereza a native of the Czech Republic. The Kangaroo Orphanage is a halfway house of sorts where children are placed until they either are moved to a permanent long term orphanage or the court awards a guardian custody. The House was a somewhat beautiful light in something that when you pause and think is a very sad situation. With Tereza as our Guide, we undertook a variety of challenges and learning objectives. The ones we followed were:
<ul>
	<li>Design and pursue a student-led project.</li>
	<li>Provide a service to an organization/community.</li>
	<li>Organize activities outside the campus.</li>
	<li>Explore a new country and culture.</li>
	<li>Improve your organisation, communication and collaboration skills.</li>
	<li>Get to know more about yourself and your group.</li>
	<li>Achieve a positive (social) change.</li>
</ul>
We achieved the first goal of designing and pursuing a student-led project. By planning this project we fulfil this first goal. With Tereza, a native of Prague,  at the helm of the designing the project we arranged times and dates to go to the orphanage along with how to get from our Airbnb to the orphanage which was out of walking distance, to say the least being two metro changes and two buses away. We pre-arrange our service activities at the orphanage where needed and they requested that we play  with the young kids and paint in the morning and the entire group playing games and telling the older children, now returned from school, about our countries.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-697" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/PW-prague.jpg" alt="PW prague" width="2500" height="1666" />

We explored the goal of organising activities outside the campus which proved to be quite the challenge because one has to account for not only age but also language. Most children spoke little English if any at all and we found ourself at the time heavily leaning on Tereza for what we called “English Subtitles” for the insistent Czech chatter. The activities we organised were talking about our countries, Argentinian Dance courtesy of our Argentinian Alejo, Frisbee, tag, hide and seek, and also a Czech game the children taught us called vybika. We also participated in some activities which the children came up with like horse where we had children on our back for much of the play time along with a particularly delightful talent show with beautiful songs by the children, all of which Tereza told us later were about love and some about how lovers leave and abandon the. We were perplexed, to say the least. The children also learned new words along the way like numbers, introductory phrase, ‘high five’ and “come tomorrow’ which broke all of the hearts on our last day.

We also got the opportunity to explore Prague and the Culture visiting Prague Castle, the national museum, Charles bridge, john Lennon wall, and the escape room famous in Eastern Europe. We even manage to taste some traditional Czech food and learn a few works like “Ahoy!’ And ‘Diki’. We also picked up some historical and architectural aspects of Prague from a tour we accidentally end up following. The goal of Improving our organisation, communication and collaboration skills was by our largest area by far.

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/prague-pw-2.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-698"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-698" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/prague-pw-2.jpg" alt="prague pw 2" width="2500" height="1667" /></a>

With ten people every length of the journey requires organisational skills. From food to finding a balance between meeting the wants of each individual and the group as well. With meeting every night we manage to untangle who would cook dinner each night since it was cheaper, and bedroom arrangements. When we met a decision that not all agreed on a discussion was conducted allowing for everyone who wished to express themselves

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-700" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/pw-prague.jpg" alt="pw prague" width="2500" height="1667" />

For me, I learned that in a group setting with 15 people leaving with a flat I learned that personally at times it's good to take time for yourself to get air to breathe and simple stop and take in the moment that you are alive and in this vibrant and eclectic city. I learned that in my group role assignment was important because it allowed for tasked to be shared and organisation.
In conclusion, The end result of a project week is to make some impact in the society within which you are operating. For us, I believe the impact we made is giving the children exposure to people from a variety of places, races, languages, and ethnicities. In what another part of their life will they get to meet or see a Syrian, a Malaysian and a Bahamian in the same room. In a place where they have one map which still had Yugoslavia on it; exposure to these different peoples in a positive environment can leave a lasting impression.

&nbsp;

Diky Praha!]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Feb&#039;17 - Prague II.</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2017/03/17/702/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 17 Mar 2017 07:48:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=702</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>Stefano Santori, Ana Santos, Alex Belo, Camila Lindo, Asbjorn Hansen</strong>

[spacer height="10px"]
<h3>Design and pursue a student-led project</h3>
We had very little help from adults, which was a challenge. We had to be responsible enough to be able to fulfil the objectives of the project week and to keep engaging with the community even when things weren’t on our side. As students, we end up messing up and making mistakes, but those make us grow up and learn way more than if everything turned out alright with very little to almost no challenge. I can say on behalf of the whole group that we learned so much and we grew so much from the 5 days we spent in Prague.
<h3></h3>
<h3>Provide a service to an organization/community.</h3>
Although we did not manage to work with the hospital we went one day to volunteer in an orphanage to paint the walls of a room and in another day we made sandwiches and distributed them to the homeless people in Prague. This made me realise that although these small actions will not make a big difference in the orphanage and will not end homelessness in Prague they help and make people keep a smile on their faces as being helped is always an enjoyable experience.

<em> <img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-703" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/pw01.jpg" alt="pw01" width="1334" height="1000" /></em>
<h6 style="text-align: center;"><em>The making of the sandwiches </em></h6>
<h3><em> </em>Organise activities outside the campus</h3>
The biggest conclusion that I took from helping to organise a project week is that things might not go as expected. The process itself of organising activities is a bit challenging as I had to come up with ideas of activities to entertain patients in the hospital such as playing the guitar.  But the most challenging part was to come up with activities to help the community when the hospital denied us a chance to work with them. Nevertheless, in the end, we come up with the idea of distributing sandwiches to homeless people in Prague and that was probably as rewarding as helping others

<img class="aligncenter wp-image-704 size-medium" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/pw02-225x300.jpg" alt="pw02" width="225" height="300" />
<h6 style="text-align: center;">Giving sandwiches to the homeless</h6>
<h3>Explore a new country and culture</h3>
Since the very beginning, we understood that Prague was going to be an unexpected beauty. The small streets surrounded by coloured buildings that opened themselves in stunning squares with architectures from the Italian renaissance. Hospitable smiles from the locals in the small cafes and light happiness while crossing the famous bridge with our eyes full of the cathedral’s peaks are the things that we’ll remember the most.
<h3>Improve your organisation, communication and collaboration skills</h3>
The project week was a great way to really understand what life ends up being like. Things don’t work out, there are miscommunications and we have to learn how to turn those problems around. The week we were in Prague we were met with multiple challenges, people that only spoke Czech, not wanting to collaborate with us. We had to stick as a group and rely on each other. We had to come up with a brand new project week and we did it, as a team.
<h3>Get to know more about yourself and your group</h3>
Walking for kilometres in the city created a special bond between us. Talks about how different or similar the city was compared to our cities made us share moments and anecdotes between the group. Shoutout of freedom while watching Prague from the edge of the castle in the late afternoon’s light, a moment of silence and reflection, that won’t leave us for a long time and gave us something with a deeper level of sensation.

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/pw01.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-703">
</a> <a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/pw02.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-704">
</a> <a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/pw03.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-705"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-705" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/pw03.jpg" alt="pw03" width="2048" height="1365" /></a>
<h6 style="text-align: center;"><em>Prague from the castle</em></h6>
<h6 style="text-align: center;"></h6>
<h3 style="text-align: left;">Achieve a positive (social) change</h3>
Since the NGO working with the hospital, ended up not wanting to collaborate with us we decided to go around the city and help the homeless. Distributing sandwiches in hopes of making their day better and brighter. The smiles we got, the “thank you” was something that warmed all of our hearts and I believe will stay with us. We were able to, hopefully, helped those people a little. Big changes start with small actions.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Feb&#039;17 - Art in Paris</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2017/03/17/feb16-art-in-paris/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 17 Mar 2017 10:17:15 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=714</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[&nbsp;

This is an art based project in Paris and we will explore the different arts in museums and street arts. It will also focus on how does the refugee crisis in Europe impact the newly created art (if there are any). We will interview one artists with different age group, and some the refugees.

[spacer height="10px"]

In our first day we visited museum ‘’Musee du Montmartre’’, according to the website it supposed to be an old museum but after we went there we could not find any art from the 16 or 17 century. Therefore, we counted it as a modern one.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-716" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/20170302_134838-1.jpg" alt="20170302_134838" width="2576" height="1932" />

In our second day, we had to visit the second biggest and popular museum in Paris ‘’musee de orsay’’. But the challenge was in finding the way to get there. We took the Metro, but the wrong one. However, after we spend two hours to reach it, we also had to wait for almost one and half other hour in the line to get there.  It was a very famous old museum and we got to see a lot of old art from many artiest French and non-French. We got more idea about art in Paris’s museums and about Paris itself. As every evening we were giving our self a chance to go out and explore Paris. We visiting some popular tourist places in Paris like the tower and the Notre dame cathedral.<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/20170302_134838.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-715">
</a>[spacer height="10px"]

We used to visit museums every day, even the day we supposed to visit the artist and interview her. In the third day we interviewed the artiest and we recorded the interview. She was originally from Iran, but migrate to France 25 years ago, and she graduated from an art university in France. Today she is an art teacher and she has a small studio and she teaches in her own way, because there are many things she doesn’t agree with the other French way of teaching art. The questions were about her journey in the art field and what are the changes that she has realized in the Modern art and what are the challenges she faces as an artist in Paris. The interview was an open conversation that we recorded.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-717" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/20170227_122535.jpg" alt="20170227_122535" width="3264" height="1836" />

In our last day, we visited the Louvre, and it was much huger than we expected. We saw so many old art from the 16th and 17<sup>th</sup>, but of course we couldn’t finish quarter of it.

[spacer height="10px"]

If we will give a summary about the different between the old and modern art and how technology influence the modern art in Paris. In the 16<sup>th</sup> and 17<sup>th</sup> most of the arts were a religious based art and most of them seemed to have the same colours. While the modern art have different ways of using the colours and the idea of exhibitions is much used. The arties said that she is also a singer, she 10 years ago she came up with an idea of painting while she is singing, and she wanted to spread it Paris and teach it for the new generation, but sadly she was not allowed to do it because there was no references for it. That is why she said ‘’ In Paris the mother of art city, they don’t allowed you to create any art, you just have to copy what was already there, and I don’t consider this as a modern art.’’[spacer height="10px"]

We also failed to find any street art in Paris, the government does not allowed that because they want to keep the city as historical as it is. We also asked the arties about refugee and how if there are any opportunities for them in the art field, but the answer was an expected. She said in Paris people don’t care how brave you are in your art work and idea unless you are from a developed countries like, America, Netherlands, and Italy….so on. Therefore, refugees here have no chances at all until now. She said ‘’ even me who came here 25 years ago, I got rejected from many chances because I am from Iran’’.

[spacer height="10px"]

One thing we did not like about Paris was the traffic, to some extent it was very risky and unorganised, people don’t care about the traffic light at all, even if it is time for walker to pass cars will still keep going. We also felt the city was resist somehow, in some areas we observed that there were only Arab people, and in other only black people. As there were so many homeless people everywhere.  But the people in general were very nice and helpful, many people were advising us to be careful and to take care of our self and properties, and they were helping us to find our way.

[spacer height="10px"]

In conclusion, we learnt a lot from this project. We get to know each other more by dividing the work between us, each of us learned something new. For example Rabab learnt how to cook, Hoza and Len learned how to read physical maps. We learned about the refugee in the art field, some French cultures and a lot about art in the mother of art city.  Some of us already planned their next project that will be focused on the refugee homeless in Paris.

[spacer height="10px"]

We faced so many challenges to achieve this project, but we were all patient and by encouraging each other we were able to make it.

&nbsp;

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Feb&#039;17 - Manchester College in University of Oxford  (Tate Library)</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2017/03/23/feb16-manchester-college-in-university-of-oxford-tate-library/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 23 Mar 2017 08:31:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=725</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In essence, it is a time for students to spend a designated amount of hours a day helping a community, organisation or a target group of a choice to improve their overall work dynamics. In most cases, the point of this activity is that both parties will benefit in a way, whether it would be long-lasting or respectively short-term.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-726" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/pw-mira.jpg" alt="pw mira" width="510" height="907" />

My project week took place in between the dates of 27<sup>th</sup> of February and 3<sup>rd</sup> of March in Manchester College’s library, part of the University of Oxford. They working hours I and the head of the library agreed on was 7 hours a day, starting at 9 am with an hour for lunch break and finishing at 5 pm. A very curious fact I hot to learn about the institution itself was that this is, in reality, the smallest college in Oxford out all of them it is equipped with the 6<sup>th </sup>biggest college library amongst them.

[spacer height="10px"]

On my first day I was very puzzled with the fact there are only two permanent persons working the 60,000 books library, but I soon realised that a practice for them is to attract volunteers who come and go and help them manage the workload. Moreover, a common practice is to have a cataloger who joins them every week but is not part of the everyday work dynamics. At the beginning of the very first day, they introduced me to the rest of the people working the college itself during the lunch break which took place in the dining hall. My first day’s  job if you want to call it this way consisted mainly of relabeling books in order for them to meet the international agreed on code, which appears to be easier for students to understand since is the same in most libraries. As it turned out this is not an easy task and a proof for this was the number of months it took them to only partially finish the project, which started in the summer of last year.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-727" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/pw-mira2.jpg" alt="pw mira2" width="982" height="552" />

Over the week I got to do a variety of tasks, from relabeling books, to selling second copies on amazon and describing the series the library had, but no longer needed. This is a method they use in order to get rid of the things they are not interested in and simultaneously make shelf-space for the requested books by the students from the university.

[spacer height="10px"]

On another note, the route I took from Maastricht to Oxford, I did with a train from Maastricht train station to Brussels-midi, from where I got a train to London (Eurostar, therefore I had to go through security and be there an hour in advance). After arriving at the London train station, one should take a subway for 4 stops in order to catch the OxfordTube which will take them to Oxford.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>April&#039;17 - Musicadeau</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2017/05/02/april17-musicadeau/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 02 May 2017 06:45:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=734</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">During Easter, my friend, Muaad, and I devoted our time to work on our Youth Social Entrepreneurship, Musicadeau. We did so in hopes of Musicadeau becoming a reality in the next school year. </span>

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/musicadeau.png" rel="attachment wp-att-736"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-736" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/musicadeau.png" alt="musicadeau" width="651" height="236" /></a>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">In essence, Musicadeau will become a one-day event where we invite amateur bands from respectively United World College Maastricht, local high schools and Maastricht University to perform at an external venue. The purpose of this event is to support an NGO with the profit we will gain from the event. Also, to give small and upcoming bands a chance to play in front of an audience. It is quite a task to establish this event and therefore it was needed for us to use the considerable time for planning it. This project week allowed us to do so. We managed to work on the logistical challenges such as which venue to contact, how to advertise the event. Furthermore, we worked on the budgetary aspect of the event. Many expected and unexpected costs came up through our research and work. We finished the schedule of the event itself. Now, we seem ready to pitch our YSE project on May the 3</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">rd</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">. Hopefully, this project week has given us an advantage when pitching our project. </span>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>734</wp:post_id>

	<item>
		<title>April&#039;16 - Celestial bouquets - Slovakia</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2017/05/02/april16-celestial-bouquets-slovakia/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 02 May 2017 14:10:31 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=738</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<b>FIRST DAY OF THE ADVENTURE </b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">When we arrived in Slovakia, the first thing we noticed is that the diversity was very different from The Netherlands. We arrived at the house in Štefanová and unpacked our things at 8 pm. We were all really excited to explore the nature because it was so green and there was a lot of snow; some of our other friends experienced snow for the very first time. It was so nice to just see the happiness on their faces and see them enjoy the snow; we obviously had a snowball fight… we were all very tired and decided to sleep, for a long time…</span>

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/pwsk1.png" rel="attachment wp-att-742"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-742" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/pwsk1.png" alt="pwsk1" width="691" height="406" /></a>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">The next day, some of us hiked to a hill nearby with snow on it while waiting for the others to come back from grocery shopping. It was a lot of fun to casually have a walk in the, already on the first day, stunning surroundings of nature. We took our cameras and made pictures of each other and of the flowers, nature, and landscape around us; of course, we had time for a snowball fight in between! We already noticed that there was a lot of mud and made a lot of jokes about all the possible ways that we would get completely drenched in mud/water; little did we know...</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">When we were settled in and the groceries had been done, we decided to do our first hike. The hike we did was a hike that ended up going to potentially 1200m height. We started the hike in the part which wasn’t completely snow-ified and had a lot of grass and diverse variety of plants. This quickly changed once we got higher in the mountains, where a lot of snow (+- 35 cm) was to be seen literally everywhere we walked. We all really enjoyed playing in the snow and we were really fascinated by the amazing views that Slovakia offered. We went from high to low, from cold to warm, from saturated to hungry.  </span>

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/pwsk5.png" rel="attachment wp-att-743"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-743" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/pwsk5.png" alt="pwsk5" width="637" height="467" /></a>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">We ended up walking at 8 pm, in the dark, freezing to death, not knowing exactly where we were going, to get back to Štefanová. There were mostly pine trees in the top of the hike and in the lower parts we could find a variety of small flowers, grouped up together in patches spread over the landscape. The higher we got, the lesser plants grew which could withstand the cold.</span>

<b>[spacer height="20px"]SECOND DAY</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">The second day a lot of the snow had gone and we decided to take a shorter more low-lying hike. We went on a hike that went near a waterfall and didn’t have any snow that we had to walk through (which was a pretty nice change after yesterday, which were swimming in the snow). During this hike, we explored a lot more of the forest area of Slovakia. Similarly, to the first part of the hike of the previous day, during this hike we saw a lot of different, and might we say beautiful, flowers grouped up together in patches and a diversity in where they grow. The nature was clearly appreciated in Slovakia, as there were a couple of signs that mentioned that the nature is protected and pollution is punishable, for the greater good of the environment.</span>

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/pwsk3.png" rel="attachment wp-att-740"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-740" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/pwsk3.png" alt="pwsk3" width="634" height="417" /></a> <a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/pwsk4.png" rel="attachment wp-att-739"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-739" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/pwsk4.png" alt="pwsk4" width="598" height="396" /></a>

&nbsp;

<b>[spacer height="20px"]THIRD DAY</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">On the third day, we decided to step up our game again, we went even higher than on Monday. Today we climbed a hill, which showed the same diversity when it comes to plants and flowers. One thing that struck us was that when we went to an open field at a lower altitude, we could see a lot of small colourful flowers. However, when we went to some open plains at a higher altitude where the wind blew very harshly and viciously, the number of flowers was pretty much none.</span>

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/pwsk2.png" rel="attachment wp-att-741"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-741" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/pwsk2.png" alt="pwsk2" width="588" height="391" /></a>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Tomorrow we are packing our stuff and the day after, we’re going back to Prague and eventually the same evening we are going back to school. Before this, we are going to the Garden of Tereza’s grandparents, to help them do gardening and serve the community while we are at it. </span>

<b>[spacer height="20px"]LAST DAY</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Today we went to the grandparents, with the plan to help them maintain their garden for them as an exchange for helping us with a lot of stuff when coming and staying in Slovakia. Unfortunately, the weather got the better of us and it started raining continuously from the moment we arrived until the middle of the night; this did not kill the spirit of our group, nothing does for that matter, and we decided to sit inside and join the grandparents who cooked food for us, traditional Slovak obviously. It was absolutely, stunningly, overwhelmingly, gorgeously good food; on this we could all agree. It started with traditionally made goulash with some sort of steamed bread, followed by numerous amounts of offers for wine. We immediately noticed that it was not common to decline the offer. An interesting thing we noticed was that alcohol plays a much bigger part in social structures of families and friends than in Western-Europe. In Slovakia, the offer for alcohol is not really for you to decide whether you’d like some alcohol, but for them to offer you the drink. After declining the drink they actually didn’t really understand what we were doing, it was so uncommon. In Western-Europe you offer someone the drink because they want a glass of wine; here, one offers the wine as a gesture of kindness, declining shows a disrespect for their kindness. We were, through the help of Tereza, able to explain that it was definitely not the case!</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">After this, we sat on the couch and played some card games while socializing with the grandparents. It was really nice to see that especially the grandfather wanted to really talk about our nationalities; for example, Amsterdam – Ajax, Cameroon – He had a study friend from there, etc. It was really sweet of them to be so involved with us, and we told them we greatly appreciated their kindness and openheartedness.</span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">We learned during this trip that dedication and perseverance is a key challenge that a lot of us had to overcome because there were times where we were exhausted but had to keep going, and we are proud and grateful of our group that we really helped each other and were very thoughtful of each other when it came to the challenges that each of us had to overcome. There are always going to be things which you cannot change, you must adapt. And that is exactly the thing that we learned on this trip. You cannot control the rain, the temperature, the light. All of this is for us as a group to adapt to and overcome these things. Once done, it is the most satisfying thing to be on that hill, or to be on that mountain, to have crossed that river, to come home on time, to be able to make that meal. All of this shapes us, and all of it contributed to an amazing project week full of experience and joy. This was not only a UWC experience, it was also the trip where we gained memories for life!</span>

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>April&#039;16 - Bosnia: The orphans are no longer alone</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2017/05/10/april16-bosnia-the-orphans-are-no-longer-alone/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 10 May 2017 13:39:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=747</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The project has been done starts from 25<sup>th</sup> of April until 29<sup>th</sup> of April, and it was basically activities with Orphans youth from the age 15 years to 18, at the organisation called "Bridge of mercy" in the city of Sarajevo and some other students came from Zenica. The first day was a presentation from me to the organization about the UWCM, and my personal experience for a year here at UWCM, followed by a presentation from the organization about how it works and their project, and it end up by some activities to get to know to students that I will be working with.<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/pwr4.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-751"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-751 size-large" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/pwr4-e1494423527618-1024x768.jpg" alt="pwr4" width="700" height="525" /></a>

The second day was the trip to UWC Mostar, there were 8 students and me, we arrived at the college at 10:30, and we left at 3:30, me, the organization and the college have done short presentations about our work, and after we went to take a look around the city and to the old bridge. It was really good experience and I was very lucky to be there.

<img class="aligncenter wp-image-748 size-full" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/pwr2-e1494423483497.jpg" alt="pwr2" width="1278" height="720" />

The third day was the multicultural dinner at my uncle's home, and before we played various games, and after all slept over in my uncle's house. The next day we woke up so excited to do the Holy day, but it was so cold, then it was snowing, so we cancelled the Holy day, and instead, I took them to the Cinema and we watched the film (The Fate of the Furious).

<a href="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/pwr3.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-750"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-750" src="http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/pwr3.jpg" alt="pwr3" width="1378" height="1032" /></a>

In the 29<sup>th</sup> of April I left Bosnia by bus, the journey took 26 hours, passing Croatia, Slovenia, Austria, Germany to the Netherlands, it was such a nice experience from the beginning to the end, and I advise everyone to do something new with people you do not know in a place you have not visited before. This is the true value of the project week, and I learnt a lot of things in only five days: the good management except catch-up the bus, because I missed my bus to Bosnia, and the only option was to fly, and how to do things and work with new people without any help, and the students were not strong in English.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>April&#039;16 - One World Documentary Film Festival Brussels</title>
		<link>http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/2017/06/19/april16-one-world-documentary-film-festival-brussels/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 19 Jun 2017 07:46:44 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[olaya]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uwcmaastrichtimpact.com/?p=756</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div><em>We (Luana, Johnathan, Marilena, Sarah and Willow) went to Brussels for the One World Documentary film festival organised by a school called Atheneum Brussels. In the 5 days, we watched 5 documentaries about human rights and had a panel with experts for each topic afterwards. On Monday we watched the War Show about the Syrian war; On Tuesday we watched Plastic China about pollution; On Wednesday we watched Prison Sisters about Afghan women's rights; On Thursday we watched the Opposition about civilians being forced to leave home in New Papua Guinea; On Friday we watched the Pearl of Africa about a transgender’s story in Uganda. The overall experience was great in terms of the movies and the connection we’ve made with the local school and host families.</em></div>]]></content:encoded>
